PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions Assets/Income Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
A petition signed by 71 citizens of Australia, electors of Western Australia pray that:

During the forthcoming amendments to the Social Security Pensions Assets/Income tests, consideration be given to young disabled persons on Invalid Pensions who are handicapped to the extent that they cannot enjoy a normal life style.

Financial support can be forthcoming during the lifetime of the caring parents but there is constant worry that the continued assistance they afford may be threatened by the very normal process of a parental bequest. This ordinary family procedure could in some cases deprive the very basic pension entitlement to those who are unable to help themselves.
Your petitioners therefore pray: That consideration be given to the following: (1) Separate asset/income test for invalid/handicapped pensioners and (2) Financial limits be set higher.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Representation Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

We the undersigned citizens of Australia believe that there is no justification for increasing the size of the Parliament, and therefore humbly petition the Senate to reject the proposed Representation Act 1983 which provides for 36 more federal politicians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Rating System
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable President and members of the Senate assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That the Rates Ordinance for the Australian Capital Territory needs to be amended so that the burden of rates for the Australian Capital Territory is spread more equitably amongst all the rate payers of the Australian Capital Territory. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate: An inquiry be initiated to inquire into the ACT rating system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

2. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

3. We call upon the Federal Government, however, to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own special programs and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

4. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State/Territory Governments, to ensure a planned programme of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. We deplore the unprincipled and self-interested attacks being orchestrated by minority sects and groups against the policies and person of the Commonwealth Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, the Hon. Senator Susan Ryan.
2. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non non-government school costs.

3. We endorse the Federal Government's principal opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

4. We call upon the Federal Government, however, to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own special programs and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

5. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State/Territory Governments, to ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Robertson (from 34 citizens) and Zakharov (from 507 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectfully showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decision which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Non-Government School Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every child in Australia is entitled to government financial support for their education whether they attend government schools or non-government schools .

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that urgent consideration be given to a favourable decision for the continuation of Federal Government per capita grants payable in respect of all children in non-government schools at a rate calculated as a percentage of Government standard costs at a level not less than that prevailing in 1983.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 681 citizens), Scott (from 11 citizens) and Sibraa (from 24 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to undermine civil liberties and religious freedom. It could also be a means of undermining the traditional family structure of our nation.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, should-
Delay the Bill and ask: That the Government set up a Joint Parliamentary Committee to examine:
(a) The implications of the United Nations Covenant for public policy, the extent of Australian commitments, responsibility and accountability in terms of the Covenant,
(b) The full effects of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 for public policy in giving effect to the United Nations Covenant.
The terms of reference of the Joint Parliamentary Committee to be widely publicised and oral and written submission sought from interested organisations and individuals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 14 citizens), Walters (from 147 citizens) and Watson ( from 42 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc., for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled: should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 30 citizens), Bjelke-Petersen (from 370 citizens), Boswell (from 335 citizens) and Robertson (from four citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school 'community' provide an environment condusive to the development, including moral development of their children.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled; should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 12 citizens), Bjelke-Petersen (from five citizens) and Robertson (from 181 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Welfare Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That there is grave cause for concern in the Australian community at the continuing sensationalist media and political campaign directed against the humanitarian and socially just effects of the welfare state (most recently exemplified by the frontpage article 'One in 4 get Welfare Hand' in the Melbourne Herald of Monday, 3rd October 1983).

That, whilst enlarging public awareness of the critical social problems facing our community, such articles tend to paint the victims of our social system as worthless parasites living off the work force.

1. We believe that the 635,000 persons receiving unemployment benefits at the end of June 1983 deserve full support from the Commonwealth, and that the 85,104 persons receiving sickness and special benefits deserve society's sympathy rather than castigation.

2. We also believe that the 2,011,542 persons receiving age, invalid, wife and widow pensions, supporting parent benefits and sheltered employment allowances at the end of June 1983 deserve help from the Commonwealth.

3. We affirm that it is the time-honoured and moral right of Australians to receive assistance in times of distress and hardship, and we remind the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia of its profound responsibility to safeguard and enhance the dignity and well-being of its citizens.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of local governments in Australia shows that:
General revenue grants to local government under personal income tax sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83,
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent,
The increase in grants to State governments over the same period was 11.8 per cent,
Increased demands are being made on local government authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g. Community Employment Program,
The Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in general revenue grants to local government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to local government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 14 citizens) and Lewis (from 11 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty-two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a referendum rejected the introduction of territorial government or local government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to territorial or local government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action or legislation in respect of territorial or local government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament House. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth our complete opposition to any stage of the nuclear industry. We wish to inform you of our support for union bans aimed against the uranium industry. We look forward to a society that respects life, opposes violence and recognises our total dependence on our global ecosystem.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament take action to halt mining, milling and export of Australian uranium and put people before profit.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That, with the exception of the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows.
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
The chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jack Evans (from 21 citizens), Foreman (from 20 citizens), Maguire ( from 20 citizens) and Robertson (from 42 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Subsidy for Student Colleges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the reduction in the subsidy to tertiary student residential colleges of twenty-five per cent announced in the Federal Budget will:

1. Increase the financial hardship already being experienced by Australian students. The cut in subsidies to colleges will undoubtedly increase fees for that accommodation in 1984. Many students will be forced out of tertiary education as they will not be able to meet these increased costs particularly as the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme only gained a maximum increase of $2.80 per week in the Federal Budget.

2. Decrease access to education for country students. Many country students live in college accommodation either to attend tertiary institutions in the metropolitan area or in regional centres. The cut in the subsidy to residential colleges will even further disadvantage this group of students who already have comparatively low participation rates in tertiary education.
Your petitioners therefore call upon the Senate to ensure.
(1) That the full subsidy to student college accommodation is immediately restored.
(2) That the Federal Government assume financial responsibility for all student college accommodation to prevent the planned closures of colleges in Victoria.
(3) That two student representatives are appointed to the committee of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission reviewing student housing.

(4) That new forms of college accommodation are investigated which would be more appropriate to the needs of the current student population, i.e. accommodation appropriate for students with dependant children.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Meat Export Inspection Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

1. That Australia's meat exports are being placed in an uncompetitive position by the imposition of substantial Export Meat Inspection Charges whilst Australia 's competitors receive free inspection plus considerable subsidies.

2. These charges are causing substantial loss of business for export abattoir operators and loss of jobs for their employees due to the disparity in inspection costs of export and non-export works arising from a 200 per cent increase in Federal Government charges at export works.

3. That immediate steps should be taken to end serious injury being done by these charges to export abattoir operators, their employees, livestock producers and all others dependant on the Australian Meat and Livestock industry.
Your petitioners therfore humbly pray that the Federal Government will act to immediately suspend all Export Inspection Charges for a period of three years
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Coates (from 279 citizens) and Scott (from 668 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Mr Arnold Tatarenko
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we are deeply concerned for the well being of Mr Arnold Tatarenko, a member of the unofficial Pentecostalist congregation of the Dnepropetrovsk region of the Ukrainian SSR.
2. That Mr Tatarenko has been imprisoned for the non-violent exercise of his religious beliefs.
3. That the Australian Government lend its support to initiatives by Amnesty International, which has adopted Mr Tatarenko as a prisoner of conscience.

4. That we urge the Australian Government to make representations to the Government of the Soviet Union to promptly release Mr Tatarenko, all representations made by individual citizens through the embassy of the USSR in Canberra having failed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gietzelt)-by leave-agreed to:

That Senators Chipp and Crowley, having been duly nominated in accordance with the resolution of the Senate dated 17 November 1983, be appointed members of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.
Debate resumed from 16 November 1983, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill. This Bill will have a very significant Committee stage as numerous amendments are to be moved. The Opposition is concerned with electoral matters, electoral justice and representation. We are aware of the ways in which an inadequate electoral system can operate to the disadvantage of any party in politics, or any group of citizens. I am reminded that in New South Wales in 1965 we won government but we had to get 54 per cent of the popular vote at that stage to do so because of the distribution of seats and the way population was distributed. We want to see a system which is fair, equitable and free from any kind of corruption or undue influence of any party; we want to see a system which is efficient and which people can understand.

SPEECH.PARA: The electoral Bill before us now represents a significant review of the Electoral Act. In broad terms, the Opposition supports the objectives of this legislation, the objectives of improving electoral practice, and the Opposition recognises the very valuable work that has been done by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, on the recommendations of which much of the Bill is based. I put on record again our appreciation of the work of that Committee. It worked in Canberra throughout the winter. It produced a very significant first report. It has attracted much bipartisan agreement as to recommendations. Although we will concentrate in this debate on some areas of difference, that should not be allowed to obscure the fact that there has been agreement between parties in this Parliament on many significant matters, and that many joint recommendations have come forward. The Opposition is anxious to assist in any attempts to arrive at an electoral system that encourages maximum participation by voters, which leads to voters being able to cast valid votes, and which enhances the fairness in the system. To this end, those amendments of the Act which seek to simplify the process are welcomed by the Opposition.

This legislation is by no means a departure from many of the long-established features of our electoral system, many of which will be retained. For example, the legislation endorses: single member electorates for the House of Representatives, numbers in each division varying by 10 per cent from the average quota, proportional representation for the Senate, compulsory voting and a preferential system of voting. These features, which we believe to be important, will still remain. In addition, the legislation establishes an Australian Electoral Commission and creates deputy electoral commissioners. The Bill seeks to codify certain Acts of the Parliament. For example, the private member's Bill which went through this place a year or so ago dealing with the divisions of Queensland, for that State to vote as a single State for the purposes of Senate elections, will be codified within this Bill. This is something that is supported by all parties to this debate, certainly by the Opposition. To the extent that the Government is seeking to tidy up legislation, it will attract support.

Before identifying some areas where we have concerns and perhaps flagging some of the areas in regard to which we will, in Committee, offer amendments which we think in many cases will improve the legislation and which in several cases will set out a different view, a view held differently on principle, which we hope might attract the support of the Committee at that stage. I should say that we are not satisfied that what is put up by the Government is the best possible set of amendments to achieve the best possible electoral result. It is for that reason we will be moving a number of amendments. Because of some of our concerns , we are putting forward an amendment to the motion that the Bill be now read a second time. We set out our concern that the Bill will not be in the best interests of democratic practice. I now move:
At the end of motion, add ', but the Senate, whilst acknowledging that the passage of this Bill will improve the efficiency of the electoral system-
(a) deplores those aspects of the legislation which attack individual freedoms, threaten the continuation of the preferential system of voting and introduce public funding; and

(b) requests the Government to withdraw those clauses which require the registration of political parties, the introduction of the list system of voting , the public funding of political parties and the disclosure of political donations'.

Quite apart from these housekeeping aspects of the legislation there are, as set out in the amendment, some fairly insidious moves by the Government to impose an ideological view on the electoral system; a view which might favour a list system of voting; a view which does favour the public funding of political parties. The Opposition objects to these on principle and wants its objections made known in strong terms. In particular, the proposal to take taxpayers' money and pay it to political parties to help fund their election campaigns is something which not only the Opposition but also the majority of Australians do not support.

It might be worth while identifying in broad terms what the Bill does contain. It sets out to establish changes in voting systems; it seeks to reduce informal votes by allowing errors in voting papers not to disqualify votes; it seeks to allow people to vote for reduced numbers of candidates and still cast valid votes in Senate elections; it seeks to use the list system; and it seeks to permit the use of ticks and crosses in the recording of votes. They are all changes to voting systems. The Bill also seeks to change voting procedures. It seeks to close the polls at an earlier hour and it seeks to allow voting by an elector not only in his or her subdivision but also throughout the electoral division. It seeks to permit the display of how to vote cards in the polling booths and it seeks to make it more difficult for people in certain hospitals to apply for and obtain postal votes. In fact, I think certain people would be denied the possibility of getting postal votes. The Bill seeks to introduce provisions for mobile booths and electoral visitors, and it introduces a whole block of changes in relation to postal voting. The Bill seeks to set up automatic registers of postal voters. It seeks to establish postal votes for those who, while not disabled themselves, are caring for people who are disabled . It seeks to make new postal voting arrangements for remote divisions. It seeks to allow formal errors to be corrected by the person receiving a postal vote. We are going to move amendments to many of these provisions. The Bill seeks to allow oral applications for postal votes. It seeks to restrict witnesses to postal vote applications. It seeks to alter voting qualifications and it seeks to make changes in relation to certain Aborigines. It seeks to make changes in relation to certain convicted prisoners. It seeks to make it more simple for people at the age of 17 to enrol for a vote. It seeks to make new arrangements for itinerant voters.

The Bill, in another major swag of amendments, seeks to alter redistribution procedures -to alter the timing and the criteria. It seeks to remove from Parliament the capacity to have any review of proposals. The Bill also seeks to set up the possibility of what it calls 'mini-redistributions'. Therefore, redistributions are another major area in this legislation. The Bill also seeks to introduce a number of provisions in relation to public funding and disclosure . We will discuss this aspect of the Bill during the Committee stage. However, this proposal covers such matters as gifts to political parties. It talks about the valuation of gifts and the writing of regulations to do this. It talks about the levels of public funding which will require disclosure. It talks about enforced disclosures and enforcement procedures. This whole area gives the Opposition considerable cause for concern. The Bill seeks to deal with a number of other miscellaneous things.

I would like to say a few words about the issue of public funding because that is one of the matters on which the Opposition has concerns in principle. We think there are still undesirable features about public funding. We think the public does not have high regard for politicians or political parties. Of course , as politicians we are sorry about that. But we think public funding will lower public regard even further. Australians might well resile from the prospect of having to fund political parties which themselves are not willing to fund their own election promises. We will have to give them money to go to an election in respect of which they will make promises which they will not keep. The advent of public funding will entrench support for established parties irrespective of their performance. They will be entrenched in terms of their support on the basis of the votes they receive at the preceding election. We think this represents the first move to marry political parties in the electoral system, a system which traditionally has dealt with individuals rather than parties. This is the first attempt to bring parties in as entities and we do not believe this will be either healthy or wanted. We do not believe it will be to the benefit of the electoral system. We think it will lessen the influence of the individual voter. It is a concept that the Liberal Party does not support.

Of course, we are a party that believes in the rule of law, and if the will of the Parliament is that certain things should happen, we are not saying that we would not, with reluctance, make use of the provisions. Our colleagues in New South Wales have done so. But let there be no mistake: As a matter of principle we think this proposal is wrong; we do not think it will benefit the electoral system; and we do not think the voters want it. We urge the Senate to use its review capacity to look again at this proposal. We think it is automatic that Labor's move to public funding and the list system, if successful, will require the official registration of political parties. We think if that happens those parties will begin to possess power and authority just by virtue of their having been registered. We think that someone who possesses that registration will be in possession of a powerful asset. We think people should examine very carefully what the long term implications of that might be.
The Opposition is also concerned about the aspects of the legislation which require disclosure of donations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet you are.

—I am interested in Senator Robertson's comment that he bets we are. It illustrates a very interesting difference in approach. We are aware that the Australian Labor Party receives massive support from trade unions. I mention one circumstance involving people I know who are school-teachers. They have told me that donations were forced out of them by the New South Wales Teachers Federation and that the money was then used during the election campaign. These were donations which they did not want to make but which they were forced to give or they would be faced with direct retaliatory action within their union. We are very concerned about some of the ways in which funds are raised from reluctant unionists for funding political parties. We are concerned that the requirement for disclosure, unless sensitively framed and carefully applied, will abrogate a fundamental right of privacy. It could result in many people withdrawing completely from activity in the political process and withdrawing even modest support because they are fearful of retribution if it were to become known publicly that they were involved in helping the political process and in trying to see that one of the parties remained viable. Let me be quite clear about this: Many people on our side of politics fear that there will be retaliatory action from the union movement if it is known that these people are funding a political party. That is the reality, and if Senator Robertson finds it distasteful, so be it. That is an accurate recitation of the concern which many people have.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say a few words about the list system of voting. It is true that the voting process in the Senate can be simplified, but the use of the list system will reduce the effectiveness of the whole concept which lies behind a preferential system of voting. The preferential system is designed to allow voters to exercise an individual preference for candidates or for parties and to express their choice by moving from candidate to candidate. The choice will remain for the elector to go through the process of full preferential selection but by putting a simple tick in a box-if that is what the Parliament decides should happen-one could in a stroke just accept the full how-to-vote instructions of a party. It will entice many people to take up this form of voting.

If this list system is applied to Senate voting, it will introduce disparity between the voting process for the House of Representatives, which is not subject to a list system, and for the Senate which will be. We think that is unfortunate. We think it is far simpler for people to know that when they vote, the process they use will be to follow a full preferential listing of numbers and that that will occur whether they are voting for the House of Representatives or for the Senate. It is very difficult to ask people to use ticks or crosses on one of their voting papers and to write numbers on the other voting paper and not to expect that some inefficiency or unavoidable error will occur as a result. While this might minimise informal votes in one respect, it could well encourage them in another. The fact is, of course, that at present 90 per cent of all electors are able to cast formal votes. That is a credit to the voters. It just puts out of court the claim by the Government that the community cannot handle a full preferential voting system. Clearly, the community can handle it. The fact that 90 per cent of votes are formal indicates to us that the task should be rather to increase that number of formal votes than to try to change it and move to a list system which carries at least as many problems as it does advantages.

The main part of our contribution to the debate will come during the Committee stage. We have some 20 or so amendments to clauses which we will move in the Committee. I hope the Government will be receptive to these Committee stage amendments. Many of them are designed to do things more efficiently. We think there are some better ways than the Government has proposed. Some of the amendments are designed to express a difference in principle, but we hope it will be possible, when the Bill reaches the Committee stage, to improve the legislation. I go back to my opening comments. If our goal is an electoral system which is fair and efficient, which avoids certain corruptions and which is not open to misuse, we will be well satisfied. I ask the Government to give careful consideration to the amendments which we offer. We for our part will try to argue them with appropriate brevity and clarity. I hope that during the Committee stage we can make some progress on a bipartisan basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this very important piece of legislation, the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill, which, I believe, effectively enfranchises many Australian electors for the first time, including many Australians who have voted for many years but have never been able to record a formal vote because of the system. Australia has been crying out for these electoral reforms for decades. Our electoral system is among the most complex in the world. I believe it is unnecessarily complex. These reforms will bring Australia back to being among the world leaders in electoral reform. The Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill will help us to re-establish one vote one value as a principle of electoral procedure in Australia. History will record in years to come that these reforms will rank with the great reforms in our electoral history. Australia once led the world in electoral reform. In 1856 Victoria and South Australia introduced secret ballots . In 1894 South Australia enfranchised women. In general terms, Australia was among the first places in the world to abolish the property vote, with perhaps the exception of my State where it lingered on for many years into the twentieth century. Australia was among the first countries in the world to provide salaries for members of parliament. Effectively that meant that many working people could participate in parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time of Federation our electoral boundaries for the House of Representatives were among the fairest in the world. Certainly, they were fairly close to the one vote one value principle. The unfortunate thing is that in Australia we have allowed ourselves to fall well behind other countries in electoral reform. Basically our laws in Australia in this area are nineteenth century laws. They are not laws about mass society with large electorates. They are not laws about political parties forming governments. They are not laws about the modern influences on voting behaviour, for example, large scale advertising. The electoral laws in this country, when one really boils them down , are more about the practices which could influence votes in the small electorates of the past. For example, the laws in some States still refer to the practice of treating, of buying food and drink and of bribing. The laws still refer to the practice of exercising undue influence. Some States' laws also refer to the practice of intimidation. Those practices could really affect results in only very small electorates, as in the past.

The last major consolidation of the Commonwealth Electoral Act was in 1918. In 1974 and 1975 the former Whitlam Government tried repeatedly to reform Australia 's electoral laws, but was frustrated in this place. It is interesting to note that some of the proposals in the Bills of 1974 and 1975 are included in this Bill. It is part of an electoral reform package which has been introduced by the current government. There are proposals for two electoral referenda to be held in February next year. Yesterday we passed the Representation Bill reforming the size of the Senate and the House of Representatives. There is a $3m education and enrolment program for voters and also a specific program for Aboriginal electors.

All this activity on the electoral front is a pleasant change from previous decades. There was certainly one review, at least, of the Electoral Act by the former Government, but no action on it was taken. The report of the Harders Committee of Inquiry into the Disclosure of Electoral Expenses did not see the light of day until this year under the present Government. I congratulate the current Government for moving to appoint the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. I congratulate the Select Committee for its tremendous effort in making recommendations to reform Australian electoral laws and the bipartisan spirit in which it conducted a great deal of its activities. The report comes to terms with the existence of political parties. Indeed, the Select Committee report recommends the registration of parties. That proposal is incorporated in this Bill. Political parties are a key element of our political system. They are the basis for forming governments in a mass society. The recognition of political parties in electoral legislation is long overdue.

I was pleased to be one of four members of parliament who actually sent submissions to the Electoral Reform Committee. In my submission I called for a list system of voting for the Senate following my experience in South Australia where we have had such a system for some time. I called for improved voter education activities to better inform people how to cast formal votes. I called for the placing of party affiliations on ballot papers next to candidates' names , among other items. I am pleased to say that these recommendations in my submission basically were adopted by the Select Committee.

I believe that Senate informals are a blot on our political system. It is shameful that for decades we have been faced with a situation of having very high numbers of informal votes in our upper House elections. Quite a disgraceful example occurred in my State in the Senate election held this year when, at two polling booths in the Port Adelaide division, the Senate informal vote reached 27 per cent. That is a real indictment of the system. It shows that the system is too complicated, is unnecessarily complex and that many Australians are frustrated in trying to cast valid votes.

When we look at the election results around Australia for the 1983 Senate election, we find that the informal vote for the Senate was, in fact, the third largest block of votes nationally for the Senate. The informal vote for the Senate actually exceeded the vote for the Australian Democrats around Australia. That is the dimension of the problem. It is even more starkly highlighted by the fact that the number of informal votes in New South Wales and Victoria this year exceeded one electoral quota for the Senate. So, the informal vote could have elected one senator in both of those States.

Who votes informally is a very important question that has to be faced up to. We carried out an investigation in my State some years ago. We found that, in many suburbs where there are large numbers of senior citizens, where migrants have arrived recently from certain countries or where there are citizens with low levels of schooling, we got high informal votes. The key finding that came out of the study was that most of the people who vote informal in the Senate are able to cast valid votes in the House of Representatives. So, clearly something can be done about the number of informal votes cast at a Senate election.

I believe that informal votes have been at high levels in recent decades in Senate elections because the voting system is unnecessarily complicated. I defy anybody to say that they walk around with 30 or 40 preferences in their heads ordered for candidates. It defies the imagination that people can actually rank 30 or 40 or more candidates in some order of preference. Since we have had a preferential voting system in Australia, informal votes for the Senate have been at high levels. Under the original system introduced for the Senate at the time of Federation, the informal vote averaged only 4 to 5 per cent and not the 9 per cent or more that we have now. In the present system there is also the danger that it can be exploited by unscrupulous people trying to increase deliberately the number of informal votes. Certain allegations were made in 1974 in New South Wales to that effect.

The Australian Electoral Office conducted a study of all informal ballot papers at the 1977 Federal election and the report showed uniformly in all States that the errors which caused informal votes were basically of two types: Incorrect numbering sequence and cases where people had left some squares blank. It was quite striking that in virtually every State about 77 per cent or 78 per cent of informal votes could be put down to those two types of errors. So clearly people were trying to fill in their ballot papers. People were trying to cast formal votes, but they were just frustrated by this system which required 30 or 40 preferences to be placed on a ballot paper.

This Bill proposes several measures which I believe would have the effect of reducing informal votes, particularly for the Senate. Firstly, a proposed simplified Senate voting system is provided for in the Bill. Under this proposal electors have the choice either of using the present system of expressing preferences or of using a radically new approach which involves simply placing a vote in only one square on the ballot paper and in that way electing an entire party's how to vote card. That is a radical departure from past practice in Australia and one which I believe will have the effect of maximising the number of formal votes in our upper House elections. The proposed voting system also allows electors to place a tick or a cross on the ballot paper and that will be regarded as having the same effect as placing a No. 1 in the square on the ballot paper. I believe that this reform of allowing ticks or crosses will particularly help migrants. Many migrants in Australia are used to voting overseas under systems where voting was by means of ticks or crosses. Certainly scrutineering in Australia has shown that there is no doubt that many informal votes at present are caused by ticks or crosses being placed on the ballot paper .

There is also a new definition of the formality of votes so that more votes can be made formal. For example, where there are more than nine candidates on a ballot paper in a Senate election, if 90 per cent or more of the squares are filled in the votes are classed as not informal. The votes are in fact valid and the preferences will be counted as long as the numbers on the ballot paper are consecutive. Preferences will count up to the point where the consecutive sequence of numbers ends.

The proposal to allow voting on the basis of supporting an entire party's how to vote card is simply a further refinement or extension of the list system of voting. I believe that the list system of voting is a very effective system of maximising the number of formal votes cast in an election. In South Australia a list system operated for our upper House at the 1975 and 1979 elections. In 1979 the results were quite outstanding. In fact, across the whole of South Australia at the 1979 elections there were less informal votes for the upper House than there were for the lower House. That is quite an unusual result in Australian electoral experience. Upper House informal votes normally are well above those in lower House elections. In the South Australian system, placing a No. 1 on the ballot paper meant a vote for the party list. It did not go to the extent of the proposal in this Bill of voting for an entire party's how to vote card. It simply voted for a party's candidates. It was very striking that, when the Liberal Government in South Australia changed the system in 1982 to require, instead of one number being placed on the ballot paper, 11 numbers equal to the number of vacancies, there was a marked increase in the number of informal votes . So I think the lesson from that experience is that to reduce informal votes it is very important to keep the number of figures required to be expressed on the ballot paper very low.

There is nothing wrong with the proposal in the Bill to enable voters simply to cast a vote for one particular party's how to vote card, that being all that they are required to do. After all, under the present system of proportional representation, the parties still issue how to vote cards and suggest to voters that they follow those cards. It is quite striking that in respect of all of the major parties-the coalition parties, the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats-very few voters stray from following those how to vote cards. For all of those parties that I have mentioned, only between 2 and 3 per cent of all voters strayed from the how to vote cards. About 97 to 98 per cent followed how to vote cards exactly. Unfortunately, the corollary of the preferential voting system is that 5 or 6 per cent more voters cast informal votes as a result of the preferential voting system, yet only 2 to 3 per cent of voters take advantage of the system to change their numbering sequence.

A basic objective of the electoral system should be to maximise the number of formal votes. Certainly it is not the only objective, but it should be a major objective. Electoral systems are more than just about enabling people to express preferences. This proposal of simplifying the Senate voting system will effectively enfranchise many Australians for the first time and is long overdue. It should do this, too, because after all, the Senate is a most powerful upper House and the greatest number of Australians should be able to express formal votes in Senate elections.

One of the important reforms contained in the Bill-although some would say that it is minor, I believe that it is important-is the proposal to enable party names to be printed on ballot papers alongside candidates' names. That is provided for in the new section 106C. This proposal, although simple, will reduce the extent of voter confusion. After all, to put party names on ballot papers is only a very small step from the reality of the grouping of Senate candidates on ballot papers. After all, that has been in force since 1922. It is only a small step further to enable candidates to have their party affiliations printed on ballot papers alongside their names. That proposal will bring us into line with a number of overseas countries, including New Zealand, the United Kingdom, Canada, France and Norway, which all provide for party names on ballot papers.

I think you are aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, of the case in South Australia in 1977, when the former President of this place, Sir Harold Young, got an extraordinary number of votes at the second position on the Liberal Party Senate ticket in the Port Adelaide division. He got about 1,600 first preference votes in that division, whereas in all the other electoral divisions in South Australia he received only 500 to 600 first preference votes. It is more than likely that many voters in the Port Adelaide division confused Sir Harold Young with the Federal member of the House of Representatives for Port Adelaide Mick Young. About 1,000 votes were probably switched as a result of that confusion and countless others would have been made informal by voters putting two ones on their ballot papers.

A very important reform proposed in the Bill is to have posters at polling booths to display group voting tickets for the Senate. This will apply only in respect of Senate elections, but electors will be able to see the actual candidates for particular parties displayed in a group in poster form at booths. This is a little like the system in South Australia which has operated for two or three elections whereby party how to vote cards are placed in the voting cubicles. This system works very well in South Australia and the electors of that State have become used to being able to go into the voting cubicle and see the how to vote cards for their parties displayed in the cubicles.

I think the new section 7A proposed for the Commonwealth Electoral Act is very important. It provides for expanded voter education activities in Australia. In fact, voter education is to be a clearly delineated function for the new Australian Electoral Commission. That makes a bit of a break from the past focus of the Australian Electoral Office which has basically been concerned with the enrolment and registration of voters. I think there is a great need for voting instruction activities in Australia. There is no doubt that a number of people in the community would benefit from the availability of voting assistance, and I believe such assistance can be very effective in improving voting in Australia. In South Australia in 1980 the Australian Labor Party conducted its own voter education program. It identified suburbs with very high informal votes. It identified areas where people could be given assistance by means of party canvassing, by members actually door knocking and providing special literature. I think the results of that program speak for themselves. During the 1980 Senate election in South Australia there was a reduction of 11,000 in Senate informal votes, equal to a 1.7 per cent fall in Senate informal votes, and that was despite the fact that there was a vastly increased number of candidates on the ballot paper. In general in Senate elections the more the candidates on the ballot paper the higher the level of informal votes. So that program indicated that informal votes could be reduced against the trend. We found that in the suburbs where canvassing occurred, where people had voting explained to them, the number of informal votes actually fell by 7 or 8 per cent or more. So it can be effective, but the point that must be made is that voter education should be a government responsibility and not that of an individual party. I hope the Australian Electoral Commission, when it is constituted, will look at this whole model of door knocking and canvassing and provide street by street explanations of voting activity.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I now turn to the proposals in the legislation concerning public funding of elections. Australia stands virtually alone among the democracies of the world in that it has, with the exception of New South Wales, virtually no laws on money in politics. Up until a few years ago we did have at the Federal level expenditure limits on candidates but they were abolished by the Fraser Government. That abolition occurred at the time when most of the other democracies in the world were moving in the direction of more regulation of the flow of money into politics and its expenditure. Public funding is a key question. The public financing of elections is a key question and most of the other democracies with which Australia normally compares itself have public funding and/or disclosure laws about the flow of money into politics . It has been estimated by some commentators that Australian elections are possibly the most expensive in the world on a per capita basis. One estimate I have seen is that the 1983 Federal election may have involved outlays of the order of $12m, and it has been suggested that $10m of that was contributed by the coalition and about $2m by the Australian Labor Party.

I believe that the flow of money into politics should be in the open; it should see the light of day. There are real dangers of hidden money in politics. There is the risk of buying favours and the risk of corruption. In a country such as Australia where, for example, we have relatively high levels of tariff protection for industry there is a risk that some people might draw the conclusion that by supporting certain parties they might be able to gain some protection for their products, and I believe that is one area of real risk. Also electoral success in modern elections should not depend on the amount of money available to particular parties and candidates. Democracies simply cannot exist where electoral success depends on the amount of money available for expenditure by a particular party. I think also that doubts in the community about the current uses and sources of money flowing into politics have some impact on the public standing of members of parliament.

The proposed system of government assistance for the costs of elections provided for in this Bill would be of the order of $8.5m every three or four years, depending on the term of parliament. I think that is a modest amount of money to pay for a vital and vibrant political system in this country at a national level. The proposal is that parties will be reimbursed for election expenses up to a limit. The limit for House of Representatives elections will be 60c per elector and at the moment that is equivalent to the cost of two postage stamps. With a joint House of Representatives and Senate election the amount of money involved for each voter would be 60c for the House of Representatives and 30c for the Senate. So the total cost per elector of this proposal for public funding would be 90c. At the moment it is equivalent to the cost of three items of postage for each elector on the roll. I think that is a very small price to pay for a significant boost to democracy in this country. The system would involve parties claiming for actual expenditure incurred after the event. The proposal will require parties to be registered and only parties which obtain 4 per cent or more of the formal vote will actually qualify for government funding for their electoral costs. The payments for the cost of elections will be made to parties rather than to candidates.

I think one of the important aspects of the Bill is that the period looked at will not be simply the period of the formal election campaign after the issue of writs but will encompass any expenses incurred in relation to an election whenever those expenses are incurred. That is very important because so much political science research has indicated that a lot of the activity which really does change votes in our political system occurs many months before the actual formal election campaign. Certainly those sorts of findings were put forward in respect of the 1972 Australian election when it was felt by many commentators that many of the votes were actually changed months before the formal campaign began.

The other key reforms in this legislation include assistance for certain electors. From my experience this is a very important area. The proposed new section 120 would involve treating illiterate voters in the same way as voters with eyesight problems and those who suffer physical incapacities. Illiterate voters would be put on a consistent basis with those people and all three groups of people could have the assistance of the presiding officer at a polling booth in marking the ballot papers for them. In fact, they could simply show to the presiding officer a how to vote card of the of their choice and ask him to mark their ballot paper accordingly. I think that is a very important reform. There is no doubt that the area of voter assistance in Australian elections has been in need of upgrading for many years and I think this particular reform will go a long way towards cutting informal votes, particularly in Senate elections. I think the proposal to provide a seven day minimum period between the calling of an election and the closing of electoral rolls is a very major reform. We saw the disgraceful action earlier this year by the former Government in closing the rolls immediately after the issuing of writs and effectively disfranchising many of our fellow citizens who as a result were unable to cast votes in the Federal election.

All in all, this Bill is very comprehensive. It is the most major reform of Australia's electoral laws since 1918. I hope that in the next few years we can see some reforms in other areas which were canvassed but left open in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. For example, we need to look at computerised voting in Australian elections. It is a long overdue reform. Computerised voting will work with Australian preferential voting and the Committee has acknowledged that that is the case. It would also like to see the next step in the public funding area being the funding of party research. Policy formulation by political parties is of vital importance to democracy. Good policies make better government. We should follow the lead of overseas countries in providing funds for party research activities. This is a long overdue reform. The Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill will bring Australian electoral law into the twentieth century and, most importantly, will effectively enfranchise many Australians for the first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I address myself briefly to some of the major features of the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill. It is the result of an inquiry by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. The inquiry was necessary and the Committee has come down with some very worthwhile recommendations. It has also come down with some recommendations which are incorporated in this Bill with which, as Senator Baume said earlier this morning when outlining the Opposition' s attitude to the Bill, we do not find it possible to agree. Consequently, again as foreshadowed by Senator Baume, a number of amendments will be put which we hope will be seen as being constructive and may well, at least in part, be agreed to by the Government as this debate continues.

SPEECH.PARA: I said that there were areas of this Bill with which I found disagreement, but before I look briefly at those, I mention two very significant achievements and recommendations. One of those relates to the determination of the Committee not to reduce the margin of tolerance in electorates from the current 10 per cent to a proposed 5 per cent. I think that the Committee is to be congratulated on having refused to accept that proposition and having maintained the tolerance of 10 per cent which some years ago and for many years before that was 20 per cent in the vast extra-metropolitan areas of Australia. I am still of the view that there is a strong case to be made for that sort of margin in such a vast land, because in spite of all the rhetoric about communications there is no shadow of doubt that the vast distances of this country provide a great difficulty for members of parliament to establish and maintain a close personal contact with their electorates. That is perhaps the basic requirement of an effective democracy. No matter how well the postal system works and no matter how many telegrams and telephone calls are made, in the final resort there is no real substitute for the capacity to meet in one's area with one's representative in the Parliament and to talk specifically with him or her.

Another recommendation that I believe is extremely important is the virtual refusal of the Committee to accept and recommend an optional preferential system of voting. The optional preferential system is really just an over- simplification. It is almost an insult to the intelligence of the Australian voter that such a thing should be considered as necessary. More than that, it is the first step, perhaps the only step, towards a first past the post system. The results of first past the post systems, where they exist around the world, are such that anything between 37 or 38 per cent and 40 or 42 per cent of the voters can, in effect, elect a government. That does not seem to be good enough. The other reason for the need for preferential voting is that it is crazy to assume that all matters in political philosophy, all matters referable to the way a society, a community, lives are confined to areas that can be defined as either black or white. Clearly, there are shades of opinion. These shades of opinion are often expressed politically by individuals or various political parties. To negate the opportunity for the electorate to reflect on those shades of opinion and to indicate their preferences is certainly no service to the democratic system.

I believe it is time that the Electoral Act was reviewed and brought up to date in many fields. That is the basic objective of this Bill. In a number of areas it has been very successfully addressed. However, there are one or two areas, or perhaps more, with which I do not find any measure of agreement at all. The first of those has been referred to, and I guess will be referred to on many occasions. That is the area of public funding. My Party, the National Party of Australia, and I have been opposed to public funding on a range of grounds since it was mooted in this country. It seems totally unreal and unnecessary that the Australian taxpayer should be called upon to finance political individuals or parties. There is no possible way in which a taxpayer should be seen to be responsible for the promotion of philosophies with which he has nothing in common. Consequently, the determination that taxpayers should provide the funds for those who promote a range of attitudes and philosophies is a crazy and totally unacceptable proposition.

Public funding makes yet another adverse contribution to democracy in our country. It seems to me that when people recognise that what can be described as 60c from each voter, in actual terms is millions of dollars coming from the taxpayers' purses to promote and advertise the views and attitudes of a political party, clearly there will be a lessening of interest at the grass roots level and at branch levels. There will be a lessening of interest in the community in general in those very political, economic and social matters that concern everybody.

The strength of a democracy is surely the capacity and determination of the people in that democracy to identify their attitudes, to identify the directions in which they wish to travel and to seek to promote them of their own volition, amongst their own people and amongst a whole range of people in the community. That sort of determination, a determination to be financially able to do that sort of promotion, will be severely jeopardised by a reliance on the taxpayer. After all, as I said originally, the strength of any party in a democracy relates to the responsible debate that occurs at grass roots level. That is where basic policy is formed, and that is where it should be formed. That sort of institution should not be dependent upon the taxpayer as a whole for its finances to such a degree-indeed, to any degree at all-and the result of that sort of dependence can only be, in my view, a lessening of the active participation in debate and policy consideration amongst those hundreds of thousands of people who ought to be concerned in a free society to establish the circumstances, to establish the views and policies, that they seek to promote.

Mr Deputy President, I wish to raise a number of other matters-for instance, ordinary voting within a division, which was a recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and is a proposition of this Bill. Clearly it has the advantage of simplification but I believe that it may well be an oversimplification. It may well resolve itself into multiple voting which, of course, is a major step that should be avoided. Though this suggestion that we should allow ordinary votes within a division is attractive from the point of view of its simplicity, it may well be a problem in practice. I think that, naturally, people will live with 6 p.m. closing of the polls; they do in a number of places in Australia already. But I believe there is a quite strong argument to suggest that it is not really a step forward. Closing at 8 p.m. has a great attraction to a significant number of people on religious grounds. It has a great attraction for people involved, as often they are on a Saturday afternoon, in a whole range of sporting activities, and to people involved in work which normally takes them well past sunset at certain times of the year. So , whilst the reduction in hours from 8 p.m. closing to 6 p.m. closing would have , I suppose, some technical advantages from the point of view of the convenience of a whole range of voters, it certainly cannot be described as a step forward. On the other hand, the implementation of mobile booths is a step in the right direction.

I make brief reference to the proposition of the list system of voting. Again the significant point about this is that of course it is a simplification and it may reduce the number of informal votes, but perhaps it is an over simplication and perhaps it would not permit people to exercise properly their optional preferences. I believe that the list system, as I said, is too simple. There is an argument-a strong argument-that suggests that there should hardly be the sorts of numbers on a Senate ticket that we were once confronted with in my own State of New South Wales. I think there may have been 73 or 74 candidates. That seems to be a rather crazy situation. On the other hand, I think it is something of an insult to the intelligence of the average Australian voter to assume that he cannot fill in a significant number of squares to indicate the preference of which he is aware. I believe he can and indeed as the situation stands the number of votes not correctly filled in is under 10 per cent. That could well be improved by reducing the numbers on the ticket but I do believe that to make it so simple that one has the option of just ticking a team is making it too simple altogether.

I was interested to note that Senator Maguire, in summing up this legislation, said that it was a significant boost to democracy. I do not believe that that is so on a number of counts and particularly with reference to public funding. As I have already said, I do not think that is a significant boost to democracy at all. It is just putting a responsibility on the taxpayer to promote all sorts of philosophies which he should not be expected to do. The apparent significant boost to democracy by making voting so simple again could be described as either a boost to democracy or as an insult to the intelligence of the people who form that democracy. There are matters of principle and philosophy, and some technicality, which we believe should be improved and could be improved in this legislation. Again, there are areas with which I find absolute agreement. I was pleased indeed about two matters-that optional preferential voting was not accepted and that the tolerance was not reduced from 10 per cent to 5 per cent. I still believe that there is an excellent argument that maintains that it should ultimately be restored to its 20 per cent level.

In closing, let me say that the Joint Select Committee itself clearly has covered a very wide range of investigation and has come down with some very important observations and recommendations. Many parts of this Bill would improve the electoral system and I believe that the amendments that the Opposition has to this legislation would, if accepted, improve it still further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Deputy President, the Senate is debating the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill. This is a comprehensive Bill and it will make a significant revision of Australia's electoral laws. I mention at the outset that this must be a Bill of some note. Some honourable senators will recall that in 1981 I brought forward a private member's Bill which was eventually passed by this Parliament in 1982. This Bill became the Senate Elections (Queensland) Act. That Act is now going to be incorporated in the electoral legislation, upon passage of the Bill now before us. Prior to the passing of the Senate Elections (Queensland) Bill the Constitution allowed Queensland to be divided into electoral divisions for Senate election purposes. I refer any honourable senator who wishes to recall what I said at that time to page 832 of the Senate Hansard of 26 March 1981. In that speech I outlined the need for some legislation from this Parliament to close what was perhaps a loophole in the Constitution. The legislation before us seeks to repeal the Senate Elections (Queensland) Act and the provisions of that Act will be incorporated in section 16 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

SPEECH.PARA: There will be many speakers on this Bill both during the second reading stage and the Committee stage. Therefore I intend to mention only certain features of the legislation. First, I would like to mention the Senate ballot paper. Senator Scott, who spoke before me, made some reference to this and in some respects I disagree with what he said. The number of informal votes that are cast in Senate elections is totally unacceptable and this Bill tackles that problem. Given the complexity of the ballot paper and the voting system it is understandable that we have so many informal votes. It is worth while looking at the number of candidates at Senate elections in each State and each Territory in recent years. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which is headed 'Number of Senate Candidates 1974-1983'. This table, which has been compiled for me by the statistics section of the Parliamentary Library, has been shown to the Opposition.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-

Notes: 1. Full Senate Election
2. Half Senate Election

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The table indicates that in 1974 there were 245 candidates for the Senate election in Australia. This is a fairly typical number. In 1975 the number was 271; in 1977 there was a drop to 151; in 1980 the number was 182; and in 1983 it was 250. It is perhaps more pertinent to look at the numbers in each State rather than the total number. Senator Scott mentioned that in 1974 there were 73 candidates in New South Wales. This meant that electors in New South Wales who went to the polls were obliged to fill in numbers from one to 73. I can recall a story about a lady who picked up her ballot paper, took it out of the polling booth, which I suppose is against the electoral legislation, took it home, made a cup of tea and while she was drinking her cup of tea filled in the numbers from 1 to 73. She took it back and put it into the ballot box. That was probably a long-winded way of filling in a ballot paper. However, many people made errors when confronted with that number of candidates. I really wonder when one has to list 73 candidates how one can determine one's preference between the fifty-eighth and fifty-ninth candidates. It seems to me to be taking the situation to an absurd length to continue with the same system of voting when we have so many candidates.

SPEECH.PARA: There were 62 Senate candidates in New South Wales in the election in 1983, which was almost the same number as the record number in 1974. In Victoria there were 50 candidates and in Queensland there were 42. Despite what we might say about the intelligence of voters-most of the electors are intelligent and know the way in which they are going to vote-electors are going to make unintentional errors if we have so many condidates. Those of us who have scrutineered in Senate elections know full well that many people who want to fill out the ballot paper are unable to do so because of the complexity of the ballot paper itself.

It is worth while comparing the number of informal votes in the Senate with those in the House of Representatives. Since 1974 we have had Senate elections at the same time as House of Representatives elections. In 1974 10.8 per cent of votes for the Senate throughout Australia were informal. Over one in 10 persons cast an informal vote. By comparison 1.9 per cent of votes in the House of Representatives election were informal. If one took the argument, and I do not think one really can, that all of the 1.9 per cent of informal votes were deliberately informal, one could say that 8 per cent of people unwittingly cast an informal vote for Senate candidates. If we look at the figures for elections held between 1974 and 1983 we find a consistent difference of about six or seven percentage points between the House of Representatives informal vote and the Senate informal vote, the Senate informal vote being higher on every occasion. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table compiled for me again by the statistics section of the Parliamentary Library and headed 'Percentage of Informal Votes Federal Elections 1974-1983'.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This table clearly indicates that there is something drastically wrong with the Senate ballot paper and the way we have to vote. For instance, in the 1983 election 9.8 per cent of Senate ballot papers were spoiled because the voters could not fill out the ballot paper in a way that was acceptable. Almost one voter in 10 could not fill out the paper correctly. Something is drastically wrong when one elector in 10 spoiled his ballot paper.

SPEECH.PARA: When discussing this matter in this place some years ago I suggested that it would be an easy task for those with a mind to do so to sabotage a Senate election. For example, it would have been possible to put a large number of candidates on the ballot paper. By paying the then deposit of $200 for each candidate a thousand candidates could have been put on the ballot paper for a particular State at a cost of $200,000. The consequence of electors having to mark their preference from one to 1,000 or from one to 1,023 would have been chaotic and would have thrown the whole electoral legislation into disrepute. Voters would have rebelled. A strategy like this will be far less likely and perhaps will be negligible with the passage of this Bill. First, a candidate's deposit will be increased to $500. I suppose this will deter some candidates although I do not think it will deter many who have nominated in the past. I am not of a mind to try to deter people by using financial considerations, but at least the deposit has been increased and if anybody were to make a serious attempt to sabotage the ballot paper by putting on so many candidates it would cost that person a lot more.

Perhaps even more importantly, with the list system of voting, the informal vote is likely to be far lower, irrespective of the number of candidates. So if we have a very large number of candidates and people want to use the list system of voting, they will be able to do so without really being concerned about the number of candidates.
