Under this legislation, an elector may cast a vote using the list system and that vote will be deemed to be cast according to the preferences registered by a party on its how to vote card.

It should be mentioned that individual choice of candidates will still be possible using the current preference system of voting. So if people do not want to use the list system, they can still do their own thing and put down preferences according to however they want them. I recall that in a recent Senate election in Queensland a great many people did their own thing. They did not always follow the order of the candidates set down on a party's how to vote card. There will still be people who will want to do that. They will still be entitled to do so, but those people who want to use the list system will be able very readily to cast what they know to be a valid vote. If we allow people to cast a vote and have it counted in the way in which they would like to have it counted, we will be getting closer to what we want to do-that is, to allow every person who has the right to vote to be able to do so and to have that vote counted. We must bring down the informal vote for the Senate. The informal vote is not an indication that the voters' intelligence is at a low. It is an indication of the fact that our system is much too difficult and much too complex to place before the voters.

I would like to move on now to mention some matters about the House of Representatives ballot paper. A sample ballot paper is shown in Schedule 1 to the Bill. There are two changes in the actual format of the ballot paper. I will dwell on the first one and will mention in short detail something about the second change. The first change is that candidates' names will no longer necessarily be in alphabetical order. Under clause 80 of this Bill, proposed new section 106 (2) (a) will make it mandatory for places on the ballot paper to be determined by lot. Of course, this measure has been adopted to counter what is often called the donkey vote. It is a poor reflection on our society that the donkey vote can have a decisive effect on who will represent us in Parliament. But donkey votes do occur and I suppose that they will continue to occur. It seems unfair that a person's chances of success should be increased because his surname starts with a letter close to the beginning of the alphabet. For persons with a surname such as Colston, I suppose it is not too bad, but for my colleague in the House of Representatives, Mr Young, it is not too good.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Senator Zakharov?

—Senator Zakharov would certainly not be enamoured of the present situation. Apart from individual members, it is also unfair to the institution of Parliament that those who collectively make up that Parliament may be there by chance. Donkey voters, of course, are people who number their ballot papers in numerical order straight down the ballot paper without considering the merits of respective parties of candidates. Estimates of the value of the donkey vote vary. However, Boyce and his co-authors in the Dictionary of Politics suggest that a donkey vote is worth 2 to 4 per cent of the vote. They suggest that 2 to 4 per cent of the electors cast a donkey vote. Jaensch and Teichmann in the Macmillan Dictionary of Australian Politics suggest that the donkey vote may be worth between 2 and 3 per cent of the total vote.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently, I was associated with a situation wherein the donkey vote was, with little if any doubt, decisive in determining the successful candidate in one State electorate in Queensland. We had State elections in Queensland on 22 October this year. In the electorate of Maryborough there were three candidates. Mr Alison was the National Party candidate, Mr Bailey was the Liberal Party candidate and Mr Nightingale was the Australian Labor Party candidate. So the ballot paper was listed Alison, Bailey, Nightingale. Bailey, the Liberal candidate, was eliminated when preferences had to be distributed. After the distribution of preferences the result was that Alison received 7,648 votes and Nightingale received 7,640. So Alison was elected by eight votes.

I do not wish to detract from Mr Alison's success, but if his name had been Yalison, it is highly doubtful whether he would have been elected. If the donkey vote were worth only one per cent-it might be recalled that I quoted authorities who said that it was worth between 2 and 4 per cent-it would have been worth 150 votes to Mr Alison. It should be recalled that he won by only eight votes. Even if the donkey vote were worth only 0.1 per cent, it would have been decisive in having Mr Alison elected, because 0.1 per cent would have been about 15 votes, and honourable senators will recall that Mr Alison won by eight votes. Again, if I may use an example from Queensland, it is worthy of note that one character changed his name by deed poll from Smith to Asmith. His aim was to be the first on the ballot paper. Now it would be a nice twist to be able to inform the Senate that he was beaten by a person called Aboud, but that did not happen. In that situation, he was decisively beaten by everybody. But a person changing his name by deed poll in order to get on top of the ballot paper makes a mockery of the democratic process.

In this Bill, we have at least gone part of the way to overcoming that by providing that positions shall be balloted for. So those whose surnames start with a letter close to the beginning of the alphabet, such as A, B or C, will not necessarily have an electoral advantage. As I have said, we have only gone part of the way. Those who are fortunate in the ballot will be advantaged by the donkey vote. So someone will still receive an advantage. Therefore, I do not believe that we should regard this as the final step, significant though it may be. By issuing ballot papers which have candidates' names in different orders, it is possible to counter completely or almost completely the donkey vote. This system is in use in Tasmania and there is no reason why it should not work in Federal elections.

The second alteration to which I referred in relation to House of Representatives ballot papers is the printing of names of political parties on the ballot papers. With the passage of this legislation, this will occur, and it is a measure which is long overdue. There are also alterations in relation to the way in which completed ballot papers may be regarded as formal.

However, I should not dwell on this matter but instead turn my attention to a clause dealing with enrolment. Many Australians remember how thousands of potential voters were denied the right to vote at the Federal elections in March this year. In February the then Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, announced that there would be an election for both Houses of the Parliament. He made the announcement on 3 February. The rolls closed on 4 February. Thousands of people did not have an opportunity to enrol. Not thinking that an election was imminent , they saw no immediate need to place their names on the electoral roll. Mr Fraser's haste denied them the right to vote. Of course, all eligible persons aged 18 years and over should ensure that they are on the roll, but not everyone in the community is as politically aware as all of us here. Often electors do not see a need or any urgency to enrol until an election is about to occur.

The situation which occurred in relation to this year's election in which many people were denied the right to vote will not occur after the passage of this legislation. At least seven days' notice must be given before the rolls close. Under clause 45 of the Bill that we are discussing the date fixed for the close of the rolls shall be seven days after the date of the writ. No longer will potential electors be ambushed as they were earlier this year. Of equal importance is the amendment which will allow for provisional enrolment for 17- year-olds. After provisionally enrolling, which will not be compulsory, people will automatically become enrolled on their eighteenth birthday. I can foresee that provisional enrolment will become a routine task for those in their last year of secondary school.

Before concluding, I wish to offer my congratulations to the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform which worked with diligence to present a report to the Parliament in September this year. The proposed legislation which is before us is heavily dependent on the Committee's report. I have mentioned but a few of the contents of this Bill. However, I do mention that it is a comprehensive Bill and one which is to be commended to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill is a major achievement for the Government. It is an extremely important Bill and one which seeks, for the first time since the original Commonwealth Electoral Act was introduced, to reform the system and give it a thorough workover. Many elements in this Bill probably will not even be raised at the Committee stage, but many of those aspects will be extremely important to many people in the community. I give but one example which might show the flavour of such amendments. Total paraplegics effectively would not have been able to vote under the current Act. Under the proposed legislation they will be able to do so. Such amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act take account of the many and various problems that electors in Australia face. The amendments take account of the fact, for example, that many Australian citizens serve the interests of this country overseas. They may be Australian delegates or may serve in other capacities. While servicemen overseas were able to vote, their wives and children who were living with them could not. This situation has now been rectified. Australians who serve in the Antarctic were deprived of a vote under the previous legislation. This has now been rectified. So it goes on.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to put on record the fact that this Bill picks up and seeks to overcome a multitude of problems, indeed hundreds of problems, that have plagued the Commonwealth Electoral Act over that period. I think that the Government is to be congratulated for being the government which has brought forward such a far- sighted and useful reform in this area. But when any such Bill comes into this Parliament which deals with the really crucial element of a democracy, that is, how the representatives of the people are elected, it will necessarily contain within it matters of high political controversy. Likewise, this Bill does. The fact that the consideration of the Bill at the Committee stage will be concentrated in those areas ought not to take away from the fact that all honourable senators in this place, I am sure, support the vast bulk of the reforms that are contained in the legislation.

I turn to the major elements of the Bill. Firstly, an independent Australian Electoral Commission is to be established. That Commission will be responsible for all the matters within this electoral legislation. Probably the most important reform in this area deals with the way in which redistributions are handled. Many technical reforms have been introduced regarding when redistributions will take place. There have been some reforms in relation to the criteria by which electoral reforms shall take place. I believe the most important change is that for the first time the electoral commissioners will be totally independent. We have been lucky in the Federal Parliament that by and large our redistributions have been fair. Very little can be said at the Federal level about gerrymanders or malapportionments. Under governments of both political persuasions we have been very lucky that the major parties have taken very seriously their role in government to maintain, as far as possible, an impartial and independent electoral system. I believe there should be very little dispute about the move now to recognise that independence in formal legislative form and to require that the redistributions, once made and once objections have been lodged with and considered by the Commission, stand and that the Parliament will no longer have the power to alter such redistributions. I think that this provision will really enhance the standing of parliament and the standing of the political process within the community.

The next major set of reforms deals with the voting systems, particularly in relation to the Senate counting procedures. There are some problems in this area . I will be moving amendments at the Committee stage to rectify those problems. These changes have sought to overcome some of the anomalies about which Senator Colston, who spoke previously, has written and which he experienced in his political career. Those changes are of a highly technical nature, nevertheless they are important. However, a reform is missing from that section of the legislation. It is a reform which the Australian Democrats believe would be the major reform that could be undertaken in Australia's political life. It concerns the introduction of proportional representation to the House of Representatives. I believe the fact that this is missing from the Bill effectively means that the Bill has not really grappled with the last major task of reform in the electoral process. I believe that is a bitter disappointment to many people in the community who feel that that is a necessary move that we must take. I hope that in the future it will be seen to be a necessary reform and that eventually it will be taken. However, I do not propose to move any amendments at the Committee stage in relation to that item. The Liberal and National parties have indicated that they would oppose any such amendments as would the Labor Party. Therefore, it would be a fruitless exercise. But I would not like the fact that I will not be moving any amendments to try to introduce proportional representation to the House of Representatives to be taken to mean that the Australian Democrats, nevertheless, do not still dedicate themselves to that ultimate reform and that ultimate task.

The next set of reforms are those that I referred to in the beginning and are likely to raise very little discussion in the Committee stage. They are the range of reforms which attempt to overcome the problems of enrolment and voting. By and large I think everyone in this chamber is supportive of hundreds of those reforms that appear in this electoral legislation. I think it is important for those people in the community who have an interest in these matters actually to gain a copy of the Bill to understand the full extent of the reforms that the Government is quite rightly proposing in 1983 to take us into the year 2000 to meet the peculiar problems of this country and its citizens.

The next series of reforms deals with areas which are of high political controversy; that is, the problems of funding and disclosure of donations and electoral expenditure. I wish to raise some matters in relation to those problems. I will be moving some amendments in this area in the Committee stage. Indeed, I will propose in excess of 30 amendments in the Committee stage on a range of items. I understand that the Opposition will be moving a number of amendments also. The Government, of course, has already moved a series of amendments in the House of Representatives. I put on record my appreciation of the extremely co-operative and helpful discussions I have had with the Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley) and his staff to clarify many of the matters in the Bill. Indeed, the Minister moved a number of amendments in the House of Representatives that the Australian Democrats in discussions recommended to the Government and which the Government, in reviewing the legislation, had seen fit to accept. I believe that the attitude that the Government has taken to this Bill and its willingness to consult on this matter are very much to its credit and show, I think, the spirit in which it has engaged in reforms in this area.

Public funding is necessarily an extremely controversial matter. I refer first of all to page 146 of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. The public funding which is already available for electoral purposes is detailed on that page. Unfortunately, it is a misconception in the public debate that, for the first time, we are introducing public funding of elections. We already have had massive public funding of elections. This Bill seeks a different method of public funding. It does not introduce public funding for the first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fairer system.

—As Senator Haines has interjected, a fairer system is proposed here, not an innovation in that sense. Some of the areas for which money is already provided by the taxpayers to political parties and candidates running for public office include: The continuing payment of staff for members of parliament during election campaigns; the payment of members' telephone accounts for all purposes; the provision of travel within Australia for members during election campaigns; the provision of staff to the Opposition front bench, party leaders and Ministers; the provision of limited free time on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation; the provision of Royal Australian Air Force No. 34 squadron aircraft to certain party leaders during election campaigns, not to the leader of the Australian Democrats unfortunately; access for members to parliamentary research facilities; the provision of offices for members; election related advertising by the Australian Electoral Office and the Australian Information Service; the provision of material such as 'Guide to Candidates and Scrutineers' by the Australian Electoral Office; and last, but not least-it is extremely important-tax deductibility of individual election expenses. That amount, by the way, is undetermined; it is an open cheque. We have no idea how much elections currently cost the taxpayer by direct financial assistance to candidates. We cannot have an idea because of the confidentiality of the taxation system. Indeed, it is not unknown for that to be used to pick up the totality of the amounts of money which are expended. Under the law, that is legal and perfectly permissible. It is a matter of the ways in which money is expended and on whose account it is expended. If it is expended on a personal matter and, indeed, every expenditure could be a personal matter-
—Including how to vote cards.

—How to vote cards, advertising in newspapers and the whole works could be claimed under that tax deductibility provision. At the moment we have no idea how much it costs. The list goes on to page 147. It includes tax deductibility of union dues. Evidence was given to the Committee that many of the donations made by companies might also be tax deductible by using them in certain ways. One example of that was that a company could pay a certain amount, say $10,000, for an advertisement in a political newspaper when in fact the going rate might be $200 and thereby receive a tax deduction as a legitimate company expense for advertising purposes. Of course, there are many other ways because of that tax deductibility framework whereby money is able to be made available for election purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important at the outset to make sure that when we talk about public funding we talk about a differing system and one which seeks to provide fair and equitable funding based on the popular support that candidates have within the community. Indeed, this system is a vast improvement on the bureaucratic system of public funding which operates in New South Wales. This system is a much simpler, clearer and, I believe, much more easily understood system for the ordinary voter than the system in New South Wales. I believe it will lead to far fewer problems than we see occurring in New South Wales if we read the various reports of the relevant authority in New South Wales. Many candidates, including candidates who belong to the governing party in New South Wales, have had money taken back from them because of their inability to fulfil the requirements set down in the law.

The simplicity of the approach in this Bill has very much to recommend it because in simplicity comes accountability to the electorate. The electorate will be able to understand very clearly the amounts of money that political parties receive and, in further elements within the Commonwealth Electoral Act itself, it will be able to see how that money is expended. The disclosure items within the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation amendment Bill are not necessarily linked to funding. It is important to realise this because there is a distinction between making disclosure and public funding. Often they are lumped together. It is not necessary, for example, to have any disclosure of public funding. However, there is a disclosure provision in this Bill. So the funding is based not only on the number of votes that one has received, provided it is in excess of 4 per cent, but also one has to be able to show that the amount of money to which one is entitled has been spent for election purposes. So accountability is built into this legislation to enable the electorate to see clearly where that money has gone and how it is being used. I hope that for the first time that may raise the public debate about the way that moneys are spent on elections. It is the hope-indeed it was expressed by members of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform from all political parties-that into the future we may see saner and more responsible election campaigns, and better campaigns in terms of the way that the matters are discussed.

Essentially, the matter of funding must be looked at; but there is no such thing as a free lunch. At the moment, ultimately the people who pay for elections in Australia are the taxpayers. They may pay through their taxes-this has already been raised-or they may pay through the cereals that they have for breakfast. The money comes from somewhere; it does not come from out of the air. The money is paid ultimately by the taxpayer in some form or another. I hope this is certainly not the last reform in this area because I would like to see a thorough-going movement much further than we have here. But at least it is a first step. Funding will be much more open and will be seen to be open by the electorate. The electorate will be able to see where it is spent.

Another contentious area which is not necessarily connected to this aspect but is included in the Bill is the disclosure requirements in relation to donations to political parties. The Australian Democrats, since the formation of our party , have required donations to our party over a certain amount to be publicly disclosable. I am quite happy to admit that that has almost wiped out any donations over that amount. That raises a very interesting point. There is an old saying in English that he who pays the piper calls the tune. Quite frankly, I find it very difficult to understand why a person puts $100,000 into a political party as a purely altruistic act. But, of course, that is the political fiction-that it is done through pure altruism. It is very nice to know that altruism has been growing in Australia because the amounts of money have been accelerating, not in arithmetic terms but in geometric proportion to the cost of living. It is very heartwarming and uplifting to know that altruism has grown so rapidly in this country.

But if one wants to be a bit more cynical about the situation I think we must admit that the problem of funding and elections is a crucial and integral problem of the whole democratic process. I was very interested to talk to visiting members recently from the United States of America about their State legislatures and to hear them say that the single main political problem in the United States revolves around funding. Indeed, one member from a State legislature went so far as to say that the problems of funding could sow the seeds of destruction of the American democracy. I believe that it does do that. Whereas many of the propositions contained in this Bill may not meet the direct political objectives of all parties in the Senate, I think we may be as one on the fact that this whole area is one which must concern us greatly and one which we must continually probe. We must be concerned with an attempt to reform to make sure that we are not overcome by the problems of costs. One way of confronting that in the future may be to seek a severe limitation of costs for election campaigns. I for one would support that very strongly.

But in the meantime we have to do what we can and one reform in this legislation is to make such donations publicly disclosable. I do not believe that in a democracy people ultimately will be concerned with that aspect. I know the arguments on both sides. I know the arguments about the right of an individual to dispose of his money as he sees fit without disclosing it publicly . I accept that that certainly is a principle. However, in this situation we have a conflict of principles. The overriding principle must be the health and the continuation of our democratic system. I believe it is as important as that that the money element connected with political parties and the enormous costs that are involved in election campaigns must not be such as to get us to the point where people can buy governments. We are not at that point. We have not had that in the past. But I see it in the future and I see it because that is what is occurring. It is readily acknowledged as occurring in places such as the United States. I hope that this will be our first step to prevent our falling into problems such as are occurring in other democracies.

The Australian Democrats support very strongly the regularisation of public funding operations and we support strongly the disclosure mechanisms contained here. But we say that they do not go far enough and hope that we may see in the near future further reforms in this area not only in relation to funding but also in relation to where it is expended and how it is expended. We run into problems of principle here also. No doubt we will run into conflicts of principles again by going down those paths. But I believe it is necessary for us to take a very hard headed view and to push in that area as strongly and as rapidly as we can.

Another area which is dealt with in the legislation concerns the registration of political parties. This has become necessary because of a series of reforms, long overdue reforms, that are contained in this legislation. For example, I refer to the placing of the names of political parties on the ballot paper. I understand the problems involved and the Australian Democrats sympathise very strongly with them. It is not our intention as a political party to seek to entrench strong party systems in this country. However, I point out that this Bill does not actually do that. How parties operate is not determined in any way by this Bill. Once this Bill becomes law, parties could operate as political parties do in the United States, with a very fluid operation. That is not outlawed or ruled out in any way by this legislation. We believe that the actual operations of political parties could be freed up enormously. It is our political view that the operation of political parties should be freed up enormously.

One case in point was the recent discussion that we had in this chamber on a private member's Bill moved by the Australian Democrats in regard to uranium mining. That showed very clearly the failure of the political party system to be able to deal adequately with that problem. It is our hope that into the future the party system which has served Australia well and which has given much to our democracy will not become more and more rigid but will allow itself to be opened up to new movements within the community and new forms of association such as we have seen with companies over the last 30 or 40 years and with trade unions over the last 30 or 40 years. I believe it is important that political parties do not shut off those possibilities of evolution and development.

What we have in this legislation is a reform to have names of political parties , which are a fact of life in the Australian electorate, on the ballot paper because we have to know the parties concerned. It follows from the reforms which are proposed that we need to have political parties registered. I am sure that we shall have debate in the Committee stage as to the best way in which that might be done and as to the finer points of tuning. I imagine that Senator Harradine will raise some of the points regarding fine tuning. I hope that in Committee the Government will be amenable to movements in that area if it sees that they are necessary. Nevertheless, by and large, the registration provisions are fair and adequate to the task which is necessary. They are not intrusive any more than they need to be to cover those reforms. They could have been much more intrusive. I think that they have been as intrusive as is minimally necessary. That is probably a good thing at this stage, to get the feel of the matters and to see what types of problems might emerge.

The Government has been quite open in seeking amendents to the Bill and has also suggested, which suggestion the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have supported, that the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform remain as a committee of this Parliament to look at the implementation of this legislation and to report back to the Parliament in due course if problems arise as a result of the changes that we are making. That is a thoroughly sensible and reasonable way in which to approach these types of reforms. I hope that it marks a period of constructive work on legislation, not only in this area but in many others as well, and that we can see that not all wisdom resides with the Government and that the Parliament has a larger and larger say in the legislative forms by which this country is run.

In summary, the Australian Democrats are very pleased that the Bill has come forward. We support its basic thrust and basic principles. Many of the amendments which we had wanted have already been picked up by the Government in the Committee stage in the House of Representatives, and probably all but three or four of the amendments made in the House of Representatives were originally suggestions from the Democrats. We shall be suggesting another batch of 30 to 40 amendments in Committee, which I hope the Government and the Opposition will be able to support, as further refinements and further developments of what we are all seeking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill 1983 is the first attempt at a major and comprehensive review of the Commonwealth Electoral Act for quite some years. It is therefore, in that respect, overdue. It is also a Bill which draws heavily, but not totally, upon the report and recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, a committee of which I was privileged to be a member. I say at the outset that electoral laws in Australia have served the people well at the Commonwealth level over the 82 years since Federation.
—You have benefited from them. If you look at the representation , you will find an imbalance. The Liberal Party of Australia has been in power much more often than the Australian Labor Party.

—That interjection simply shows the good sense at the ballot box of the voters, in that, for about 60 of the 82 years, they have chosen non-Labor governments. My intention is to deal with the Bill as objectively as possible, but if the Australian Labor Party is interested in an exchange, let us have it. What I was saying was that in my judgment and in the judgment of the majority of people, the laws that have prevailed in the conduct of elections federally over the generations have been honest laws which have worked well and which have produced majority rule. In the overwhelming number of cases, the parties that got the majority of votes were those that formed the Government. That has been the basis of democratic rule. I acknowledge that, not to say that nothing better can be achieved but to pay tribute, incidentally, to the officials and the many people who have taken part over the years. The redistribution systems have been essentially honest and essentially a true reflection of majority rule. That is not to say that they cannot be improved. I want to acknowledge that we do not start from any sense of grave imperfection, of corruption or of gerrymander. We start by looking at a review, seeking to improve upon what has been solid and sensible over the years.

SPEECH.PARA: I know of no situation in the whole of my time in public life where outside influence, involving money, has influenced governments, of whatever colour, to make judgments. I know that governments are influenced by all sorts of democratic pressures, from their parties, their ideologies, trade unions, interested groups, and all sorts. I know of no clear indications of corruption, although it was alleged by a Labor Party member in the Select Committee that the Iraqi breakfast may well have been such as indication. I would have believed that the Labor Party would have triumphed over that.

I start on that basis and by saying that the first amendments to which the Bill directs itself are largely machinery amendments that the Australian Electoral Office has brought to the Committee's attention by saying that their adoption would be beneficial to the democratic and electoral process. I commend those many amendments that are in the Bill. The Committee made 132 relatively significant recommendations, most of which have been adopted and it made many other minor ones, many of which have been incorporated. The first thing to do in regarding the Bill is to recognise that a series of overdue machinery amendments , largely coming from the Electoral Office, are incorporated in the Bill. I commend them. There has been an attempt to improve the methods by which people can become enrolled and can receive a vote. In general terms, as with the Aborigines and others, they are to be commended.

A large part of this legislation concerns improvements of machinery. It deals with significant matters. For example, it deals with the methods of redistributing boundaries. Depending upon its implementation, it could be an improvement. It sets up statutory bodies for redistributions and stautory timetables, giving the membership of those bodies to people by reason of their position-to a person because he is a surveyor-general, to a person because he is an auditor-general, to a person because he is a judge Those ideas and ideals are excellent in themselves, but, without any reflection, they will be strong only if all governments ensure that the people who reach those positions get there by their natural abilities and the evolution of time, and not by any government decision that they would, in a partisan sense, make good people for committees. So one must keep in mind the fact that the principles are fine but that the practice itself can have its imperfections. I commend the general principles in the Bill concerning redistribution provided that, as I say, principles are not bent by governments of the future to achieve what they hope will be their own self-interests.

The Bill contains a number of other matters, the benefits or otherwise of which will be proven only by time. Over the past 30 or 40 years there have been repeated suggestions of the registration of political parties, the provision of party names on ballot papers and the facilitation within the electoral process of identification of the candidate by the elector. It was not for any insidious reason that these suggestions were not incorporated over the years. Time and again the Electoral Office advised about the complexities that arise from an attempt at registration, an attempt to protect the name of a political party and an attempt to stop people exploiting the names of political parties. Time and again, therefore, these were examined and put aside even though obviously the ideas had merit. The Electoral Office has gone to a very great deal of trouble, as have the law officers, to try to devise a system which will be workable. I can say only that I hope the system will work but that I think it will take years to evolve a series of safeguards which will stop deceptive practices and which will allow for flexibility, bearing in mind that political parties are not immutable and should not be. They are not there forever. For instance, even if the name Australian Labor Party has been common over many years there have been very many different Labor parties in Australia. It is very difficult indeed in terms of a legal judgment to decide what is the Labor Party. There has been the Beazley Labor Party and the Lang Labor Party, just to call two to mind. There has been a whole range of different parties all of which in their day contended for their place in the sun and contended that they were the rightful successors and therefore the rightful users of that title. Make no mistake that as time evolves there will be splits in particular political parties. This has happened in the Australian Labor Party a number of times over many years. So the question of whether registration is the right thing and the question of who is entitled to a name will be extremely difficult ones.

Attempts have been made in this legislation to improve upon the handling of postal voting and in many ways it is beneficial to improve upon the facilities for people to get postal votes, to speed up the process and to provide a register of postal voting. All of this, on the face of it, is good, and all of this is aimed at trying to stop exploitation and trying to stop any kind of corruption within the system. When we come to the Committee stage my colleagues and I will be making comments on some of what we regard as the imperfections, some of the overrigidities that have been built into this system.

I want to dwell for a moment or two upon the difficulties that I particularly have faced-and I am sure others have too-in confronting this whole matter of electoral reform. There seems to me to be a necessity to get to the philosophy of what we are seeking before we invent a mechanism. There is a tendency to start off by saying 'Let us invent a mechanism which will be the most simple mechanism we can possibly devise' instead of saying 'This is my goal. This is the goal I want to reach, and the mechanism or the vehicle for getting there will be described by me now'. The fact is that when one comes to the question of preferential and proportional representation and of informal and formal votes one needs to ask oneself: 'What comes first-the protection of the philosophy of the voting system or the methodology of collecting a formal vote?' One can of course so simplify a preferential vote or a proportional representation vote to enable total formality that the vote is no longer preferential or no longer proportional in itself. So in fact in my series of dissenting reports I posed a series of problems. I said:

Preferential and proportional representation systems depend for their success upon an educated and motivated electorate which will seek to ascertain the backgrounds and affiliations of candidates and groups and will make a conscious effort to allot them a considered order of preferences. Some may be willing to follow a particular how-to-vote card. Others will want to be free to move freely over the ballot paper.
Then I said this:
The question to be asked is: What is more important, the character and integrity of the voting system or the maximum reduction of informal voting? The two are not readily compatible.

What are we seeking to do-to protect the voting system or simply to reduce informal votes? I think this has been a dilemma in the journey of time, because rightly or wrongly-I, as a minority, believe wrongly-the Australian community has over many years accepted compulsory voting as part of its religion in terms of election processes. It is as though it were absolutely fundamental. We seem to have a belief that this is common to democratic systems. The fact of the matter is that compulsory voting is the exception rather than the rule. It does not exist in countries such as America or the United Kingdom. Once we start on the principle of compulsory voting we force a whole series of sanctions into the system. The enforcement of enrolments, the enforcement of getting people to the polls and the enforcement of virtually compelling them to vote. What a strange thing it is. We have a system which forces people, whether they are willing or not, to go to the polls. It cannot pick up the pencils and mark the ballot papers. It cannot force them to do a variety of things, yet it does-it compels. In my dissenting report I gave judgment-and it is purely mine; my political party believes in compulsion but I do not because I think it alters the whole system to the great disadvantage of democracy. I said:
The compulsion of an apathetic, reluctant or even hostile person to vote may well produce an ill-considered and irresponsible vote.

Indeed, those of us who know the extent of the donkey vote, that is the vote as I have described it, know that it is in the order of 2 per cent or more. It is worth pausing to remember that most elections are decided on a margin of less than 2 per cent-that is, the marginal seats are decided by that much. Have we come to a situation in which we are willing to allow the results in an election to be determined by the compulsion of the apathetic, the reluctant or even the hostile? The more one looks at what happens in voting, the more one comes to the conclusion that a considerable number of people go to the polls but do not want to vote.

In the summary in the report we see that 32.4 per cent of the informal ballot papers for the House of Representatives were blank, 14.99 per cent of them had writing, lines or scribbling only and 21.24 per cent had symbols only. So something like 65 per cent of the people were determined that they were not going to cast a formal vote in the ordinary way. Thirty-two per cent of voters who voted informally put in blank ballot papers.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the total informal vote?

—The percentage of informal votes for the House of Representatives was 2.52 per cent. For the Senate 8.67 per cent of the ballot papers were blank, 4.82 per cent had only writing, lines or scribble, and 7.01 per cent had only symbols. A very significant number of people had no intention of trying to cast a formal vote, as distinct from those who made an honest attempt.
—Some of them must have been terrified by the size of the ballot paper.

—I accept what Senator Sibraa says. In fact, the Labor Party and the Labor Government are now to invent a Senate ballot paper under the list system which will terrify everybody. The logic of what I am now saying precludes acceptance of a list system. I will describe the list system because it follows on from informal voting. Everybody is aware that a Senate ballot paper in one or two States only, mainly New South Wales and perhaps Victoria, is a very large and formidable ballot paper. All sorts of devices have been suggested to simplify that ballot paper. One such device was that it should be circular; another was that we would have a lottery to decide who should be in the left-hand corner so that the donkey vote could be accidental. It is an interesting proposition because the list system makes the donkey vote non- accidental in the end. Now we have come up with an extraordinary recommendation, one that I believe defies anybody's rational outlook. I ask the Senate to reject it. It is proposed that each of the parties and groups register their names on the Senate ballot paper. With the registration they can register the order of preferences on their how to vote card. Any group, however small or ineffectual, can register its name and its how to vote card and then, in the lottery of fate, it can be in any position, including the left-hand position, on the how to vote card. By that lottery or Lotto method it can then distribute its vote across the paper, not by random but by its predetermination. Thus in the future quite clearly many will struggle to get the left-hand position. The major political parties will have a vested interest in lobbying strenuously all groups on the ballot paper to register how to vote cards giving them the preferences ahead of their opponents. There will be a tendency for self-interested political parties to have more phoney groups on the ballot paper, because the luck goes to whatever group wins the left-hand position and can transfer the preferences. This is put forward by those who interject about the formidable size of the Senate how to vote card. Now they will make it much more formidable. It is also put forward by those who say that we need to make sure that preferences can be properly allocated. I say to the Senate that the list system as proposed in this legislation would be an outrage to our system of democracy. In due course I will make a number of other comments on some of the fundamentals, but I deal with two or three other matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said that in general terms the redistribution process seems to be sensible and independent, one that can give a sensible judgment. But the Government has decided that the decision on the boundaries shall be made outside Parliament and without any kind of debate within the Parliament. I reject that decision. Parliament is the sovereign body. In the end, those statutory bodies which do its work ought to have a responsibility to table their work here. A debate should be held in the Parliament. I am not advocating a debate which rejects, delays or has any part in altering the final boundaries, but I stress the need for the right to scrutinise what is put forward. There should be the right to make suggestions within a rigid time-table so that there will not be any delay. Parliament should be able to question the electoral commissioners as to whether they had thought of various points. The commissioners could then make their final judgment. I reject the proposition of those who continually say that an honest situation can only come about by putting it into the hands of someone outside Parliament and that to put it in the hands of the Parliament would lead to a dishonest situation. I totally reject that proposition.

The institution of parliament was built and evolved as the finest expression of democracy and human values in the temporal scene. If we downgrade ourselves we deserve all we get. But I have never believed that honesty can be created or enshrined. Honesty is in the hearts of men. In my dissenting report I said, and I say now, with respect to statutory bodies, that independence in itself conveys no particular magic or virtue. Virtue emerges if independence is used for its sole purpose, that is to enable full objectivity and integrity of action. Since we are all human and capable of fallibility of judgment, whether members of independent tribunals or not, there is no substitute for full public scrutiny of those to whom we have given particular powers. Every statutory body has a responsibility to table its reports in the Parliament and to be subject to examination as we are day by day. Those who have a view that members of parliament have some lesser amount of honesty than those outside do a grave disservice to this Parliament. I reject the proposition totally.

This Bill enshrines the principles of public funding and disclosure. There is some tendency to think that because the Liberal Party does not believe in public funding or disclosure it is hiding something and is the party of big money and big business. It is felt that it is a huge public machine compared with the poor helpless Labor Party. There can be no greater nonsense than that. The huge industrial infrastructure of the Labor Party through the trade union movement, shop stewards and trade union officials selling their philosophy in the boss's time day by day, cannot compare with the more amateur effort on the other side. Money in itself has been demonstrably a much larger part of the organisation of the Labor Party, including its infrastructure of finance from the trade union movement. To try to compare the amount of money spent by parties in the last two or three weeks of an election campaign, and to say that because the Labor Party in recent years has spent less that it is necessary to have some kind of equaliser and that it should be given more money is nonsense. Let us therefore equalise over the whole journey. Let us look at the whole of the infrastructure.

The fundamental of a political party is that it is a voluntary organisation. It gets its energies from the grass roots base by striving and by drawing upon the physical and financial energies of people. Thus it should remain. I reject any suggestion that one can by public funding legislate for honesty. In my time I have never heard anything more cynical than that kind of proposition. As I said in my dissenting report:

It is not possible to legislate for honesty. To erect a facade which cannot work and to represent it to the community as a reform to strengthen the integrity of the democratic system is to do the community a grave disservice.

If a candidate, member or political party has an inherent tendency to dishonesty or a weakness to yield to temptations or pressures for a reward, no public subsidies towards Federal election campaigns will strengthen the integrity of the individual or the organisation, nor will disclosure of election funds be any deterrent.

What nonsense it is for anyone to believe that with this kind of system suddenly we will create honest people where, by implication, there was a tendency to weakness or dishonesty. That is the first thing I want to reject. I have a higher opinion of my fellow parliamentarians and my fellow men than that proposition implies. I do not believe that history shows that parliamentarians have been corrupted by money and that decisions have been made in Parliament as a result of corruption by money. They have often been made by corruption of ideas and by corruption by other pressures; they have been made honestly; and they have been made by bungling. But in any case I have to say that it is a quaint proposition indeed. As I have said, it is a cynical view of mankind, and one which I do not share, to somehow suggest that integrity can be bought by a public payment which may alleviate the financial pressures of election expenses. That is absolute nonsense. Those who say 'Look, overseas they have public funding; they do this, that and the other' have not told us the consequences. They have not disclosed to us whether suddenly overseas the system has become more honest, whether the politicians have suddenly developed halos. It is a nonsense situation. What they should tell us is that the result of public funding has been that every kind of trick has been devised to get funding privately, by back door measures. Every kind of device has been invented and used to dodge disclosure.

What we are doing here is a sad thing indeed. In a Bill which contains many useful things, this provision, the list system, the hours of polling and one or two other things are, in my judgment, major defects. It would be wrong for us to go to the public and say that we are self-cleansing, that we will make something honest, when, in the first place, there has been no disclosure in the past of major dishonesty and, secondly, when we are really saying that we will keep potentially dishonest people honest by giving them money. I think that is the very reverse of the truth. I reject it. I believe that a political party should be a voluntary organisation. In the past we have basically had a system which has worked. I believe that we get a vibrant organisation when volunteers give their physical and financal efforts to a political party, and I am sorry indeed that the Bill should have been constructed to include such, I think, grave imperfections.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill. In 1977, in 1979 and again in 1980 when the Australian Labor Party was in opposition I moved that a select committee of the Senate be appointed, firstly to inquire into and report upon all provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 and associated regulations and procedures and, in particular, changes that should be made to parts XIII to XV of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, which deal with methods of polling and the present system of counting returned votes, and changes that should be made to parts XVI and XVII of the Commonwealth Electoral Act so as to determine the best means of ensuring the public disclosure of the sources and amounts of donations to political parties and candidates and to prevent abuses of existing limitations on electoral expenses; and, secondly, an appropriate method of allotting proportional subsidies by the Australian Government to political parties and candidates. We did not have the numbers in the Senate at that stage and the committee was never established. Therefore, I am extremely pleased to see that one of the first acts of the Labor Government was to set up the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform-which is very similar to the select committee that I proposed, as I said, in 1977, 1979 and 1980-to see it reporting to the Parliament only six months later and now to come in here and see the legislation introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: There has never been a complete overhaul of the Electoral Act and therefore the report and legislation are long overdue. When Senator Withers and Senator Chaney , who are now in opposition, were the Ministers concerned with the Electoral Act they both promised a full review. Both Ministers publicly expressed dissatisfaction with the electoral laws. They were followed as Ministers for Administrative Services by Mr John McLeay who, in answer to a question in the House of Representatives, also said that our electoral system needed review. But what was done? Absolutely nothing.

I intend in the time available to me today to make my main remarks on the issue of public funding. We have just heard a speech from Senator Sir John Carrick, who spent the majority of his time opposing the concept of public funding. We have to ask ourselves why the Opposition is worried about public funding. Why have Opposition members of this Parliament and also of the New South Wales parliamentary Opposition called public funding corrupt and why did a previous Liberal Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, call it corrupt, especially when it can be argued that the most democratic of countries-for example, France, Holland, the United States, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Belgium, Switzerland, West Germany, Italy and Canada, to name but a few-have some form of public funding? In fact, Australia is one of the last democracies to install a system of public funding. Public funding has been in existence for over a decade in a number of countries. These countries have working parliamentary democracies at a time when the number of parliamentary democracies around the world is declining. It could be argued that public funding has made those countries more democratic.

My interest in this subject goes back to 1973 when I was a delegate on an Australian Labor Party and Australian Council of Trade Unions delegation that went to the Federal Republic of Germany. One of the issues we were interested in was public funding. We were guests of the Social Democratic Party's political education foundation, the Friederich Ebert Foundation, and the Christian Democrats of course also have their foundation, the Konrad Adenauer Foundation. I, along with the other members of that delegation, was amazed at the work of these foundations not only within the Federal Republic of Germany but also elsewhere because, in fact, their work was international. For example, the Social Democratic Party's foundation has offices in places as widely dispersed around the world as Lusaka in Zambia and Bangkok in Thailand. They are all publicly funded. In West Germany and Sweden the parties receive funds not only for educational purposes but also for party newspapers and research, and I believe that there is certainly a role in Australia for political funding of educational and research work for the major parties. It has been a very barren area indeed for the major Australian political parties.

What is involved in the public funding legislation? Public funding is to be provided to registered political parties and to registered groups and candidates who are not endorsed by a registered political party on the following basis: Firstly, 60c per vote in a House of Representatives election or by-election and, secondly, 30c per vote in a Senate election that occurs simultaneously with a House of Representatives election and 45c per vote in a half Senate election. To qualify for public funding a party representative, or team group in a Senate election, or an individual non-party candidate must poll 4 per cent of the formal vote. My personal opinion is that it should be higher, but the Committee has come down with 4 per cent and the legislation includes that figure. Amounts available for public funding are paid up only to the level of proved electoral expenditure. The amounts to be paid per vote are to be indexed each six months in accordance with the consumer price index. Donations of $200 or more to a candidate or $1,000 or more to a party or group must be disclosed to the Australian Electoral Commission. Anonymous donations above the disclosable level are to be forfeited to the Commonwealth. The agents of candidates and parties must disclose the name and address of the person making a donation. All electoral expenditure incurred by candidates, parties and other participants in electoral campaigns must be disclosed to the Electoral Commissioner. Furthermore , all radio and television stations, newspapers and printers must disclose electoral expenditure and indicate the source of the expenditure.

I note, Mr Deputy President, that former Senator Puplick, a Liberal senator, in his maiden speech in the Senate on 20 September 1978, said that he looked forward to the days when we would have public funding of political parties, disclosure of donations, some register of pecuniary interests, fair redistributions, one vote one value, a revised Federal Constitution and real popular participation in government.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES SPECIAL COMMISSION OF INQUIRY

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the answer he gave me on 3 November in relation to access by the New South Wales Special Commission of Inquiry to Australian Federal Police transcripts when he said that, if it was necessary to amend the Commonwealth law to do so, he would be prepared to introduce legislation to that effect. In view of the inability of Mr Justice Cross to proceed with the investigation of some of the allegations that have been referred to him until he has this information, does the Attorney now agree that prompt action is required by the Commonwealth? Has the Attorney been able to process the matter which again seems to be in difficulties with the Labor Caucus over the proposed amendment to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act? When does he expect to be able to bring forward the necessary amendments to the legislation?

—It is necessary to pass legislation to enable the material in question to be passed to Mr Justice Cross for the purposes of inquiry. Yes, I have been able to process the matter through the Parliamentary Labor Party and I expect to be able to introduce the necessary remedial legislation tomorrow.

—Can the Attorney-General advise what High Court challenges the Queensland Government has instituted against the Commonwealth Government since 1972? What have been the results of those challenges and what legal costs have been incurred by the Queensland Government in relation to those challenges?

—There have been six High Court challenges by Queensland since 1972 to Commonwealth legislation. The only successful one was in 1975 to the validity of the Petroleum and Minerals Authority Act 1973 on a narrow technical ground. I do not have the information as to the cost that may have been incurred by the Queensland Government in the conduct of those matters. I will make available to Senator Colston the full detail of the cases in question. However, briefly, they were: Queensland against Whitlam, which was the challenge to the Bill being put to a joint sitting; Queensland against the Commonwealth, which was the challenge to the validity of the Seas and Submerged Lands Act; Queensland against the Commonwealth, which was a challenge to the validity of the Senate (Representation of Territories) Act; Queensland against the Commonwealth, which was the successful challenge to the Petroleum and Minerals Authority Act based on the technical question about Senate procedures; Queensland against the Commonwealth, which was a further challenge to the Senate (Representation of Territories) Act; Queensland against the Commonwealth, which was the challenge, of course, in the Koowarta case to the validity of the Racial Discrimination Act. So the batting average has not been all that sensational.

—I ask the Attorney-General a question. I refer to an article by Marion Wilkinson in the National Times under the heading 'Big shots bugged'. Has the Attorney-General noted the article and particularly the serious allegations made in regard to a Sydney solicitor, a former New South Wales magistrate, a judge and a Liberal politician? Will the Attorney-General assure the Senate that these allegations have been or will be fully investigated to determine whether there have been any breaches of Commonwealth law and, if so, that appropriate action has been or will be taken?

—For reasons relevant to the date of commencement of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act, phone tapping by the Australian Federal Police could not have been involved in relation to the subject of this particular story. For similar reasons, I can assert with some confidence that there was no use by the Federal Police of the listening device provisions in the Customs Act. To the extent that the story has any foundation, it is possible that the source may have been a listening device authorised under New South Wales law which could have been used by the Australian Federal Police or the New South Wales police. The Australian Federal Police, I am advised by the Special Minister of State, are investigating whether the leak came from any information supplied by them. I am awaiting further information on this aspect from the Special Minister of State. We will see what it might be possible to put on the public record when we have that information.

—Has the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs recently received a letter from me passing on the concern of some Tasmanians in the non-government school sector concerning consultations being undertaken by the Schools Commission with the non-government school community in regard to the evolution of a new method of distributing funds to that sector of education? Is the Minister satisfied with the extent and timeliness of any such consultation? Will she ensure that consultation takes place at the lowest feasible level closest to the actual school communities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of Senator Tate's representations on this matter. I share his concern that consultations about a new formula for funding of non- government schools should be as extensive as possible. I have instructed the Schools Commission to commence these consultations and to ensure that all major and legitimate spokespersons for the non-government sector will have an opportunity to discuss these matters with the Commission. The Commission, of course, has an ongoing program of consultations around Australia. It meets with non-government school authorities, as I do. I have had the opportunity in every State and Territory in Australia except, I must say, Senator Tate's State of Tasmania, to have discussions with the major organisations representing the diversity of non-government sectors. However, the Commission is aware of the urgent need for it to be able to answer my invitation to advise us on a new equitable formula of funding which will accommodate our concept of the community standard. The consultations have begun. The Schools Commission has already had a meeting in Tasmania in the last couple of months and has written to non- government school organisations and authorities in all States advising them of the timetable for the development of the new formula and of the schedule for consultations which will take place early next year.

ANSWER.PARA: I share Senator Tate's concern that consultations should be as close to the grass roots as possible. But I am sure Senator Tate and all non-government school authorities will understand that it is not possible for the Commission to visit every non-government school in Australia. There are 2,200 non-government schools in Australia and obviously there is not the opportunity for individual consultations with each school. I am confident that the non-government schools authorities in each State-bodies such as State planning and finance committees on which already there is wide representation from the non-government sector- will be able to put into our development policy in this area all the concerns and the requirements that they have.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs whether she has seen advertisements in this morning's newspapers calling on me by name and my colleague Democrat senators to 'vote in favour of an amendment to the '' States Grants (Schools) Assistance Bill 1983'' which calls for the restoration of the right of all children to receive guaranteed government financial support for their education'. Senator Macklin, our spokesman on education, last night telephoned Elizabeth Hart, the person who authorised the advertisement, to ask her what the advertisement was referring to. She told him that she did not know. Following that, I ask: Can the Minister tell me whether it is possible to amend this Bill along the lines suggested by Mrs Hart and the group supporting her? Can the Minister confirm that the only amendment that I know of-namely, that moved by Senator Peter Baume-is only in fact an expression of opinion and in no way can it amend the Bill or change its contents?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the advertisement in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning which is attempting to bully the Australian Democrats into adopting a course of action which is technically not feasible. Obviously, this advertisement is part of a campaign conducted by some supporters of those schools which have had their Commonwealth recurrent grant reduced modestly to try to force the Government to change its mind.

ANSWER.PARA: The suggestion in the advertisement represents a complete misunderstanding, deliberate or otherwise, of the powers of the Senate in this regard. Certainly, I have seen no amendment which would attempt to change the allocations of money in the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill and I am not surprised that I have not, since such a course of action is not possible.

I have heard of, though not seen, a second reading amendment which I gather Senator Baume intends to move, which expresses his opinion about the appropriations for education. We have actually heard his opinion before, but apparently he will attempt to append his opinion to the motion for the second reading of the Bill. I have seen no draft amendment which would accommodate the demands made on the Australian Democrats in the advertisement which I saw this morning.

Honourable senators ought to be aware that the powers of the Senate in relation to amending laws, appropriating revenue or moneys, or imposing taxation are based on section 53 of the Constitution. The relevant part of that section states:
The Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people.

The grants to these 41 schools were reduced by 25 per cent. As the restoration of that 25 per cent to the 41 schools concerned to the level operating in 1983 would clearly require additional funds, it would therefore represent an increase on the burden of the people. It is therefore quite inappropriate for the Senate to attempt to amend the legislation in the way suggested by the advertisement concerned.

I point out to honourable senators that, contrary to what the advertisement maintains, all children in non-government schools will continue to receive a basic grant in 1984. For the 41 schools which have attracted so much attention, the grants will be $270 for each primary student and $428 for each secondary student. These 41 schools, I must stress, will in fact attract nearly $13m in recurrent grants from the Commonwealth alone in 1984.

I point out again for the information of the Senate that the most needy schools , those at level 3 which represent 85 per cent of the non-government schools, will receive $741 for each primary school child. That is a $21 increase over last year in real terms. The sum of $1,177 will be given for each secondary student. That is an increase of $34 in real terms over what was received last year.

So the implication in the advertisement that there has been an overall reduction in funding for the non-government sector is quite wrong. There has been an overall increase. There has been some redistribution which, together with extra allocations from the Government, has brought about those increases for the vast majority of non-government schools. The 41 schools are still receiving a per capita grant at the levels I have mentioned. I remind the Senate that the $13m in Commonwealth recurrent funding to the 41 schools is a very significant proportion of additional funds which were made available in the education budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware that the Queensland Cabinet this week gave permission for the development of a coastal road through the Cape Tribulation National Park in far north Queensland? As this area contains unique rain-forest recognised as part of the National Estate, can the Minister comment on the role of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment in protecting this area? Furthermore, is the Minister concerned about the development occurring in close proximity to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park? What liaison is proposed between State and Federal authorities to ensure the protection of the nation's unique rain-forests in north Queensland and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the proposal by the Douglas Shire Council to construct a road through the Daintree National Park between Cape Tribulation and Bloomfield River. The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment discussed this matter with local shire officials during his visit to north Queensland last week . While I recognise that this proposal falls within the responsibility of the Queensland Government, both the Minister and I deplore the destruction of the rain-forest which would result if this type of construction were to proceed.

ANSWER.PARA: I am also concerned about the harm which would be done to the fringing reefs along the coastline. Accordingly, the Minister has asked his officials to work on this matter with all dispatch and to come up with an alternative which will enable the preservation of this outstanding rain-forest area while at the same time taking into account the development needs of the people of north Queensland .

TALK.START.PARA: —My question which is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce refers to an article which appeared in the previous edition of the National Times concerning the Colorshield Tile Co. of Brisbane. Is the Minister aware of the serious difficulties facing this company, which is now said to be producing at only 25 per cent of capacity and facing closure because of a drawn out investigation by his Department of a complaint about dumping by a New Zealand company? Is it true that in October last year a prima facie case was established that Colorshield was suffering from dumping by AHI Decrabond? Is the Minister satisfied with the conduct of the matter since that time? Does he plan any personal intervention to assist the company? Does he believe the case has demonstrated the need for any change in procedures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the article in the National Times. I am not sure that I read it, but I looked at the picture. I think it was in the issue before last. I am certainly aware of the complaints of Colorshield. I have met with the proprietors of that company on two occasions. I certainly cannot answer in terms of the exact dates on which events were alleged to have occurred, but let me say this: Last year there was a complaint and an investigation about dumping. The company, AHI, made certain voluntary undertakings, as it was able to do under the dumping procedures. These undertakings were consistent with our obligations under the closer economic relations agreement and under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. In June of this year a price undertaking was proposed by the importer and general agreement was reached on that matter. I accepted those undertakings.

ANSWER.PARA: Since that time, the complaints of Colorshield have rather been directed towards the very large supplies of the competing product from New Zealand which it is alleged were imported into Australia before the undertakings were given. The supplies were stockpiled and directed specifically to the Queensland market. That is the essence of the complaint.

That matter is still the subject of investigation. It is the subject of correspondence between AHI and me. I received a letter on the matter from that company a few days ago. That issue is not resolved. Whether a solution is available to the Government in the circumstances as described is doubtful, but officers of my Department have been in Queensland investigating the matter in the last few days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations been drawn to an article in last Thursday's Australian Financial Review in which it was revealed that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, had called for changes to the industrial relations framework which would allow companies and workers to opt out of the arbitration system? Does the Minister believe that this type of approach is desirable in the present economic climate? Is it consistent with the views expressed by employers at the National Economic Summit Conference? Would such an approach be destabilising and could it lead to an upsurge in the level of industrial disputation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's position on the question of wage fixation is, I think, abundantly clear. It has been the subject of discussion at Question Time in this chamber on a number of occasions. The Government is committed to a centralised wage fixation system. That commitment was approved at the Summit and has since been approved again and again by a number of prominent industrialists and industrial relations practitioners. So there can be no doubt about the Government's view. There is a lot of doubt, of course, about the Opposition's view, because the Opposition speaks with a forked tongue on this matter.
—Many tongues.

—It has been suggested that it speaks with many tongues. I am not a tongue expert. In answer to previous questions I have drawn attention to the views expressed by Mr Macphee in relation to these matters. I want to make one or two observations about the suggestions raised by Mr Howard. I am not criticising them, but they are far from being fully developed. Certainly, the public has not had the benefit of understanding a full exposition of Mr Howard's views. While it is suggested that unions and particular employers could opt out of the conciliation and arbitration system, it is not at all clear whether they would be able to opt in again if it suited them. That is a consideration which I think would very likely arise. Secondly, if the opt-out provision is followed, it is quite clear that those unions which do agree with employers to opt out will be those unions which have very powerful industrial muscle. The implications of such a process of the strong unions opting out of the system would certainly lead, I think, to higher levels of industrial disputation and would not be in the interests of the overall system.

ANSWER.PARA: I think Mr Howard has directed a lot of attention to the concept of comparative wage justice. The extent to which he attributes failure of the wages system to that concept would not be modified by his proposal, because that proposal, insofar as it is historically and perhaps incorrectly fixed into the wage fixation system in Australia, would remain. There are other concerns about Mr Howard's view. One intellectual basis for the view seems to be that as a result of the existence of the so-called comparative wage justice system wage levels fixed in a particular industry automatically flow to other industries. In the past that has not been so in terms of the resource based industries, which have paid very high wages compared with other industries. Those wage levels have not automatically flowed to other industries. There are a number of criticisms of this kind which simply reveal that it is a proposition which is full of sound and fury in the market-place, but at this stage it signifies nothing. Until it signifies something it is probably not advisable for even an Opposition party in Australia to be peddling the view very widely until there is some serious intellectual underpinning of the viability of that view.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate because of the close interest he took in matters of Government information when he was in opposition. What was the cost of producing the first edition of the Record of Government, which, complete with portraits of Ministers , purports to inform the public of the Government's achievements in its first few months of office? How many copies have been printed and what has been their distribution? How regularly are we likely to suffer this exercise in blatant political propaganda? Does the Minister agree that the Government is guilty of gross hypocrisy, given its previously sanctimonious approach to Government information activities, in launching this entirely new publication and through its other decisions which have resulted in an increase from 17 to 33 in the journalistic staff working in close contact with Ministers to promote this Government's activities?
