—I congratulate Senator Reid for remembering my diligence on this topic when we were in opposition. I am glad that I made some impression in that role. Let me say that the burden of the criticisms I made was that the Fraser Government, by its vast expenditures on these matters, was setting new and lower standards. The assumption in Senator Reid's question was, of course, that a Labor Government would inevitably set higher standards. I am very grateful to her for making that assumption. I think that it is true of most of the things which we do. It was an interesting assumption underlying the question. Having made that comment, I am unable to answer any of the questions which Senator Reid specifically asked. I do not know how many copies of the Record of Government were printed. I do not know what the cost was. I do not know how regularly the publication will come out. If Senator Reid likes it, we can arrange for it to come out every month. I will provide details as soon as possible.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I preface it by saying that the Minister will be aware that many retired members of our community invest their life savings in non-interest bearing accounts. In the light of that, will the Minister's Department publish a series of comparative tables so that retired members of our community can establish how best to maximise their incomes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ray for the question. Many retired members of the community in recent years-certainly since the introduction of the income test, as distinct from the means test-have been putting their money into non-interest bearing accounts, such as cheque accounts, in order to avoid the income test. Frequently this has been most unwise. This has been demonstrated in particular by figures Senator Gietzelt has released regarding applications for service pensions. The great tragedy of this situation, of course, is that people have been investing large amounts in interest-free deposits. The capital amount is eroded year by year by inflation, particularly by the sort of inflation rate which we have had in recent years. Banks and other organisations have taken great advantage of this. The people have been able to receive a pension and fringe benefits which they would have been better off not receiving. It would have been better for them to invest their money in a sensible way to their advantage and to the advantage of the country.

ANSWER.PARA: We intend to introduce the assets test. We are introducing tables to show how that assets test will affect pensioners. I will certainly take up Senator Ray's proposal that we put out tables to assist people on how to invest, and invest wisely, within the pension system. I believe the investment industry in this country, as has been said in interviews on programs recently, is now anxious to concentrate on providing proper investment advice to people rather than merely advice on how to avoid the income test or taxation. I hope that in the future the combination of that advice and new initiatives brought out by the Government will result in more sensible investment and a better and more adequate income for all retired people in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the extraordinary and unprecedented commitment by the Government to spend $1.25m of taxpayers' money on the promotion of the Yes case at the referendum to be held on 25 February, this amount, of course, being over and above the $21m cost of the referendum. I ask the Attorney-General whether in previous referenda equal opportunity for the presentation of both Yes and No cases was provided through the Australian Electoral Office and whether equal time was provided to both sides to present the cases to the people through the then Australian Broadcasting Commission. Is it also a fact that in previous referenda funds were provided for promotional purposes by organisations, political parties and individuals interested in supporting either side and that no Government finance was provided for publicity , apart from through the Electoral Office and the ABC? Can the Attorney-General say who authorised Government expenditure of $1.25m on the promotion of the Yes case? From what appropriation will this amount be obtained? Does the Attorney- General recognise the democratic fairness of equal presentation of cases for and against referendum proposals so that the electorate can make an informed decision on 25 February? Will he acknowledge that it is unfair that these government funds should be earmarked for expenditure on a Yes campaign to the exclusion of the No case?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be quite irresponsible for the Government not to provide positive support for constitutional changes which would provide this country with more efficient and stable government, particularly when the changes in question have support, not just of one party, but from all the major parties in this country. The Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats support the matters being put to the public in this way. It is the case that the No case gets ample treatment at taxpayers' expense through the equal time provisions that Senator Jessop has referred to and, of course, through the distribution of the referendum pamphlet containing the Yes and No cases. We still await with interest what Senator Jessop's No case will be on the removal of obsolete provisions. It is the case that the No case gets ample air time.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also the case that opponents of referendum proposals in the past have generally embarked upon quite active paid advertising campaigns of their own, supported as they have been by various interest groups. I readily concede that it has been very rare indeed for governments of the day to do anything other than rely simply on ordinary campaigning and the formal Yes and No cases going into the post boxes. The absence of strong campaigning on the Yes side must be seen as contributing to Australia's record of failed referendums. When one is spending $21.5m on the conduct of the referendum, the additional one and a bit million dollars that is proposed for this, by comparison, seems eminently worth spending.

I make one final point. The Queensland Premier has indicated his enthusiasm for embarking upon what he describes as an election style No campaign against the referendum proposals. I have no doubt that the Tasmanian Premier will do the same. I will be very interested to know whether either of those gentlemen will give undertakings as to the non-utilisation of any government or taxpayers' resources in those States in the conduct of their contributions to this campaign .

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Attorney- General very effectively evaded the question. I asked him, among other things, who authorised the expenditure of taxpayers' money for this purpose? From what appropriation will this money be obtained? Does the Attorney consider it fair that the Yes case should be supported by taxpayers' money, whereas the No campaign apparently is not considered worthy of support although many people in the electorate would want that to be presented on an equal basis?

—The last part of Senator Jessop's supplementary question is simply idle reiteration of the rather feeble rhetoric with which he commenced his question. I do not think it demands any further answer. In relation to the first part of the question and who authorised the expenditure, a committee of Ministers on government advertising, chaired by the Special Minister of State, is responsible for dealing with things such as authorisation of Medicare advertising or Commonwealth Electoral Office enrolment drives and matters of that kind. That committee has formally endorsed this proposal. The appropriation in question will come out of, as I understand it, the appropriation for the Department of the Special Minister of State. The honourable senator is welcome to pursue this matter with as much vigour as he can muster when it comes to the next round of Estimates.
—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. What plans does the Government have in the short or long term for the future of Essendon Airport in Melbourne?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The future of Essendon Airport, of course, is a matter of considerable importance to the residents in the area and in Melbourne generally. I am led to believe that a study was commissioned by the immediate post-coup Government led by former Prime Minister Fraser back in 1976. He indicated that a study would be carried out about the future of that airport. I think the words he used were that it had a future until about 1985, and he gave that Government' s commitment to review the future use of the airport. This review is currently being carried out for the Commonwealth Government by the Department of Aviation. It is due to be completed by mid-1984. Following completion of that review the Government expects to announce its decision on the future of the airport, that is, to retain or close Essendon Airport by mid-1985.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government, however, in addition to continuing the review of that decision and to help it formulate its opinion, has determined that we should look at the likely effects. A committee has been commissioned to look at the future of the airport. To allow the widest possible participation in the review, a public liaison group has been commissioned. That liaison group, chaired by the Department of Aviation, comprises representatives of State and local government, community groups, industry, employee groups and other individuals.

The Government is intent that there should be public participation. This will be achieved through a series of public opinion polls, through a public awareness campaign which includes paid advertisements in the local Press and audio-visual display in local shopping centres and community centres, and information leaflets delivered to approximately 44,000 local inhabitants within five kilometres of the airport. So we are setting out very deliberately to seek the opinions of those who will be affected by any change in the present status of Essendon Airport. Conditional upon that review, the Government will make a decision within the next year or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware that the Douglas Shire Council of Cairns is about to commence construction of a road through the magnificent coastal rain-forest wilderness between Cape Tribulation and Bloomfield? Is it not a fact that this area is listed on the register of the National Estate? Is it also not a fact that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment said in Queensland on 23 November that this area would be suitable for world heritage listing? Can the Minister confirm that the Government has proper and responsible legislative powers under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 and the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 to prevent this act of destruction against the National Estate?
—A similar question has been asked, but this one is a little wider in its terms. Therefore I shall allow it. I call the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment.

—I answered a question about this proposed road which would destroy the rain-forest region in the Daintree area. I informed the Senate that my colleague the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment is having discussions with Queensland officers to seek to provide an alternative whereby the rain- forest can be protected and the development needs of north Queensland addressed. In relation to the specific powers which the Commonwealth might have, either to list the matter on the World Heritage List or to take action, I will refer those matters for more detailed response from the Minister, Mr Cohen.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. It refers to the recent report that nearly 50 per cent of the country's racial discrimination complaints came from residents of Queensland. Can the Attorney indicate when an office of the Human Rights Commission will be established in Queensland? Does the Federal Government anticipate receiving full co-operation from the Queensland Government in the setting up and the operation of the Commission in that State?

—It is the case that Queensland accounts for far and away the largest proportion of complaints made by Aboriginals under the Racial Discrimination Act. The figure is not quite half; 60 out of 160 complaints were made in Queensland last year as revealed in the figures given by the Deputy Chairman of the Human Rights Commission, Mr Peter Bailey, last week. The Deputy Chairman announced that it was the intention of the Commission to open an office in Brisbane as early as possible in the New Year. I have indicated to the Human Rights Commission that I view the matter as one of very high priority. I will be having discussions with the Commission shortly about resources to allow the opening of that Brisbane office. As to the last part of Senator Elstob's question, discussions with officials in Queensland as late as last week indicate that there is no likelihood that Queensland has any intention of passing anti- discrimination legislation of its own. Whether we will have any co-operation from Queensland in the operation of the Commonwealth Human Rights Commission in that State remains to be seen. I would not want to have my shirt on it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Is the Government considering a proposal to move the Australia Council from Sydney to Canberra? Does the Government have an opinion on whether such a move should take place? Will the Government make an announcement on the subject? If so, when will the announcement be made?

—I can assure the Senate that the Government is not considering a proposal regarding the future situation of the Australia Council. I am very well aware that there is debate within the arts community about whether the Australia Council is appropriately placed in Sydney, or whether it ought to be moved either on an alternate basis to Melbourne or permanently to Canberra. Many people are now voicing opinions on these matters. There have been a number of conferences recently at which these matters have been raised. I am aware that my colleague the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has attended some of these conferences and heard the points of view of people who believe that the fact that the Australia Council is in Sydney means that there is some sort of bias in its funding decisions towards people living and working in New South Wales. I am not aware of any formal proposal regarding any change in the situation of the Australia Council. Should such a proposal come on the agenda, obviously it would be a matter that the Government would be aware of. However, I will ask my colleague Mr Barry Cohen whether he has any ideas or views that may be of interest to Senator Martin on this subject.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. It relates to the claim in last Saturday's Four Corners program on Australian Broadcasting Commission television that the Vietnamese Government has undertaken a detailed study of its war veterans which reveals a strong link between service in areas likely to have been sprayed with chemicals such as agent orange and major health problems such as cancer and an abnormally high level of birth defect among veterans' children. I ask the Minister: Will the Royal Commission on the Use and Effect of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam investigate this study as well as any other available evidence of a link between chemical spraying and health problems amongst the Vietnamese population?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the Four Corners program dealing with the problems facing those who served in Vietnam made a number of allegations and drew a number of matters to the attention of both my Department and myself. Naturally, it has drawn to our attention the matters that Senator Giles has raised with me. The program indicated that information was provided to Ministers of conservative governments which certainly was inadequate and may well prove to have been incorrect. However, so far as the Royal Commission is concerned, when the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, was in Vietnam in June of this year the Vietnamese Foreign Minister, Mr Thach, indicated his Government's willingness to co-operate in the Royal Commission's inquiry and to make available evidence such as the study to which the honourable senator referred. Similarly, the American Government has offered to make available to the Commission such information as would assist it to reach some definite conclusions.

ANSWER.PARA: As I understand it, the Vietnamese study shows that the children of North Vietnamese veterans are four times as likely to suffer from birth defects, if their father served in the south of Vietnam prior to their birth, as is the case if service was confined to the north where no chemical spraying took place. In addition, I am informed that the Vietnamese have undertaken scientific investigations which also claim to substantiate this particular link. Obviously, the Commission will examine these claims very closely. If the claims are soundly based they will be of central importance to the Commission's deliberations. As a result of that, the Royal Commissioner has required the junior counsel of the Royal Commission, Mr Max Kimber, to leave Australia on 5 December for a one-week trip to Vietnam to undertake a preliminary assessment of this evidence. Early next year the Royal Commissioner, His Honour Mr Justice Phillip Evatt, plans to go to Vietnam to investigate the evidence thoroughly. However, Mr Kimber's role will be to advise the Commissioner on the basis of his investigations on how long the Commissioner's trip should be and the type and number of support staff, such as scientific experts, who should accompany him. It will depend upon the initial trip as to what evidence is of particular value to the Commission. I emphasise to the Senate that the Government is concerned to constrain costs in conducting the inquiry. We have accordingly sent a junior counsel to prepare the way for the eventual visit of the Commissioner.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and it relates to the recent disclosure by the Department of Trade involving the Government stand on the Arab League boycott of Israel and, in particular, a letter sent out by regional offices of the Department of Trade which created the impression that the Australian Government indeed condoned the boycott. In the light of this disturbing disclosure I ask the Minister: Firstly, what action has been taken by the Government to rectify this situation and to make it clear that the conditions required by the Arab League governments for companies to trade with them in no way reflect the Australian position? Secondly , I ask him to reaffirm the sentiments expressed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in answering my question without notice on 21 October, which was directed to the Minister for Social Security who represents him in this chamber, that:

QUESTION.PARA: The establishment of an Arab League office in Australia would be conditional on assurances that an office would not be involved in promoting boycotts of Australian firms.

In view of this recent departmental blunder, how can he now assure the Senate that the activities of any such Arab League office will be carefully monitored so as to ensure that it does not engage in any trade boycott activities directed against companies and individuals trading or wishing to trade with Israel?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sufficiently familiar with the details as to enable me to provide a full answer to Senator Missen. I think I am able to reaffirm the undertaking given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in answer to an earlier question from Senator Missen on the conditions upon which the office would be established. But I will obtain the necessary information on the actions of the Department of Trade and provide Senator Missen with an early answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and it follows Senator Coleman's question of 18 November relating to the status under the Repatriation Act of Australian personnel serving in overseas peacekeeping forces. The Minister advised Senator Coleman on that occasion that members of peacekeeping forces are covered under the Repatriation Act provided that he designates by notice in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette that such a group is participating in a peacekeeping force. I ask the Minister: Is it a fact that a number of long-standing Australian peacekeeping forces have not yet been gazetted and therefore the members of these forces are denied repatriation benefits as things stand? What action will the Minister take to remedy this oversight?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator's observation that a number of the outstanding peacekeeping forces have not been gazetted to date is correct. The net result of that is that the Australian members of those forces are not yet eligible for repatriation benefits. As I indicated on the previous occasion, it is a requirement of the Act that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs shall gazette that information when the Government makes a decision to send overseas such peacekeeping forces. There are currently four such peacekeeping forces which I am taking urgent action to gazette in order that those Australian members, past and present, may be covered by the Repatriation Act. They are the United Nations Emergency Force Two, which served in the Suez Canal area between the years 1976 and 1980; the Commonwealth Monitoring Force in Zimbabwe, in which 150 Australians served for about six weeks in 1980; the Sinai Multinational Peacekeeping Force, the Australian contingent of which departed Australia in February 1982; and the United Nations Peacekeeping Force which went to Cyprus following Australia's involvement, which dates back as far as 1964.

ANSWER.PARA: As regards the Cyprus force, I indicated in answer to Senator Coleman's question that those persons were not covered under the Act. I undertook at the time to check on that information and to investigate that apparent anomaly, and it appears that they come within the jurisdiction of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. So I can now inform the Senate that, after gazettal, the members of the Cyprus peacekeeping force will meet the provisions of the Repatriation Act for entitlement to repatriation benefits.

The point that I have to make concerns the gross negligence of previous conservative governments and their incompetence in not taking the next step. They made the decision to send Australians to the four corners of the globe in peacekeeping activities. No steps were subsequently taken to ensure that those members, who were all perceived at some stage to be likely to be involved with hostile forces, were adequately covered for repatriation benefits and treatment on their return. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that, in the case of the Cyprus contingent, that negligence stretches back almost 20 years. It is a disgrace to the previous conservative Government. I have taken urgent steps to see that those matters are addressed immediately, so that any person eligible for repatriation benefits will be covered by the existing legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Button, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate and as the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I preface my question by noting that a strike by members of the Electrical Trades Union in Western Australia, now in its seventh week, has seriously delayed the start up of the Worsley alumina refinery in the south- west of the State, resulting in direct project costs of about $20m a month plus losses incurred by major suppliers of materials, such as coal, fuel oil and lime , due to the forced deferral of orders. I also mentioned that the company, which had been taking on new staff at the rate of about 100 a month, has now suspended all recruitment and has advised its 550 permanent employees that it cannot guarantee work after Christmas. Is the Minister aware that the dispute concerns the suspension in February by the Western Australian Industrial Commission of a $38 a week pay rise because of the wages pause, and that the union has been in defiance of a return to work order for more than three weeks and that its registration has now been suspended by the Commission? Does he share the concern of the Western Australian Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Dans, who has described the strike as 'the most serious threat to the prices and incomes accord since its inception', and who has called on the union to take a wider view? In view of the crucial importance of the accord to the national economic strategy and the concern expressed recently by the Minister for Resources and Energy about the effect of strikes on Australian resource projects, not to mention the personal hardship and threat to hundreds of other jobs, what influence can the Federal Government bring to bear in an atempt to resolve what appears to be a totally deadlocked situation which is causing hardship to hundreds of Western Australians?

—On the assumption that the facts indicated in Senator Chaney's question are correct, it sounds awful. I was not personally aware of the duration of the strike or the consequences, as they have been suggested in the question. The Government deplores industrial action of that kind which, in view of its implications, can only be described as selfish. I shall speak to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and see what steps the Government can take in relation to this matter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MR BRUCE BOND: STATEMENTS ON ASSETS TEST

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Social Security. What are the implications of any delay in the planned reintroduction of the pensions assets test for the Government's program of improving the levels of assistance to pensioners and beneficiaries generally? Secondly, is he aware that the so- called investment adviser Bruce Bond, who conducts what might be called tax avoidance and income test avoidance sessions on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio in Tasmania and, I think, in other parts of the country, has been inciting pensioners to oppose the assets test? Is it not a fact that people such as Bruce Bond are part of the problem that has forced the Government to act to prevent the avoidance of the income test? Will the Minister seek an invitation to appear on Mr Bond's program so as to put the whole issue in perspective and to explain, in particular, the implications to which I referred earlier in my question, for the vast majority of his listeners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The implications of the delay in introducing the assets test are understood by everyone. The aim of the assets test is to redistribute income, which is at present going to those who are not in need, to those who are in greater need in the pensions system. Any delay will delay that redistribution and delay the capacity of this or any government to increase those base rates of pensions and the allowances available to people-for instance, pensioners with children.

ANSWER.PARA: As for Mr Bond, I have been informed that he is using his program to campaign against the introduction of the assets test. I believe, with Senator Coates, that this is one of the problems. As I understand it, Mr Bond receives a considerable fee for conducting these programs. As a result of his public appearances on these programs, he receives a considerable increase in his private business as an investment adviser. In fact, he largely relies on the people's desire to avoid either taxation or the income test, or both. Therefore, a lot of his time is spent advising people about schemes. These are legal schemes, but they are schemes which are aimed at avoiding the income test, avoiding paying taxation through capital gains schemes, et cetera, and therefore are distorting both the taxation system and the social security system.

Because Mr Bond makes his money in this way, and because of the considerable fees that he gets from the ABC for conducting the programs, he has a vested interest in this area and cannot be considered a disinterested observer or a disinterested campaigner in this way. I would be happy to go on Mr Bond's program. I only wish that the ABC would pay me the same money as it pays him to conduct the programs. But, even if I were not paid a fee, I would be happy enough to go on the program to put the other side of the story. It is a pity that people such as Mr Bond abuse their position and take advantage of it to feather their own nests in this way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Given the fact that the Tasmanian Government is negotiating with Australian companies for the use of fishing resources in Tasmania, what are the advantages of opening up Tasmanian fishing waters to overseas fishermen? Has the Federal Government conducted negotiations with representatives from overseas countries for overseas boats to fish in waters off the Tasmanian coastline?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not able to answer the question with great precision, although I am aware that the Commonwealth Government has knowledge of discussions which have taken place regarding the opening up of Tasmanian fishing waters to foreign fishing fleets. Where there is a resource such as fish in the seas contiguous to Tasmania, it is inevitable that there will be discussions of that kind. As I understand it, the principal discussions have taken place between a very large Australian company and representatives of the Soviet Union. The Government is aware that those discussions have taken place.

ANSWER.PARA: I am also able to say that over a long period there has been discussion about the use of the porting facilities at Hobart for various foreign fishing fleets. That matter was the subject of a decision on rather narrow political grounds by the previous Government at the time of the Afghanistan incursion by the Soviet Union.

On behalf of the Government I say that there is certainly no damage to any interests, perceived or otherwise, in Tasmania by discussions about these matters taking place. I am sure they will continue to take place and I think it is desirable that they do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Have these negotiations with representatives of overseas countries taken place without reference to the Tasmanian Government?

—I cannot say whether negotiations between a private company, a very substantial Australian company, and representatives of the Soviet Union have taken place with or without the knowledge of the Tasmanian Government and I do not, with the greatest respect, regard it as any of my business or anybody else's to see that the Tasmanian Government is aware of everything that takes place. I would have thought that it was its obligation to see that it is aware of these things. The Commonwealth Government is aware, but I am not sure how that awareness comes about.
—Can you find out?

—I will certainly try to find out in relation to the Commonwealth Government. I hope the Tasmanian Government will find out. We would certainly be prepared to assist, because any decisions which are made on the basis of such discussions have to be decisions made by governments and particularly with the concurrence of the Tasmanian Government. So it is not a question of the content of the discussions; it is a question of what conclusions are arrived at on the basis of those discussions and how they are implemented.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 October 1983 I answered a question without notice by Senator Mason on the subject of wind energy. Senator Mason sought supplementary information which has now been provided by the Minister for Science and Technology. I seek leave to incorporate the supplementary information in Hansard .

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Megawatt scale wind generators are being developed in the US, Canada, UK, Denmark, Germany and Sweden and have reached the demonstration stage in some of these countries. In Australia there has been no research as yet on megawatt scale generators, but the Australian Government has not abandoned wind energy research. It is funding a modest program of wind energy research under the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration (NERD&D) Program, which supplements investigations by State Governments aimed at evaluating the prospects for wind power. My colleague the Minister for Resources and Energy has advised that under the NERD&D Program a total of $428,000 has been committed to wind energy research since 1978. Areas of research supported have included site specific wind resource assessments, wind generator technology, the feasibility of integrating wind generators into State electricity grids, and performance monitoring of wind systems for homestead power.
I also refer honourable Senators to Senator Walsh's reply in the Senate on 14 September 1983 to a question from Senator Coates concerning wind energy in Tasmania (Hansard, page 660).

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING CORPORATION: HISTORIC NEWS FILM

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 November Senator Missen asked me a question relating to the historic news film archives of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Further to the answer which I gave I wish to advise the Senate that in giving my answer on that day I was speaking in somewhat broad terms regarding the situation of archival film generally in Australia because I did not quite hear Senator Missen's question, and I am not sure anybody else did either. I am able to add that in regard specifically to archival film held by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation it has two film vaults at its studios at Ripponlea in Victoria. The older vault which was completed in the mid-1950s and which currently holds more than two million feet of black and white film has been disturbed by dampness in recent years. The new vault which was completed in November 1978 has humidity and temperature control and contains all film shot in colour since the mid-1970s. This amounts to over five million feet of film.

QUESTION.PARA: To move the film from the old vault is a time consuming task as all film is cleaned by hand and checked against a catalogue. The ABC advises that there is no evidence to suggest that film has been damaged due to storage conditions in the old vault and it hopes that all films will have been relocated in the new vault by December 1984.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday at Question Time Senator Lewis asked me whether it was a fact that Medicare enrolment forms had been considerably underestimated and that forms were not available at post offices. He also asked me about an alleged Department of Health paper advocating an increase in the health care levy to 4 per cent. I have sought information from the Minister for Health and his Department.

QUESTION.PARA: As to the first part of the question, certainly in post offices the Medicare enrolment forms had run out. This arose from the fact that the Health Insurance Commission asked Australia Post as the experts for an estimate of the number of households in Australia and the number of people in those households. The estimates given by Australia Post were considerably under the real number. In fact some of those forms originally intended for post offices had to be used in the household drop. Extra forms have now been printed and will be available in post offices throughout Australia this week.

As for the second part of the question, it appears that there is no Department of Health paper advocating an increase in the health care levy to 4 per cent. Neither the Minister nor anyone in the Department has ever heard of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record may I correct a statement I made as part of my answer to a supplementary question from Senator Jessop today. It was my understanding that the appropriation for the Government's Yes case advertising, which is now coming from the Advance to the Minister for Finance, would ultimately be attributed to the Department of Special Minister of State. I am now advised that agreement has been reached for it to come from the Attorney- General's Department. I accordingly advise Senator Jessop to pursue the matter further in that Estimates committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented. When I was not in the Senate yesterday Senator Crowley asked a question based on an item in the National Times regarding what I was reported to have said at the Gold Coast recently. I would have thought Senator Crowley would have been a member of the Senate for long enough now to know that one does not believe everything one reads in the papers.
—Do not read newspapers.

—That might be a thought too, Senator Withers. I do not believe there was a representative from the National Times at the Rotary Club function when I was asked a question about women demonstrating at Pine Gap. I inform the Senate that I have never used a strap in my life, and neither has Joh ; not that I have hesitated to use a walloping hand just the same. So I cannot see any reason why it should be suggested that I would tell husbands to use the strap on their wives. However, I did say at that meeting that I felt the actions of some of the women at Pine Gap did reflect little credit on womanhood in general.

SPEECH.PARA: If I may be permitted I will make a few remarks about the comments of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). I think when one becomes a member of the Senate one does need to have a good sense of humour. That has been my experience from time to time. I have listened on many occasions to rude remarks made in the Senate about various people. I feel that the type of remark made by the Attorney-General yesterday, such as 'The picture is that of the Premier shuffling in and out of the family cave', is not very nice from a person in the Attorney-General's position. I feel sure that if the Premier challenged him or some of the other people on the other side of the House to a brisk walk or a game of squash, he would beat them hands down. He would be right out in the lead just as-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator is straying from her personal explanation.

—Thank you. I just want to say, Mr President, in bringing my remarks to a conclusion, that the Premier would be right out in the lead in the same way as he is right out in the lead in Queensland. He showed the people that at the election on 22 October.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The lack of any reliable basis for the Government's restrictive policy on the development of Australia's uranium resources.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had a good number of debates in this chamber and in the other place on the question of Australia's uranium policy and the policy of the present Government. The matter of public importance today is:

SPEECH.PARA: The lack of any reliable basis for the Government's restrictive policy on the development of Australia's uranium resources.

In bringing it forward, the Opposition wishes to highlight a matter which did not receive very much attention and on which we believe there are grounds for concern, namely, the failure of the Government to establish a reliable basis for a decision which has cost Australia very dearly indeed. I do not think I need stress in this debate the widespread dissatisfaction there is about the Government's uranium decisions. That dissatisfaction ranges from the left wing of the Australian Labor Party, as has been readily evidenced by its Victorian Branch over this last week and by other branches, through to would-be miners of uranium, many of whom have committed very substantial funds to the process of exploration, discovery and development.

The sorts of remarks made by Mr Tony Grey at the annual general meeting of Pancontinental Mining Ltd are simply one example of the criticisms which have been made so widely. Mr Grey referred to the dark shadow of confusion and obstructionism descending on the uranium industry which has frustrated our sales and development efforts. In fact, that sort of criticism of the Government's uranium policy reflects the sort of criticism admitted to by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, who has admitted that one can take quite different meanings from the policies laid down by the ALP. Of course, now that some attempt has been made to clarify that and a great deal of harm has been done, there are critics from both left and right.

There is no doubt, as the matter of public importance states, that the policy of the Government is restrictive. It provides that there are to be no new uranium mines apart from Roxby Downs. That means that projects for which the promoters had very great hopes have been aborted in South Australia, Western Australia, the Northern Territory and Queensland. The decision is selective and is seen to be unfair all around Australia, but particularly by those States which have been excluded from the substantial development prospects by this very partial decision.

It is important to note that the policy is not based on concern about nuclear weapons or waste disposal. Whatever honest concerns might be expressed about those areas and whatever action might be taken very properly by government in policing these areas, it cannot be said that one can justify being in the export market to the extent of, say, 7,000 or 8,000 tonnes per year. It cannot be said that that is in some way different, as far as nuclear proliferation or safe waste disposal is concerned, from being in the export market to the extent of another 5,000, 6,000 or 7,000 tonnes. It is quite clear that we do not have a decision on principle. We have a decision which is based far more on political trade-offs. The Government has committed itself to remaining in the uranium market to a significant extent, probably to the extent of some 6,000 to 7,000 tonnes per year. It could be higher if the Energy Resources of Australia Ltd mine at Ranger is allowed to expand to its full capacity. But we have no moral or strategic argument from the Government to justify the partial decision which it has taken. Instead, we have an economic justification which has been trotted out by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) on numerous occasions. He has tried to dress up in economic clothes what is really a multilevel political trade-off. I will not refer to all the times that Senator Walsh has made this argument in justification of the Government's decision, but I will refer to a few. In the Senate on 8 November, he said:

The reason for that-not the entire reason, but the chief reason-is that, in the judgment of the Government, for the next 15 years and possibly to the end of this century, existing mines plus Roxby Downs, if it proceeds, will fill the room which is likely to be available in the world market place for uranium delivered from Australia.
In New York just a few days ago he said:

The accuracy of demand projections into the 1990s for yellowcake is dependent on the accuracy of assumptions made about consumption and stock accummulation or run down. Both are subject to wide margins of potential error.
I heartily agree with that comment. He went on to say:
The Government's judgment was that the likely commercial demand for Australian yellowcake up to the late 1990s could be supplied from the two existing mines and Roxby Downs.

Again in the Senate on 8 November, in another passage, he made that position quite clear. In the debate at the Committee stage on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) on 9 November we find the justification on which the Government has based its whole policy, namely, that once Roxby Downs is approved and allowed to go ahead we will have the ability to fill completely any demand that there might be for Australian uranium and that one cannot, therefore, admit any other miners into the field. In response to a question from Senator Sir John Carrick, Senator Walsh tried to set down on what basis the Government had made this judgment. He said:

The Government has made a judgment on evidence provided from a variety of sources, importantly from the interdepartmental committee report on the likely commercial global demand for yellowcake from Australian sources. The Government has taken account of an admission-if that appears to be a loaded term I shall use another one-or a statement by Mr Grey of all people, the Chairman of Pancontinental Mining Ltd, who acknowledged only last month that for the first time in very many years we were approaching a situation in which the production of yellowcake was likely to come to balance with consumption . . .
Senator Walsh went on to say:

We have also taken account of a statement by Mr Townsend of the Central Electricity Generating Board of the United Kingdom that not until 1995 would the product of a new mine or new mines be required on the world market.

They are the bases on which the Government has made this critically important assessment that it can permit only Roxby Downs and the sales from existing producers. That is a very significant decision which has resulted, as I said earlier, in the effective aborting of a whole range of other projects on which people have spent substantial amounts of capital. In one case up to $100m was spent on a single project, a project with which the company is not now allowed to proceed. The Opposition believes-for that reason it brings forward this matter of public importance-that the fundamental central point which has been made over and again by Senator Walsh is not sound and is not a sound basis on which such an important decision should be taken.

A little later in the debate I will make available to the Senate-they are too bulky to be incorporated in Hansard-a couple of documents which will help to explain the Opposition's scepticism about the views which have been put forward by the Government to justify its decision. In fact, we believe that Senator Walsh has quoted people out of context and has put very doubtful interpretations on the material to which I have referred in the last few minutes. What Senator Walsh did not say when he referred to Mr Grey's comments was that those comments can also be read to say that the world is moving towards a situation where consumption will be more than production, where stockpiles will fall and where there will be need for more new contracts and, therefore, new mines. Mr Grey's company has supported the judgment that there is room in the market for more new mines with a planned $500m investment at Jabiluka.

The second person who has prayed in aid, Mr Michael Townsend, is a person whose total remarks again cast a rather different light on the situation. The statement which Senator Walsh quoted came from a paper entitled 'Some Aspects of the Outlook for Uranium Supply and Demand' which was presented by Mr Townsend at the Eighth Annual Symposium of the Uranium Institute in London on 24-26 August this year. Like Mr Grey, Mr Townsend has been selectively quoted or rather misquoted by Senator Walsh. What Mr Townsend said was not that new mines would not be required until 1985, but that under some assumptions new mines might be needed by 1988-89, but that under other assumptions the most likely scenario was that they would be required by 1983 and that under the assumption that there is a greater redistribution of stocks between users, some overproduction from existing mines, some further cancellations and delays at power stations, new mines might not be needed until 1995. In fact, if honourable senators examine the graphs attached to Mr Townsend's paper, the most probable scenario paints a picture not unlike a recent study which has been prepared as an official company document for internal use by a leading West German company involved in the uranium fuel cycle, namely, that the demand for new mines is likely to arise in the late 1980s or early 1990s.

The third document on which Senator Walsh and the Government have based their views is the interdepartmental report which Senator Walsh has mentioned in debate in this chamber. He has refused to produce that report; he is not prepared to make it available to the Australian public who have paid for its production, and of course he has hindered the ability of both the public and the Opposition to make a judgment on the assessment which the Government has made about the future uranium market. Because of that failure of Senator Walsh to publish the document, my office and I have made a number of checks and have found that in fact there is a series of quite different projections for world demand for uranium. They show widely differing results, and some show a reasonably optimistic picture while others are pessimistic. The projection made by the West German company involved in the nuclear fuel cycle-to which I have referred-suggests that there will be no unfilled world demand for uranium until 1988 but from there on it will grow quickly. While Mr Townsend's paper is a little more pessimistic, he does suggest that the most probably situation is that new mines will be needed by 1993. I seek leave to table the two papers to which I have referred.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The major difference between the papers is in their assumptions about stockholdings. Mr Townsend's paper assumes that less stocks will be required as strategic reserves, especially in the United States than the other paper. The rationale behind the use of the higher stock figure in the United States than in the German paper is that until recently the United States was self-sufficient in uranium supplies. Now it is only 50 to 60 per cent self-sufficient and consequently will require larger stockpiles than previously for strategic purposes. It may be that it requires the three to three and a half years forward supply that the Japanese generally require and more than the European countries, which currently require about two years forward supply. That change in the United States situation is very important because the United States currently accounts for some 35 per cent of the total free world use of uranium. So quite clearly, in the view of the Opposition and I think in the view of any impartial observers, the authorities quoted by Senator Walsh simply do not back up the point which he has tried to establish-namely, that there is room in Australia for only one new mine if Roxby Downs is allowed to go ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the figures produced in the German paper which I have tabled. Those figures were prepared for the company to make its own investment decisions. The unfilled demand-that is, that part of future use of uranium which is not covered by existing contracts-shows that adjustments to stockpiles will mean that there will be no more uranium needed, apart from what is already contracted for, until 1988; that is, all needs can be met from stockpiles. In 1988, unfilled world demand will be 12,300 tonnes and this rises rapidly to 21,100 tonnes in 1989, 23 ,600 tonnes in 1990 and up to 40,700 tonnes in 1995 and 56,000 by the year 2000. We can say that at least the demand figures up to 1992-93 will be reasonably accurate as they represent known quantities. We know the reactors in operation and we know those that are scheduled to be completed by that time. Of course there may be some slippage but there again there may be greater economic growth requiring more electricity and more uranium and so on. Although I stress that there are real uncertainties in all of these estimates, we do not know how much demand will be met from stocks and we do not know the validity of some of the assumptions about the sort of stocks people will want to keep. What we do know is that people who are making decisions based on their assessment of the market are making assessments which are totally different from the assessments being put forward by Senator Walsh as justification for the Government's decision.

Part of the problem for Australia is that one of the variables is Australia's own reputation as a supplier. We have reached the sorry stage where countries like Gabon and Niger are seen by the European market as being more reliable than Australia because no matter what sort of government those places have, they will continue to supply uranium. Australia stands alone among suppliers as having a bad reputation in that regard. Estimating what will be available as a market for Australia is difficult because if we had a better reputation it may well be that we could supply up to a third of the world market. The advice which I am able to get from the industry suggests that we may be able to get 25 per cent, given our current stance, but in fact we could get as little as 20 per cent. Clearly, the amount of the world market that we can command will affect the amount of uranium which can be sold by Australia. The Government is in the business, of course, of making, in effect, self-fulfilling prophecies. If it imposes restrictive provisions then of course Australia will take a smaller share of the market because it will be excluded from seeking the sales which would give it a larger share. I have had a table prepared which shows the figures from the study I have tabled in its complete form. It shows the estimated total demand for uranium which is not yet covered by contract and what Australia would provide if it provided 20 per cent of the market, 25 per cent of the market or a third of the market, which I think is the realistic upper limit. I seek leave to incorporate that table in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
AUSTRALIA'S SHARE OF UNFILLED DEMAND FOR URANIUM
('000 tonnes U)
(WOCA: World outside centrally planned economic area).

TALK.START.PARA: —That table shows quite clearly that very different scenarios are possible from the view which has been put forward by the Government, that one might look to as little as another 3,000 tonnes or so on the Australian market. It shows, for example, the possibility that in 1990, with as little as 20 per cent of the uncommitted world market, we could be selling another 4,700 tonnes of uranium. At the high end of the estimate we could be up close to 8,000 additional tonnes per year. By the time we get to 1995, at the low end of the scale we have the possibility of over 8,000 additional tonnes per year and, at the high end, over 13,000 tonnes per year. By the year 2000, at the low end of the scale the amount will be perhaps over 11,000 tonnes per year and at the high end, over 18,000 tonnes per year.

SPEECH.PARA: The concern of the Opposition is that very variable forecasts are available. There are differences among the experts but this Government has chosen to justify its policy on the basis of a quite restrictive view of Australia's possibilities in the market and to dress up its decision as being justified by that sort of certainty. I believe that even the limited material I have been able to make available in this short speech indicates that that is a very dangerous assumption for the Government to have made. The fact is that there is no such thing as our share of the world market. There is no way that anyone can calculate with precision what Australia's share of some future market will be. What our share will be in actuality will depend at least in part on the way we go about seeking to supply the market, how our relative costs compare, what our reputation is as a supplier-it is a very bad reputation now, due to Government decisions and because of political interference-and it will depend of course on the presence of Australian companies in the market and on their ability to sell. The Opposition wants to stress the importance of our continued presence in the market, a factor that the Government does not appear to understand. That factor is highlighted in a statement made by the now disbanded Uranium Advisory Council in the report that the Government tabled yesterday. That report states:

Whether new projects obtain contracts to underwrite developments is likely to depend mainly on the operators being able to maintain a market presence over the coming years, and the perception by purchasers as to the reliability of Australia as a source of supply.

The Government, through its actions, is trying to destroy whatever chance we may have to become a major supplier in the uranium market and to make the uranium industry a major source of wealth for the country. I believe the decisions taken by the Government are narrow and based on political exigencies, on political prejudice and bias. They are not in the national interest and the Government has sought to base its policies on a premise which I do not believe it is capable of establishing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, what Senator Chaney said in his last remarks is not correct. The Government has not sought to base its decisions in relation to uranium mining on a set of very confused predictions about the state of the market into the future. Certainly the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, and others have said that that is a relevant factor which the Government had to take into account but it has not been the basis for decisions which have been made by the Government. At a later stage I will mention that basis because Senator Chaney specifically raised that question in the course of his remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: The Uranium Advisory Council, in its last annual report-the members of that Council were, of course, appointed by the previous Government-had this to say:
. . . there may be disagreement about the likely extent of the market for uranium.

I do not think Senator Chaney retreats from that proposition at all. In fact, the burden of much of his speech was to point out that there will be disagreement about the likely state of the market, particularly beyond the year 1990. The simple point I want to make at the beginning of my remarks is that forecasting future demand of uranium for nuclear electricity generation is a very hazardous enterprise and that statement is borne out by what happened during the 1970s.

The projection of future demand depends on a wide range of factors to which I wish to refer. First of all, it depends on the future levels of overall economic activity. It depends upon the share which electricity has in total energy consumption. It depends on the share of nuclear electricity within total electricity consumption. It depends particularly on a capital intensive industry such as the nuclear power industry. It depends very much on the future levels of interest rates. It depends on the future prices for uranium relative to prices for other energy fuels. It depends on the present and future levels of commercial uranium inventories and national stockpiles. It depends on technical matters such as the future optimal tails assay levels in the uranium enrichment process. It also depends on nuclear regulatory requirements and future restriction lead times. It depends on future technological developments affecting reactor burn-up rates which also affect the quantity of uranium feed stock requirements.

Therefore, I do not think there would be any disagreement between the parties that many variables are involved in trying to estimate or forecast the future demand for uranium. It is not surprising, given the number of variables involved , that the Government has received conflicting advice from various sources as to future levels of demand for uranium. I am grateful that Senator Chaney tabled or had incorporated in Hansard various documents which provide yet a further assessment, I gather, of future demand prepared by various entities with a particular interest in the matter.

As I said at the beginning, the Uranium Advisory Council summarised in the passage I quoted the likely disagreement about the extent of the market for uranium in the future. I said that in those circumstances the Government had received conflicting advice. I can give some examples of that. The Government has received advice concerning the future levels of uncommitted demand for uranium, that is demand not already committed under existing long term contracts . It has been suggested that cumulative uncommitted demand for the non-communist countries for the next ten years could be of the order of 100,000 to 112,000 short tonnes with the bulk of this demand occurring towards the end of the decade. But even if one-third as distinct from the 25 per cent projection of which Senator Chaney spoke, were to be directed to Australia it would clearly be insufficient to support all of the Australian projects that have been proposed to be developed in the 1980s. That is not just a judgment of this Government; it is a judgment shared by the Australian uranium industry and overseas nuclear analysts. The Opposition seems to be saying, I suppose, that in respect of uranium mining it is advisable as a matter of resource allocation to let the market sort it out and let 100 flowers bloom.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least half a dozen.

—'At least half a dozen' says Senator Chaney. I think that is a very pertinent interjection because the estimates about how many flowers should be allowed to bloom are about as ad hoc as the estimates about likely future demand. I am simply making the point that it is a judgment of the Government and , as I said, of the industry and overseas analysts that even if one-third of world demand were directed to Australia, the market would not support all the projects which have been talked about.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney said a lot about uncertainty which has been generated in the market by the actions of the Government. Let me say one thing quite clearly right at the beginning: The International Atomic Energy Agency and other regulatory bodies have expressed a concern that Australia remain in the market within their knowledge, within the confines of the policy which the Labor Party enunciated prior to the election and within the knowledge that the industry will not be allowed to develop in the same way as it has in the past. While there is a lot of talk about uncertainty in the market-certainly one can understand that talk coming from Mr Tony Grey of Pancontinental Mining Ltd-I think references to other comments about uncertainty created by the Government's policy have to be a little more substantiated than they were by Senator Chaney.

I said that if one-third of world demand were directed to Australia the market would still not be sufficient to support all the Australian projects that have been proposed in the 1980s. I think there is an important qualitative aspect to this, namely that the prices and other terms and conditions on which Australian uranium should be sold have to be considered. If all uranium projects were given the go-ahead, the ensuing overproduction would depress prices and prejudice market stability leading to lower levels of returns from, amongst others, the existing mines at Ranger and Nabarlek and the projected mine at Roxby Downs. This would be so notwithstanding the fact that there is bipartisan support for the maintenance of some sort of uranium floor price policy. It has been the long standing practice of governments not to disclose details of the ways in which that policy is applied at the commercial level and this practice will continue under the present Government. Senator Walsh, in answer to questions in this place, has made it quite clear that he will continue that policy. Notwithstanding that policy, however, the chances of a recovery in market prices to levels exceeding floor price levels would be impeded if the Opposition's preferred course of unrestricted development of uranium mining were to be adopted.

This is one of a series of, I suppose, a baker's dozen matters of public importance that have been brought forward in the last three months by the Opposition in this place in relation to uranium mining. I can understand the basis on which the earlier matters of public importance were brought forward in the Senate. I think an objective observer would be pardoned for thinking that there was some confusion about the Government's uranium policy because it was a subject of long discussion within the Labor Party, within the Government and in the public arena. Following the announcement by the Government of its decsion on 7 November, the policy is clear. It has been articulated in answers to questions in the Senate and in the course of discussion in the Senate. The policy, firstly , is simply that if a commercial decision is made to proceed with the development of the Roxby Downs project the Government will permit that development to go ahead subject to the safeguard requirements which apply generally to uranium at the time of exports from that mine and exports from Australia generally. With the exception of Roxby Downs, if it is commercially feasible, the Government will not permit the development of any new mines.

Secondly, an inquiry is to be conducted by the Australian Science and Technology Council under the direction of its Chairman into Australia's role in the nuclear fuel cycle. The Council is to report to the Government no later than mid-May of 1984. Some of the matters which that inquiry has to examine will include Australia's nuclear safeguard arrangements, the opportunities for Australia through the conditions of its involvement in the nuclear fuel cycle further to advance the cause of nuclear non-proliferation, the question of the adequacy of existing technology for the handling and disposal of waste products by consuming countries, and so on. Of course, Senator Chaney will say that the Government's policy is being dictated by political considerations. Surprise, surprise! I think everybody who spends time in this chamber and earns a living as a senator would recognise very quickly that the Government has to take a number of political considerations into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —But Walsh says the main reason is the limit on the market.

—Senator Chaney is interjecting to say that Senator Walsh says that the main reason is the state of the market. With respect, I do not think that that is correct. A number of reasons is given for the policy.
—He calls it the chief reason.
—Senator Walsh may have said that.
—Many times, but I refer to Hansard, page 2250, of 8 November 1983.

—I understand that Senator Walsh may have said that on a number of occasions, but I am putting to Senator Chaney, who is interrupting, and to anyone else who is listening, that everybody in this place is aware that the Government decision was dictated by a number of political considerations. Senator Walsh in answer to questions has said that the market question is a chief consideration.
—'The'.

—That may be so. I think it is very important that the market situation be taken into account. As has been said on previous occasions and by me in the last few minutes, the Government received advice about the projected situation of the market and, of course, that was taken into account. I was going on to say that the matters I just mentioned in relation to the type of inquiry which is to be conducted by ASTEC are certainly political. The Government does not retreat from that fact. They involve political decisions about the circumstances in which the nuclear industry should develop and the circumstances under which the Australian Government and Australian industry should be involved in the nuclear industry. There is no retreat from the fact that they are matters involving political considerations. I was enumerating the major points of policy which were announced on 7 November because I think if they have not been made clear by now, they ought to be.

SPEECH.PARA: The third point I was coming to was that all future exports of Australian uranium will be subject to stringent supply conditions which will be determined by the Government following the inquiry to which I referred. Fourthly, a permanent commission will be established to examine on an ongoing basis the full range of issues relating to the nuclear fuel cycle, and that commission will report regularly to the Government. Fifthly, no new contracts will be approved from existing mines until after the inquiry, with the exception of the two contracts, which have been the subject of some discussion, already negotiated for the supply from the Ranger mine to the United States utilities. The conditions attached to exports under these contracts will be determined after the inquiry. Sixthly the existing suspension of uranium exports to France will be further considered in the light of the report of the inquiry or on any progress being made towards the cessation of the French nuclear testing in the Pacific. With regard to other aspects of the policy, I will just add that the Government has decided that it does not wish to facilitate or be otherwise involved with the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia's study into the feasibility of establishing those operations in this country. The decision to abolish the Uranium Advisory Council was taken some time ago and was announced at that time.

I said that the Opposition's attitude is that there should be much greater freedom for anybody wishing to develop uranium mines in this country. I said earlier that neither on nuclear industry grounds nor on economic grounds does the Government agree with the view which has been expressed by the Opposition. It is that sort of attitude which has got this country into tremendous economic difficulties in a variety of industries over the last 20 or 30 years. It is the sort of attitude which should be challenged in relation to this matter and to developments in any other industry in the 1980s when Australia has to have a much more rational look at resource allocation issues than it has in the past.

The Opposition asserts that the market for uranium should be exploited by anyone wishing to have a go; we do not agree with that. Not only do we not agree with that for the reasons which I have enunciated but also do we not agree with that for some of the reasons, which were accepted by the previous Government, in relation to the ownership of particular companies and their commitment to acquiring the required level of Australian ownership. As I said, even if one were to accept the argument of the Opposition that anybody should be able to participate in this industry-and the Government does not-it is the Government's view-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the Opposition's view, and you well know it.
—Senator Chaney says that it is not the Opposition's view. I am not clear as to what the Opposition's view is, if that is not its view. Opposition senators have been asking questions.
—No one suggested that foreign investment rules do not apply.
—I do not know. For example, there have been a number of questions in the Senate from Opposition senators about the Ben Lomond mine.
—That is subject to foreign ownership requirements.

—All of these questions have been asked on the basis: 'Why does the government not allow that mine to go ahead?' None of those questions has been directed on the basis that the Opposition suggests that it has the view that that mine should not go ahead. They have all been put on the assumption that the Government was doing something wrong in not letting it go ahead. I was making the point that it is the Government's view that there would not be a market for the uranium mined if the Opposition's apparent policy were followed. I stress that that view must be seen in the light of the Government's decision in relation to Roxby Downs. I make the point that in the view of this Government , to deny the opportunity for Roxby to go ahead, would be to prevent the establishment of a major project capable of producing large quantities of other minerals as well as uranium. In addition, in relation to additional mines it is the preferred choice simply because of the employment implications and the implications for the State of South Australia, which are very important. Those are the Government's views on the topic. We are grateful to Senator Chaney for making available a further set of projections for the uranium market in the late 1980s and beyond. We think that the general sentiments expressed by the Opposition should be rejected. But it is all part of an ongoing and important debate about the future of this industry and we do not in any sense suggest that it should not take place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance that the Senate is now debating is in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The lack of any reliable basis for the Government's restrictive policy on the development of Australia's uranium resources.

In speaking on this matter, I agree with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) that it is a continuing debate. It is a very necessary one when one sees the manipulation of uranium development policy which is taking place in Australia now. It is the responsibility of the Opposition in the Senate to continue to bring this debate before this chamber and to support those outside the Australian Parliament who are endeavouring to have their views put forward.

No matter where one looks nowadays one finds the mining industry which is endeavouring to put over its point of view and the Aboriginal people who feel that they have been wronged. The people of Australia as a whole are very concerned at what one can only describe as the antics-call it political judgment , political manoeuvring, whatever one wishes-which are taking place within the Australian Labor Party now. I refer to the battle between the left and the moderates as to what will be the future of the uranium industry in Australia. Whatever the result, the Government and the fragments of the various groups within the Goverment can be assured of one thing: The stance they have taken towards the development of uranium will certainly not go away. The question of uranium development will be like the albatross; it will be around their neck forever.

Senator Button gave the reasons why the Government made the decision that uranium mines should not be developed. One should point out once again that there are differing views within the Government. In the Senate on 8 November the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) spoke of the reason why Roxby Downs had been allowed to proceed. Senator Walsh said:

The reason for that-not the entire reason, but the chief reason-is that, in the judgment of the Government, for the next 15 years and possibly to the end of the century, existing mines plus Roxby Downs, if it proceeds, will fill the room which is likely to be available in the world market place for uranium delivered from Australia.
Senator Chaney asked:
That is the chief reason?
Senator Walsh said:
That is the chief reason.

I suggest that quote from Hansard is quite contrary to what Senator Button has said in the debate today. Perhaps this point has not been put: The bureaucrat and the politician are making decisions on behalf of the uranium industry as to what its future will be. One has only to review the situation over the last few years to see the immense amount of work that has been done by way of exploration and the amount of money that has been invested. For example, Pancontinental Mining Ltd has invested $50m-odd and Denison Mines $100m. Vast amounts of money have been invested. Surely the decision as to the viability of its markets should be determined by the people who invest the money. Do honourable senators imagine that those companies would have invested $150m plus, with many hundreds of millions of dollars yet to be invested, before a mine was ready to sell its product if they did not believe the project was viable? Do honourable senators think these amounts would have been invested so haphazardly if the companies did not think they would have the market for their produce? What rot. The mining industry is a very capable industry. Of course, it has to be when so much money is involved. If Australia is prepared to invest the amount of moneys that it has to date and will in the future, one must have the assurance and must accept the assurance that there are markets. Therefore, why do the Government and the bureaucrats not allow the mining of uranium to continue and let the market itself find the level?

One was quite taken with the arguments put forward in the last few days. Of course, the name Tony Grey comes to the fore to quite a degree. Tony Grey is the Managing Director and Chairman of Directors of Pancontinental. Surely his knowledge and his ability must shine forward much more than that of the bureaucrat or the politician. Is he not the man who should know all about it? Is he not the man who has been prepared to put these millions of dollars forward to allow Jabiluka to proceed? Of course, the viewpoint has been lost.

Let us look at the argument of the Australian Labor Party regarding the Kakadu National Park project. That project has been planned for a long time, but it has been known also for a very long time that this area is highly prospective yet undeveloped. Recently the area has been subject to radiometric surveys which have reinforced the belief that the area is extraordinarily rich in a variety of minerals. The area is rich not only in uranium but also in a variety of minerals . A variety of minerals means copper, gold and others. I understand that some 250 radiometric anomalies have been found, many of which could lead to the development of important mines which could make a major contribution to the economy. Yet, despite the necessity to have a national stocktake of the minerals which Australia will have for its future use, it is the intention of the Government to lock in uranium forever.

This decision has been made for a political reason. It is a political judgment. That decision has been made as a result of the argument, the fight, taking place within the Labor Party.
