It is not an argument in the Australian arena. The argument is within the Labor Party. It is an argument between the Left and the moderates. The Left wishes to close down uranium mining and development forever. Roxby will not be completed in time to take up the shortfall which will occur at the end of the century.

TALK.START.PARA: —Century or decade?

—At the end of the decade. Of course, it will continue to the end of the century. Jabiluka and Koongara would be able to meet this demand. At the end of 1982 there were some 294 nuclear power stations in operation around the world and another 215 plants under construction. The Chairman and Managing Director of Western Mining Corporation Ltd, Sir Arvi Parbo, has said that by 1995 more than 25 per cent of all electricity will be generated from uranium. The General Manager of the Uranium Information Centre has stated that the United States of America needs an estimated 200,000 tonnes of uranium for use by the end of the century. None of this has yet been covered by contracts. The estimate is based on existing nuclear reactors only and does not include supplies needed by new reactors. So Australia's failure to supply will not stop nuclear power from being used. Already two other major uranium suppliers, South Africa and Canada, as the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) has mentioned, have snatched up contracts that were previously being negotiated by Australian companies. The pity of this indecision, this instability of the Australian Government, is these contracts have been snatched away.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, I would suggest that uranium in the ground, as the Australian Government would wish to see it forever, will ultimately be a risk to Australian security. There will be a time-the decade, the year, will come-when world energy supplies will dwindle. Perhaps people do not realise the vast resources of energy that have been locked away by the Australian Government. I refer particularly to the uranium in what is referred to as the uranium province in the Northern Territory-the Jabiluka, Koongarra and other deposits. The uranium in the ground there is estimated to far exceed the amount of energy in oil that is now in the Arab states. Someone, perhaps, can give some picture of the incredible amount of energy that is being locked away there. Eventually, when energy becomes scarce in the world-one day it will-countries that have no energy will look hungrily towards our vast uranium reserves. Who will we in Australia be to say, just because a government says that uranium will not be developed, that if it is not developed by us it will not be developed by somebody else?

In 1982-83, Australian uranium exports were worth $354m, putting uranium in fifth place among our mineral product exports. Pancontinental Mining Ltd Chairman, Tony Grey, predicts that the Northern Territory, which I represent, will lose about $230m per year in export revenues with the loss of Jabiluka alone. Northern Territory Government documents show that if all current and proposed mines in the Territory-that is, Ranger, Nabarlek, Jabiluka and Koongarra-are allowed to continue, conservatively about $9,000m will come into Australia by the year 2000 and $1,600m of that will stay in the Territory. This would be helpful for a Territory that is now emerging as a State. Senator Walsh, by the way, confirmed these figures in an answer to a question which I asked on 8 November. The figures also show, that if the proposed mines of Jabiluka and Koongarra are not allowed to proceed, the loss to Australia will be around $6, 300m and the loss to the Territory will be $1,300m.

I have already referred to the vast amount of investment that has taken place in the Northern Territory. Surely the Australian Government is morally bound to allow these developments to take place when one sees the hundreds of millions of dollars that have been invested, not only by the big investors, but also by many small investors in Australia who are looking for a return through the mining of Australian uranium.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the non-mining.

—There is no return to Australia from non-mining, but there will be a return to the Australian investor when once again the Opposition goes back into government. It will be only a short while before the factions within the Government cause the Labor Government's downfall. The internal wrangles that are already taking place within the Labor Party over the development of uranium will, in the near future, cause the defeat of the Labor Party.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance raised by the Liberal Party which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The lack of any reliable basis for the Government's restrictive policy on the development of Australia's uranium resources.

The Australian Democrats passionately believe that there is no reliable basis for any uranium mining in Australia at any time for any purpose. We are the only political party in Australia now to hold that view. We are very proud to be in that situation. Those of us who argue against uranium mining do so, not on the basis of the left or right of politics, but on moral grounds. We should not sell something simply because if we do not someone else will sell it. That argument could well be used to advocate the peddling of heroin. We should not sell something simply because it might be good for the economy. Slavery was often defended on those very grounds. We should not trade in a commodity that threatens those who work with it. That can risk the health of the innocents who are unknowingly surrounded by it. I do not want to be theatrically demonstrative when I use the phrase, but I use it advisedly: nor should we sell the foundation stones of Armageddon. I say that for his reason: Perhaps the greatest mind of our century, Arthur Koestler, before he died, said:

Because man's emotional and logical responses have not kept pace with the rate of technological developments he has caused, the self-induced extinction of life on this planet is now approaching a statistical certainty.

They are chilling words. The reason he said that we were approaching our self- induced extinction was one mineral, uranium. As we talk today and debate the mining of Australia's uranium I remind the Senate that there are 50,000 nuclear weapons on this planet ready to be fired. That is enough to destroy the world and everything in it in about six days many times over. Every single one of those weapons came from the subject of today's debate, uranium.

The economic myth that nuclear energy is cheap can be dismissed. Uranium produces electricity at about seven times the cost of oil. So it is now a myth to say that the world needs electricity from uranium. On that basis the cost of nuclear power is causing bankruptcy in wealthy nations, even the United States of America. How then will it be the answer to the energy needs of the impoverished Third World, whose countries are already saddled with massive foreign debts? There is no reliable basis for the Government's pro-uranium policy and there is no basis for mining any uranium. I would be grateful if, in one of these debates that occur in this place, normally at the instigation of the Liberal Party, someone would tell me what is the present difference between the Liberal Party's policy on the mining of uranium and the Australian Labor Party policy on the mining of uranium. I would be pleased if someone would point that out.

This Government's greatest error, other than breaking its election promise, is its ignorance of the links that exists between the nuclear industry and nuclear weapons. Only a blind fool would deny the greatest need the world has today is for disarmament. The chilling words which we have read in the newspapers over the last two weeks indicate a significant acceleration in the nuclear arms race. Why we need more weapons of mass destruction and therefore more uranium is a complete mystery to rational human beings. As we stand here debating this matter in this deserted chamber this afternoon-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am here.

—I wonder whether the Democrats and the Liberals were wrong in opposing the Government's Bill, which the National Party of Australia supported, for more senators, because the whole afternoon while we have been debating an issue upon which the very future of the human race depends, there have been about five or six senators here. Maybe we need more senators to be able to get a few more into the chamber for these sorts of debates. As we stand debating this matter, I repeat in this virtually deserted chamber this afternoon, the United States has 12,000 warheads pointing at the Soviet Union and its satellites. The Soviets have 8,000 warheads pointed at the United States of America and its allies.
—And us.

—And us, indeed-or at least one of them at us. They have such accuracy as would land some of them within 100 feet of a target after travelling thousands of miles. The total destructive power of this arsenal is equivalent to one million Hiroshima bombs. My mind finds it very difficult to comprehend what we, the human race, have created with uranium. But I repeat that the total destructive power of the 50,000 bombs in existence now-honourable senators should remember that we are building more-is equivalent to one million Hiroshima sized bombs. At Hiroshima 130,000 people were killed. That means that the destructive power that we now have in existence could kill 130 billion human beings. There are four billion people in the world. We now have the destructive power to kill each human being some 30 times over.

SPEECH.PARA: An average-sized nuclear bomb is one megaton. That is 80 times the size of the Hiroshima bomb but the fact I am about to cite is more mind boggling and more incomprehensible than any: Some of the bombs are 50 megatons. I ask the Senate and those listening to try to imagine and to add up in their minds the total destructive power of every bomb released during the six years of World War II. Add to that the killing power, the maiming power, the destructive power of every shell from every gun that was fired in the six years to get the total of the destructive power. One 50-megaton bomb is more powerful than 20 times that total . Such a bomb would fit under the dining table of the normal suburban home.

Despite these mindboggling facts the United States has now started to deploy 572 Cruise and Pershing 2 missiles in Europe. I say with great respect that these weapons are not needed in response to the Soviet's SS-20 missiles. Those who say that they are should be aware that without the cruise and Pershing missiles the United States and the powers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation already have 6,000 nuclear warheads to match those of the Soviets, including the SS-20s. So the score now is even. Both powers, the Soviets and the United States, have 6,000 each in Europe and yet Ronald Reagan and those who support him in this place say: 'Ah, but the Americans and NATO need the cruise and the Pershing to balance the SS-20'. That is a pack of lies. It is not so. The facts that I am quoting are not from the imagination of some dupe of the Kremlin, as some people tend to call me these days. They are from the Centre for Defence Information in Washington, which is hardly a radical left wing body. It is a prestigious think tank run by retired senior American military officers. It recently concluded:
On closer examination, the SS-20 seems more an excuse for the U.S. missiles than a genuine threat.
That was in 'Defense Monitor', volume 12, No. 6, 1983. The deployment of the cruise and Pershing missiles is not only unnecessary but also brings the prospect of nuclear war even closer.

We have now reached a phase where human beings no longer will determine the fate of the world and every human being in it. The day of the hot line is over as soon as these missiles are deployed. With six minutes from launch to hit, there is no time for Andropov to get on a telephone or for Reagan to respond. The computer will fire the buttons on both sides. Already to my knowledge there have been red alerts on the American side at least-only God and the Soviets know how many red alerts there have been on the Soviet side-through computer errors. It is madness for somebody to leave a war game to a computer in Washington. Add to that the possibility of a flock of geese hitting a scanner in Alaska or some other incomprehensible stimuli which put the computer on red alert with three minutes and counting. With a six minute launch to hit there will be no time for human intervention.

The Soviets have made the deployment of the cruise and Pershing missiles an excuse for them to put more of their nuclear bombs in eastern Europe and near the United States. Yet we are spending more. The United States is planning to spend an incredible $450 billion on new nuclear weapons over the next six years. That will add 17,000 more warheads to its already massive stockpile. No doubt the Soviets will match those with new bombs of their own. So the insanity goes on. But we are not playing some game of glorious battles. This insanity endangers the future of all human civilisation. Something needs to be done now to protest to all nations with nuclear weapons that such weapons are unacceptable to human beings and that their numbers must be reduced.

I am not stupid enough to suggest that the United States should unilaterally disarm. That would be crazy. But as I have said in this House, the United States could for example make a unilateral gesture by reducing its stockpile of 30,000 nuclear weapons by, say, 25 per cent. That would radically improve superpower relations. It would be a start or a gesture. Even with the weapons it had left it could destroy every city in the Soviet Union many times over. Australia has a great role to play. We must remember that nuclear weapons could not exist without uranium. The Stockholm International Peace Research Institute-again, a very prestigious world organisation-has recently stated:
The peaceful and military aspects of nuclear energy are intrinsically linked and it is impossible to separate them.

So long as Australia continues to mine uranium we tacitly condone these nuclear stockpiles. The great risk of war posed by the nuclear industry is that it enables some of the world's most unstable nations to develop bomb capability. I will read out some of the crazies that can get bombs from our uranium: Argentina , the Philippines, South Korea, India, Pakistan, Iran, Iraq and others. Most analysts recognise that nuclear war is most likely to result from the escalation of a regional conflict. By supplying Australian uranium to such countries, namely Korea, as the Hawke Government proposes to do, we will provide them with the tools to manifest their fears and to ensure our destruction.

We must end uranium mining immediately. If we Australians forgo some monetary gain in the short term by ending uranium mining immediately, we will enhance our status and we will gain more credibility if our domestic actions are totally in accord with our international concerns. Australia as a small but respected democracy can give the vital lead to all people, no matter which side of the arms race they happen to live on, that we do not want nuclear weapons and that we are prepared to make a sacrifice to demonstrate our resolve. To do nothing about the growing risk of nuclear war is as good as contributing to the risk. No matter how small our effort, to be true to ourselves and to human life in general, we must do all we can. Australia has a great opportunity. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, should not sell us out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects the charge made by the Opposition in today's matter of public importance that our uranium policy lacks a reliable basis in its restrictive character. The fact is that the Australian Labor Party's policy is a sure, reliable and certain one. We take a certain stance in relation to Ranger and Nabarlek, and in relation to Roxby Downs if, in the judgment of those venturing funds into the enterprise, it appears to be commercially viable if allowed to develop and to seek markets. We take a very sure and certain stand in relation to those three mines, two of them existing and one in the course of being set up. We say very definitely and absolutely that all other proposed mining ventures for the development of Australia's uranium resources are not to proceed. So there is a very reliable and certain basis there for the judgment of those who wish to consider investing in Australia's various and varied mineral and energy resources. There is no question or subterfuge there.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition seems to be saying that we ought to adopt its policy on the development of Australia's uranium resources, and, of course, the Australian Democrats have an absolutely different proposal to put to the Australian people. Each of them, in a sense, wants a more absolute stance. The Democrats want, as incorporated in Senator Chipp's Customs (Nuclear Materials and Hardware) Prohibition Bill, introduced two weeks ago, an immediate cessation of imports or exports of uranium or nuclear hardware. The Opposition, the Liberal and the National parties, want us to start from their basis, which is an ideological commitment to the operation of market forces and the exploitation of these resources for commercial profit. The Labor Party attempts to steer a course between the two different propositions put by those parties before the Australian people.

The Democrats' proposal, was rejected two weeks ago by the Senate on the basis that to embargo immediately the exports of the product of the existing mines at Nabarlek and Ranger would be to put in jeopardy, indeed, to destroy the livelihood of many hundreds of Australian workers, not only those associated with the sites but also those in associated transport operations, and it would also have an impact on the Aboriginal communities which have entered into agreements with those mines. Of course, it would also have an impact on the importation of nuclear hardware for Lucas Heights, which has such a vital role to play in the provision, amongst other things, of medical isotopes to the many tens of thousands of Australian who depend on a form of treatment, particularly for cancer.

So for very good reasons we oppose the absolute approach of the Democrats. I am getting irritated by the constant analogy drawn by Senator Chipp between those who promote, to even the most modest extent-'promote' is perhaps too strong a word; I will say those who permit, to the most modest extent-the thought that uranium might find its way into the world's energy fuel cycle and the heroin pushers. We grow opium poppies in my area of Tasmania. It is a legitimate industry. But a choice has to be made between processing those poppies, which are at present in full bloom-many acres and many hills are covered in the light mauve, very large flower of the opium poppy-to alleviate human distress and suffering, and allowing them to find their way into the streets of many of our major cities and, with the dirty needles used by addicts, bring about destruction of human life. There is a choice as to the use of those opium poppies. There is a choice between life and death; enhancing human welfare, and devastating it. We are responsible, as human beings, for making the best possible and most stringent choice to try to ensure that there are sufficient safeguards to let the product of the opium poppy alleviate human distress and suffering and not cause it. The analogy is there, rather than with the heroin pusher, in relation to this whole question.

The Liberal Party and the National Party want us to start from the basis of allowing market forces to determine the issue; commercial profit should be the guiding factor. But even when those parties were in government, I never heard a Federal Minister say that the recommendation of the Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry, that there should be sequential development of mines, was a wrong approach. It has always been acknowledged that to have contemporaneous multiple development of Australia's uranium resources by many entrepreneurs would simply lead to a misallocation of Australia's financial resources, our physical resources, our social infrastructure and the use of our work force. Indeed, it would create the very situation that confronted us, when we came into government earlier this year, in the coal industry. The Japanese were absolutely dominating the situation in regard to bargaining with Australian producers of coal because they had created, very skilfully, a false impression in relation to the estimated market. Many mines had been opened in Australia and, of course, that put the Japanese in the box seat when it came to bargaining with us. But Senator Chaney-and this was echoed by Senator Kilgariff-said, 'If we do not take our share of the world market and get some export income for Australia, the South Africans and the Canadians will'. Indeed, Senator Chaney said in the Estimates debate that the Canadians applauded the Australian Government's cautious attitude because it allowed them into the market. Further, in today's debate, we hear that Niger is a possible model for Australia's attitude to the world market.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Gabon.

—As Senator Sibraa says, following a recent excursion there, Niger is utterly at the mercy of the French Government and is nothing more than an impoverished military dictatorship, maintained largely in order to ensure uranium supplies to France.
—Is it safer for the world to have them in the trade?

—No. We take the attitude that neither an absolute embargo nor the unhampered, unimpeded flow of market forces should determine the development of Australia's uranium resources. We say that, in relation to the product of the Ranger and Nabarlek mines, it would be intolerable to create havoc in the existing communities of both Australian workers and Aboriginals by closing down those mines immediately. In relation to the mixed, mineralised deposits at Roxby Downs, whilst it must be conceded that the Australian Labor Party, in identifying and grappling with the issues and values at stake, produced a policy in mid-1982 which is subject to some differing emphases, nevertheless, two elections, State and Federal, were fought in South Australia on the basis of the interpretation that that policy was intended to embrace and permit the development of the Roxby Downs deposit. That conclusion flows in good faith from the wording of the policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The tension is developed by our great concern, as has been very eloquently put by Senator Chipp, that the world should not be brought to the brink of nuclear Armageddon, as he put it. The nuclear holocaust which hovers over the whole of humanity's future history, is something with which we are all deeply concerned. I think that most of us in this chamber would be committed to taking whatever steps are necessary and within Australia's power to reduce the risk. The appointment of an Ambassador for Disarmament, Mr Richard Butler, by Mr Bill Hayden, the Foreign Minister, is a symbol of our good faith in that regard. But it is not only symbolic; it is practical. Richard Butler has been given as his first major task the putting of Australia's case in relation to the reaffirmation of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons in 1985, when it comes up for international review once again. But within that very Treaty-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is at risk.

—It is at risk. But within that Treaty, the tension which is within our policy and our attitude is present. As Senator Chipp will know, Article I states clearly that each nuclear weapon State party to the Treaty undertakes not to transfer any material to a third party which would enable a nuclear explosive device to be devised. On the other hand, Article IV reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing in this Treaty shall be interpreted as affecting the inalienable right of all the Parties to the Treaty to develop research, production and use of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes . . .

That tension is something with which one has to try to come to grips in the real world. The only way to resolve the tension is, as I indicated by analogy with the growing of opium poppies in Tasmania: One has to subject the movement of this energy resource into the world fuel cycle to the most stringent safeguards in order to ensure that the use of this material, once it is received in the recipient countries, is such that it cannot find its way into the manufacture of explosive devices. It is this particular tension which I acknowledge and therefore I have to acknowledge that indeed, while Senator Chaney uses it as a rather miserable adjective, in fact we see the restrictive policy of the Labor Party as really something of a decent and honourable adjective. The fact is that we see our policy as being restrictive in order to secure ends with which the whole of this chamber ought to agree. In fact, the view that we take is such that, when a country indulges in behaviour which leads it to be properly ostracised in relation to that behaviour from the world community, we cut off trade in uranium with that country. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) did exactly that in relation to President Mitterrand, a fellow member of the Socialist International, a person with whom one would normally have the most cordial relationship. The particular shipment due to go to France was suspended. Indeed there will be no resumption of such shipments while France continues its testing in the Pacific. In that we are joined with all those signatories to the South Pacific Forum held here in Canberra under the chairmanship of the Prime Minister in late August, which issued a communique that amongst other things, having acknowledged Australia's role and desire to create a nuclear free zone in the Pacific, stated that it would continue to make the strongest protests and condemnations so long as nuclear testing by France or any other country continued in the South Pacific region. They also reaffirmed their opposition to proposals for the dumping and storage of nuclear waste in the Pacific area.

The Australian Labour Party shares with those people-with all those varied people throughout the Pacific-a different view as to the responsible course which governments should follow in relation to the use of this great natural energy resource. We say that it ought to be for the benefit of humanity. That requires the most stringent safeguards, the most stringent channelling, of that particular resource to a very confined band of recipient countries for very strongly safeguarded use. This leads us to be cautious; it leads us to be restrictive. We believe that that particular approach is one which commends itself to most ordinary Australians, and we believe that it ought to commend itself to this chamber.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Repre- sentatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to provide funds for the major new Participation and Equity Program which will commence in 1984. Programs for schools will be administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission while the TAFE program will be administered by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. The Department of Education and Youth Affairs will exercise a strong co-ordinating role.

Because this Program will be administered by both Commissions the Government has decided to provide the funds separately from the States Grants (Schools Assistance) legislation and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) legislation for which the normal Bills are being introduced today. The Participation and Equity Program is designed to encourage a significant increase in participation by young people in education and training, to provide a useful and fulfilling education, and to encourage the achievement of more equal educational outcomes. The Program is directed towards bringing about wide ranging changes in schools which will enable them to give all students, and especially those from a disadvantaged background, a rewarding, useful education through to the end of secondary schooling. The program will be directed particularly to secondary schools with low retention rates.

The Program will provide support for courses and activities in TAFE colleges which positively enrich and expand the range of options available to youth, particularly for those less academically inclined and those currently unemployed . Courses should meet community needs, individual needs, and the national need for an adequately educated and adaptable skilled work force. Funds will also be available for approved projects conducted by other State authorities, community organizations and other non-institutional bodies.

As announced earlier this program will be funded on a triennial basis and the funds provided will be adjusted retrospectively for relevant cost increases. The amounts in this Bill are at levels reflecting the latest available data for the relevant cost indexes. For 1984, the Bill appropriates grants to the States and the Northern Territory totalling $73.408m. This comprises $40.043m for government schools, $4.523m for non-government schools, $28.188m for TAFE, and $ 654,000 for projects and programs of national significance. The Bill also provides grants of $73.408m p.a. for 1985 and 1986.
Both Commissions have now submitted supplementary reports on the structure and scope of this Program and these will be tabled shortly.

The Participation and Equity Program will be a central part of the overall framework of youth policies that the Government is developing. Its twin objectives of increasing participation in education and of introducing greater equity in our overall provision for young people reflect the Government's basic priorities for meeting the needs of young people. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.

Bill (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

On 18 October 1983 the Report of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission recommending the distibution of funds for 1984 for tertiary education programs funded by the Commonwealth was tabled in the Parliament. This Report responded to the Government's Guidelines for financial assistance for capital and equipment programs for all tertiary education sectors, and recurrent programs for technical and further education institutions.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1981 to provide for the Government's 1984 tertiary education program in the States and the Northern Territory. The distribution of these funds accords with the recommendations of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission in its Volume 4 report.

I would remind Honourable Senators that at a time of economic difficulty and budgetary constraint, it is an indication of the high priority that the Government has given to tertiary education that funds have been increased by 1.5 per cent in real terms for 1984 which is the last year of the current funding triennium.

The 1984 program represents the first and significant step towards greater participation in higher education and towards more equal participation by disadvantaged groups. It provides evidence of the Government's recognition of the vital contribution tertiary education can make to economic and social well- being.

The Bill before the Senate provides for the appropriation of $10.5m to assist universities and colleges of advanced education in meeting expenditure incurred in increasing enrolments in 1984. The Government's immediate objective is to provide for at least an additional 3,000 student places in universities and CAEs in 1984 under this program. The Government will look to institutions for a positive response which will lead to a wider range of opportunities for young people and special efforts to attract those social groups at present under- represented in higher education institutions. The Commission has now submitted its supplementary report providing detailed advice on the implementation of this initiative for 1984 and I will be tabling this report shortly. Because of the time constraints arising from the timetable for the Commission's supplementary report and the Government's legislation program, the Bill enables the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs to distribute the special allocation between institutions.
Funds for the Government's other major initiative, the Participation and Equity Program, will be provided under a separate Bill being introduced for this purpose.

In accordance with the Government's policy of encouraging equal opportunity in education for both male and female students, the Bill provides that, as far as practicable, the benefits and opportunities created by Commonwealth expenditure should be equally available to male and female students. The condition does not apply in relation to payments to student residences or affiliated colleges, to single-sex non-government business colleges or to special assistance provided to students of one sex in order to ensure they have equal opportunities with people of the other sex.

The Bill currently before the Senate includes $173.3m for capital grants, of which $46m is for universities and colleges of advanced education. This includes $3.8m in 1984 for the Graduate School of Management at the University of Melbourne. $64.1m is appropriated for the 1984 equipment program for universities and colleges and $11.1m for TAFE equipment. 1984 recurrent grants for TAFE contained in this Bill amount to $112.6m. Grants for 1984 programs in the Bill are expressed in price levels reflecting the latest available data for the relevant cost indexes. These amounts will be adjusted retrospectively for further cost increases in subsequent amending legislation, in accordance with the Government's announced policy for the re-introduction of retrospective cost supplementation.

Funds for Commonwealth institutions (that is, the Australian National University, Canberra College of Advanced Education and the Australian Maritime College) are not appropriated in this Bill. They are included in annual appropriations for the Commonwealth Department of Education and Youth Affairs.

In line with the Government's policy on enforced amalgamations, it has already been announced that the University of Newcastle, Newcastle College of Advanced Education, the University of New England and the Armidale College of Advanced Education will continue as separate institutions rather than be forced into the amalgamations envisaged by the previous Government. These institutions will be expected however, to plan co-operatively for increased participation based upon the joint use of available resources, including the technical and further education facilities in their regions. This Bill amends the Principal Act to permit funds to be provided directly for each of these institutions and, at the same time, removes the coercive sections of the Act for all amalgamations.
Orange Agricultural College also will be funded from 1984 in its own right, as recently announced.

Consistent with the Government's concern for the educational needs of those sections of the community who have had limited access to tertiary education, capital funds have been provided for a new science/engineering building at Wollongong University, the commencement of Stage 1 of the Campbelltown campus of the Macarthur Institute of High Education, a new multi-purpose academic building at the Footscray Institute of Technology and a resources centre and teaching facilities at Carseldine campus of the Brisbane College of Advanced Education. Other major capital projects will be commenced at Deakin University, Murdoch University, the University of Tasmania and the Canberra College of Advanced Education.

As announced in the Guidelines, the Government decided on a 25 per cent reduction in grants for collegiate residences in 1984 to be applied pro-rata to all residences currently in receipt of Commonwealth grants pending the Commission's review of future arrangements for support for student accommodation . The reduction will result in an estimated saving of $1.7m in 1984. Similarly the grants to Special Research Centres included in this Bill take account of an estimated saving of $0.5m resulting from the closure of the Nerve Muscle Research Centre at the University of New South Wales due to movement of key staff.

Funding for advanced English language instruction for migrants in TAFE is to be continued at the same level in real terms as in 1983, but funds will now be appropriated from the TAFE special purpose grants rather than from particular purpose recurrent funds as in 1983. Special purpose grants are directed to areas of national concern to TAFE where substantial action is required by all States. Particular purposes recurrent grants enable States to undertake programs of quality improvement which reflect the particular priorities of individual States .

TAFE capital funds have been increased by 7 per cent in real terms. This level of funds will allow all on-going commitments to be met and twenty one new projects to be commenced. This means that new projects for TAFE will be undertaken in each State and the Northern Territory in 1984.

Consistent with the Government's decision to re-introduce retrospective cost supplementation arrangements for the Commission's programs from the beginning of 1984, this Bill amends the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1981 by replacing the previous Government's unsatisfactory system of prospective allowance for wage increases with retrospective adjustments to the grants. These adjustments take account of both the wages pause and the recent National Wage Case increase and result in a net saving of $15.1m. This adjustment is reached after taking account of the decision by the Government to fully supplement the grants for 1983 as a result of the National Wage Case. A total of $17.6m extra is being provided for that purposes. Provision for this increase was included in the Budget.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

On 18 October the Report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission containing its recommendation for the calendar year 1984, in response to the Government's Guidelines to the Commission, was tabled in the Parliament. This Bill gives effect to the Government's decisions on the Commission's recommendations on the distribution of funds for 1984, all of which have been accepted.

At a time of economic difficulty and budgetary constraint, it is an indication of the high priority which the Government gives to education that it is providing for a significant increase of 2.8 per cent in real terms in expenditure on schools in 1984.

The Bill before the Senate provides for the appropriation of some $1,290m in 1984, including $573m for government schools and $679m for non-government schools with $38m for joint programs for all schools. The Bill appropriates $6m p.a. for the new Computer Education program for the triennium 1984-86. This will enable school authorities to plan the implementation of this new initiative with confidence in the continued support of the Commonwealth for the first three years. Funds for the Government's other major initiative, the Participation and Equity Program, will be appropriated under the separate Bill which has been introduced for this purpose.

Grants for 1984 programs in the Bill are at levels reflecting the latest available data for the relevant cost indexes. These amounts will be adjusted retrospectively for further cost increases in subsequent amending legislation, in accordance with the Government's announced policy for the re-introduction of retrospective cost supplementation.
The Bill also contains a number of changes in specified areas in line with the Government's policies.

To promote the economic use of resources and to provide for better planning and improved coordination in relation to the development of new non-government schools, new conditions have been included in the Bill for general recurrent grants for new systemic and non-systemic non-government schools. These schools will no longer be automatically eligible for Commonwealth grants following registration by relevant State or Territory authorities. Schools will also be required to show that they have reasonable prospects of long-term viability and, in the case of proposed operation in established areas, that there will not be a significant negative impact on existing government and non-government schools. Proposed new schools in developing areas will be asked to provide evidence of adequate consultation with State education authorities. It is the Government's intention to ensure appropriate planning and consultation which will benefit all students in all schools.

The Bill implements the Government's decision to direct the limited additional resources that are available to the neediest non-government schools. Schools in Group 3 will receive a three per cent real increase in per capita grants for 1984. This means that these schools will receive $5m more than they would have received under the previous automatic nexus funding arrangements. In this way the Government is re-distributing resources between schools on the basis of need and is assisting on closing the gap between low resource schools and those operating at high resource standards.

The Bill also implements the Government's decision to reduce general recurrent per capita grants by 25 per cent in 1984 for a small number of non-government schools. These are schools which have the capacity from their cash income from private sources alone to operate at 95 per cent or more of average government schools standard costs. When Commonwealth and State grants are taken into account, these schools will still be able to operate in 1984 well above average government schools standard costs. The savings resulting from this decision amount to some $4.5m.

Capital grants programs for both government and non-government schools will now include a designated Secondary Facilities element to complement the recurrent grants being provided under the Participation and Equity Program. In addition, separate grants are being provided for each of the other elements of the capital programs to meet specifically identified national priority areas such as the upgrading of existing schools serving disadvantaged communities and capital facilities for schools serving predominantly Aboriginal communities. Eligibility under the government schools capital program will be extended also to hostels serving country children.

This Bill incorporates Government decisions that accountability conditions attached to grants for both sectors will require educational as well as financial information, with satisfactory arrangements to be made in advance of payments for the year. This is necessary if we are to ensure that educational objectives and priorities to which these grants are directed are being achieved. School authorities will be required to certify that all students, regardless of their sex, are being given equal access to Commonwealth funded programs, subject to a qualification to allow for single sex schools. The Bill also includes a requirement for State Ministers and systemic authorities to consult the Commonwealth Minister on the composition of committees administering Commonwealth programs.

Provision has been made for both the Ethnic Schools Program and the general support element of the English as a Second Language Program to be extended in 1984 to allow access for Aboriginals. The Short Term Emergency Assistance Program is being extended to allow grants to be allocated where a school's local community suffers a significant economic decline which affects the school. Other amendments are the availability of grants for capital purposes under the Education Centres Program, and the restriction of the use of funds under the Professional Development Program for teacher replacement to in-service activities supporting Commonwealth specific objectives or programs.

Consistent with the Government's decision to re-introduce retrospective cost supplementation arrangements for the Commission's programs from the beginning of 1984, the Bill amends the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1982 by replacing the previous Government's unsatisfactory system of prospective allowances for wage increases with retrospective adjustments to the grants. These adjustments take account of both the wages pause and the recent National Wage Case increase and result in a net saving of $48 million. This adjustment is reached after taking account of the decision by the Government to fully supplement the grants for 1983 as a result of the National Wage Case. A total of $10.3 million extra is being provided for that purpose comprising $4m for government school programs, $5.8 million for non-government schools and $0.5 million for joint programs. Provision for this increase was included in the Budget. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement in connection with this paper and to have the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Policy Discussion Paper on Extrinsic Aids to Statutory Interpretation tabled in the Parliament on 14 October 1982 formed the basis of the Symposium. That Paper examined the extent to which, in interpreting an Act of Parliament, regard can properly and usefully be had to Hansard, explanatory memoranda, reports and other ''extrinsic'' materials that do not themselves form part of the Act. It also examined whether the use of extrinsic materials should be further developed and, in particular, whether there is scope for the use of specially prepared explanatory memoranda approved by Parliament as an aid to the interpretation of Acts and possibly as leading to the simpler drafting of Acts. The stated intention was that there should be discussion both inside and outside Parliament before any decisions were made on legislation on the matter.

My Department has received submissions on the Discussion Paper and there have been several commentaries in journals. The Symposium, however, was the major forum for debate, and it served to crystallize thinking on the topic. The Australian Law Journal of April 1983 noted that there can seldom have been such a searching review of the problems involved in the employment by Courts of extrinsic aids to statutory interpretation as that which occurred in the course of the Symposium. Those reponsible for arranging the discussion-my predecessor, Senator Durack, and my Department-are to be congratulated. It followed an earlier initiative by Senator Durack to insert s.15AA in the Acts Interpretation Act requiring Courts to adopt a purposive interpretation of Commonwealth legislation. A similar provision to s.15AA is now being inserted in the national companies and securities legislation.

That particular intitiative was strongly supported at the time in Parliament by my side of politics. I hope and trust that the constructive bipartisan support we offered in Opposition is continued by the present Opposition in relation to this important topic.

The Symposium brought together a large number of distinguished participants, including the Chief Justice and four other Justices of the High Court, members of the Federal, State and Territory Courts, Parliamentarians, practitioners including senior counsel, academic legal scholars and senior public servants. Lord Wilberforce, until recently a Lord of Appeal in the House of Lords, delivered the keynote address.
The debate was vigorous and wide-ranging. In summing up at the conclusion of the Symposium, Sir Anthony Mason of the High Court made the following points (pp .81-5);
the law as it presently stands in relation to extrinsic aids is neither clear nor convincing;
it was generally agreed that cautious use should be made of extrinsic materials and that their potential to assist was restricted to cases of ambiguity;

there were perhaps some misgivings about the use of Hansard, and greater reservations about the use of the old style explanatory memorandum and also the proposed specially prepared and approved explanatory memorandum which would impose an additional load on top of the heavy burden Parliamentarians and Parliamentary Counsel already carry;
if, as the proposals in the Discussion Paper indicated, the new style memorandum was to be used only in association with some selected statutes, its scope would be very limited;

there was a case, however, supported by the authors of the papers and by a number of commentators and speakers, for action by the Parliament giving the Courts a judicial discretion to look beyond the four corners of the Statute when its seems appropriate to do so;

a draft of an amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act prepared by one of the working groups of the Symposium and to be found on p.76 of the report was extremely helpful in that regard; it was so expressed that it did not stifle any initiative that the Courts would have displayed in the absence of such legislative provision.

That was the thrust of the summing up by Sir Anthony Mason. It is fair to say that the Symposium generally did not support the particular proposal in the Discussion Paper for specially prepared explanatory memoranda that would be specifically approved by the Parliament. On the other hand, there was strong support for the view that Judges should be able to have regard to any materials they think are relevant to the resolution of the problem before them. Also, there was strong support for the view that a statutory provision was desirable to encourage those Judges who at the moment feel they are bound by rules which prevent them from achieving that end. On these points I refer honourable senators to p.77 of the proceedings.

In the light of the discussions at the Symposium and the other commentaries on the Discussion Paper, my Department is examining legislative proposals in this area. I expect that those proposals will be ready for Parliament's consideration during the Autumn Sittings. Without committing the Government or myself at this stage I should now say something on my own assessment of the direction in which the Symposium points us.

I begin by referring to the view vigorously expressed by Mr Justice Murphy that the problem the Discussion Paper and the Symposium sought to address represents 'an acute problem that no longer exists'. He illustrated that problem by referring to the widely held view that certain members of the judiciary were interpreting legislation, in particular the Income Tax Assessment Act, in a way which Parliament could not possibly have intended. Mr Justice Murphy referred to s.15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act as legislation which, whether necessary or not, reflected the attitude of the representatives of the people. Further legislation was, however, unnecessary. As to extrinsic aids, Parliament should do nothing at all about them. His Honour considered that the matter was progressing in a sensible way-there were different views, but there was no real need for any legislation (p.39).

It certainly is true that, as far as the High Court is concerned, there is no longer any rule of complete exclusion of reference to extrinsic materials, including Hansard in the case of some of the Justices. In the Federal Court, it has been laid down in TCN Channel 9 v. Australian Mutual Provident Society (1982 ) 42 ALR 496 that the Hansard report of the second reading speeches of the relevant Ministers and the explanatory memoranda accompanying Bills can be looked at for the purpose of ascertaining the mischief that legislation is intended to deal with. Senators will be interested to know that in the more recent case of Harris v. ABC, decided on 4 October 1983, Mr Justice Beaumont of the Federal Court, in interpreting the Freedom of Information Act, derived assistance in understanding the meaning and intended operation of s.36 (1) of that Act by reference to the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill. He also referred to the 1979 Report on the Freedom of Information Bill 1978 by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. That reference illustrates another type of extrinsic material to which Courts can already refer -namely, reports leading to the passing of legislation. Such reports were endorsed by the Symposium as a legitimate aid to interpretation (p.82).

At the same time, judicial approaches in this area differ considerably. Some Judges refer to Hansard while others do not. Some Judges believe that they are not free to look at extrinsic material under the present law, while others do not feel so constrained. As I have already indicated, the Symposium discussions identified a possible role for Parliament in this regard. Specifically, Parliament could enact legislation to give the Courts a judicial discretion to look beyond the four corners of the statute where it seems appropriate to do so.

Another difference in approach is that many Judges limit the use of reports, or Hansard where that is referred to, to ascertaining the mischief intended to be dealt with, and not as direct evidence of legislative intent. This view was followed by Justices Mason, Wilson and Dawson of the High Court in the recent case of Sanofi v. Parke Davis Pty Ltd (6 October 1983). Other Judges do not accept the view. A case in point is Mr Justice Murphy's judgment in Sillery v. R (1981) 35 ALR, at pp.232-3.

I tend to think that this limitation on the use made of reports and Hansard is difficult to observe in practice and, in any case, wrong in principle. As he pointed out in his paper at the Symposium, Lord Wilberforce originally supported only a limited use of reports (Black-Clawson case (1975) AC 591) but now believed the limitation to be wrong and the attempt to distinguish mischief and intent illogical. In his view (p.8 of the Symposium proceedings):
Mischief and the intended remedy are the obverse and reverse of a single coin. Acts of Parliament are passed with one indivisible objective, to cure an evil and to create new rights and duties.

The argument that, even where the report sets out a draft Bill, you may not look at the commentary in the report to see what the draft Bill means, because it does not follow that Parliament approved it-a feeble argument anyway-can have no validity whatever if the draft Bill is enacted without change.

The argument that to look at the report or commentary involves construing two documents instead of one is specious. You are only construing one document-the Act-with such help as you get from the other documents. If that other document is not clear, it is no help. If it is, why not use it?

I find Lord Wilberforce's views highly persuasive. At the same time, I think it is important that any legislative intervention in these areas should be carefully framed so as not to place an undue burden on litigants and their advisers and on other users of statutes. As I observed in my comments delivered at the Symposium, there are limitations to the kinds of materials to which even the most conscientious citizens and their advisers can get access. There is also an obvious 'price tag' in the form of added costs that may result from lengthier litigation, though undoubtedly in some cases extrinsic material, where it is clear and convincing, may shorten or foreclose argument.

There is no easy or comprehensive solution to this problem. The reaching of a satisfactory accommodation will depend, I suggest, on the good sense of both the Judges and Parliament combining to produce a situation in which the range of available materials, and the way in which they are used, are reasonably defined and confined. In this regard, it must be acknowledged that, even if it were felt desirable to do so, it would not at this stage be feasible to exclude totally the use of extrinsic material by a Judge who decides that he or she is entitled to look at it for the purpose of discharging his or her judicial duty of expounding and applying the laws of the Commonwealth.

What can Parliament do to help on this particular problem? This seems to me to be the final matter to be considered. Can something be done to more readily define what materials may be looked at? Even if Senator Durack's idea of a specially prepared explanatory memorandum is rejected as not being of general utility, it can be of use in special cases. Also, as I mentioned in my remarks delivered at the Symposium, the possible use of such specially identified material should not be limited to explanatory memoranda. Use can also be made in appropriate cases of reports on which Bills are based and the Second Reading Speech of the Minister. I have in mind, in particular, reports of the Law Reform Commission.

Complicated procedures for specific approval of the material by Parliament would be neither desirable nor necessary in such cases. A simple provision in the Act declaring that the report or memorandum or speech in question may be taken into account for the purpose of interpreting the Act would suffice. I said as much in my remarks delivered at the Symposium.
I propose, in appropriate cases, to include in legislation within my portfolio a provision specifying relevant extrinsic material to which regard may be had in the interpretation of that legislation.

We could also consider a general provision for insertion in the Acts Interpretation Act that would facilitate this practice. Certainly we have to consider the deletion or amendment of sub-section (2) of s.15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act. That was simply a holding provision that was intended to preserve whatever the existing law was in relation to use of extrinsic materials , pending the examination of this topic. The provision no longer serves any useful or rational purpose, since many Judges obviously now feel free under the existing law to refer to extrinsic materials.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1982-83

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

It is a pleasure to get a report from an instrumentality such as the Export Development Grants Board which so completely covers the functions that are carried out by that body. I was very pleased to receive the 1982-83 report because it does traverse the full operation of the Board. I see the export development business as being one of the most important items that this Government should be associated with at present. We have to remember that Australia's geographical disadvantages relative to our major trading markets makes real difficulties for our exportees. It puts us at a considerable disadvantage to many of the countries which are engaged in similar pursuits. Besides that, of course, we have our system of extraordinary shipping costs which makes them even more disadvantaged. I wonder why Australia, probably more than any other country in the world, has decided to create all the various taxes , costs and charges that go with persecuting our exporters. I think it all started as part of The Lucky Country syndrome. We believed that there was plenty for everybody and that we were able to export things that somebody else wanted. In fact it started off being a tax on the purchaser, but before very long it became a tax on the supplier. It is certainly not the case that the markets that we supply can no longer get the various goods only from Australia. I hope that perhaps later in the week we will be able to discuss certain aspects of this a little more. I also find it rather extraordinary that we charge massive export levies, yet allow export incentives. I think it is about as expensive and as silly a way to spend public funds as one can imagine. There is positively no future and no profit in just shuffling public moneys. Australia's future positively lies in its export capacity and the development of avenues that provide encouragement. These have to be pursued.

I am very pleased to be able to comment on the performance and the standing of the members of the Board. I particularly mention Mr Daly, the Executive Member, and Mr Paltridge, the Chairman, both of whom I know very well. With their co- Board members, the wisdom, experience and knowledge that they present to this Board are highly respected and greatly appreciated. The report itself has to be a tremendous impetus to the many individuals and companies which are listed in it and to others which may be considering going into the export business. The very voluminous tables of the companies and individuals of every size show that it is possible to participate. I ask only that the Government press on with its logical extension and simplification of the principles of assisting our export industries. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF EMPLOYMENT AND INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Reports

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

I want to make a few comments about the annual report of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. I have not adequately gone through the descriptions of all the matters to which this Department addresses itself. However, from the brief reading I have given the report, it seems to provide an extensive description not only of the many things that have taken place in the Department but also of the considerable changes that have been made in the Department's structure over the 12 months to the end of the year 1982-83. Some of the descriptions pertain to time under the previous Government and some to that under the current Government. There were considerable changes when the Australian Labor Party Government took office. The Office of Youth Affairs was transferred to the Department of Education and Youth Affairs in March of this year. On 1 July 1983 the Melbourne Industrial Relations Unit took a new title to coincide with the re-establishment of the Arbitration Inspectorate Division within the Department on that date. There are other references to changes and different emphases of programs within the Department. In particular, much time and effort have been put into the establishment of the community employment program which was introduced into legislation on 19 May this year and was operating under the Community Employment Act which was proclaimed on 23 June this year. That program will be reviewed prior to 30 June 1986.

I was pleased to read, in particular, that the Department has an evaluation of employment generation programs for both the wage pause program and the community employment program. The Commonwealth and State Ministers agreed that the Bureau of Labour Market Research should conduct a full evaluation in consultation with the States. I think this is particularly to be applauded. Quite often thorough evaluation is missing from the introduction of programs. This cannot lead to the most efficient or effective outcome. The evaluation is regarded as integral in assessing the performance of programs and providing a basis for further program and policy development. Further, it is hoped that the evaluations by the Bureau of Labour Market Research will encompass both the objectives of the programs and the broader effect of what happens to people who have the opportunity of participating in subsequent employment experience. Its evaluation looks not only at the effectiveness of the program but also at the outcome for people who have been able to participate in that program.

I was particularly interested to look at the work of the Women's Bureau. I found it has a particular function to research and develop policies on women's employment, including equal opportunity of employment for women, and to provide advice on these matters to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I was pleased to notice further that it has the aim, if not the established brief, to increase community awareness of labour market issues, particularly by publication and dissemination of information and the presentation of employment, educational programs, seminars, workshops et cetera. In fact, it has a twofold brief. One is to provide the information and research within the Department; the other is the important one of extending that information to the people in the community who need to know not only what the Department is doing in providing information to the Minister, but also what is available to people in the community, particularly to women.

During the year the Women's Bureau produced two video tapes, Women in Engineering and Technically Speaking. Technically Speaking is a set of two complementary video tapes, one aimed at young women and girls in schools to encourage them to consider looking at other than standard or traditional employment prospects for themselves, the other designed to inform parents and career advisers about other than the usual areas of employment for young women. Those tapes are now available. Anybody in the community can apply for those tapes and use them for parent education nights and information sessions for people in the community, particularly for young women. In addressing the needs of young women, it is also very important that those people in our society who shape attitudes need to be informed of those possible changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the opportunity now to speak on the report of the Commonwealth Employment Service and also to talk about a local CES project in the area in which I live, the Manly-Warringah district of Sydney. The project was called Operation Job Hunt and I had the pleasure of launching it on behalf of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the Hon. Ralph Willis, at a large public meeting at Dee Why, chaired by the District Governor of Rotary. The operation was launched by the CES and supported by various agencies and organisations including Inter-agency, Rotary and the Manly Daily, the local newspaper with the largest circulation of any suburban newspaper in Australia. The Northern Beaches Community Youth Support Scheme provided valuable backing and I am pleased to say that because of representations made by the local State Labor members of parliament-Tom Webster, the member for Wakehurst, and Alan Stewart, the member for Manly-along with me, the Northern Beaches CYSS was recently upgraded and this year will receive $90, 000 as opposed to the $60,000 it received last year. The CYSS provided posters advertising Operation Job Hunt and the Brookvale Technical College made thermometers which were located throughout the district including the Manly wharf area, the Warringah Mall shopping centre, Warriewood Shopping Square, Manly Daily offices and the Manly and Warringah councils. These thermometers gauged the progress of the job hunt and made the community aware of the project, encouraging its participation. The Manly Daily ran full page advertisements for people seeking work. It ran editorials and human interest stories, and gave continuing publicity to the project worth many thousands of dollars.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of Operation Job Hunt was to counter growing unemployment in the Manly-Warringah area, which now stands at 8,000, with 70 per cent of those unemployed being between the ages of 20 and 44, and to bring home to people that the people out of work in the area were not just kids on the beach whom some people had called dole bludgers, but were the family next door, like themselves, with children and a mortgage. They happened to be mainly professional people in the district. It was a timely project as young people are now leaving school, and in bringing into focus the plight of the unemployed in the area the project was and is trying to localise unemployment and find local solutions to the problem. This is an important aspect of Operation Job Hunt.

The operation officially ends today, 30 November, and so the Commonwealth Employment Service report is timely. The success of the job hunt is shown by the fact that, on the first official day of operation, 55 jobs were offered by employers in the Manly-Warringah district and, in the first week, nearly 200 were offered. The target for jobs was 500 by the end of November and the number of jobs so far created by local employers totals 804 of which 658 have already been filled. The rest are still being processed. In November last year only 398 job vacancies were received at the Brookvale and Manly CES offices. The 804 jobs created have been a great result and I congratulate a number of people, including John Martin, the manager of the CES at Brookvale; Paul Collings, a CES officer; Jill Muddle, the area project officer for community employment programs ; Tom Barry, the manager of the Manly CES; Kathy McVay from Brookvale CES; and all those others associated with the campaign. I am informed that many other CES offices have taken a keen interest in Operation Job Hunt and there are plans for similar drives which will follow the lead set by the Manly and Brookvale CES offices.

The community response to this project has been magnificent. Members of the community pulled together and worked to make the project a success and showed that they were willing to meet the challenge and provide valuable jobs to the unemployed in the Manly-Warringah district. I am aware that the Minister concerned, Mr Willis, has shown a great interest in this pilot project. We hope, along with the local people, that he will be able to visit the area in the near future and see at first hand for himself the excellent job that has been done by CES officers in this important pilot project.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I was pleased that honourable senators opposite suggested that items 3 and 4 on the list, the report of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and the report of the Commonwealth Employment Service, should be debated together. I think it is desirable, after the five-minute bursts that are allowed today under the sessional order and after the relatively brief treatment that the reports are likely to get tomorrow, that this matter be adjourned and that we come back to it in the new year. I have little doubt that however much there might be signs of improvement in some sectors of the economy we as a Senate, when we return next February, will need to address our attention to the continuing problem of high unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: We do have at the moment some predictions, including some which have been referred to recently following debate in the other place, emanating from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet which suggest a risk of not only high but also continuing and rising unemployment. Of course the Government's own Budget suggested that there would be further growth in unemployment during this financial year. We have had comment in the Senate over recent weeks on the apparent unreliability of current statistics. There is an extraordinary variation in the figures which have been put before us by the Australian Bureau of Statistics over recent months, including very substantial variations in the participation rate and hence in the apparent unemployment rate.

But none of that really takes anything away from the sorts of facts which Senator Sibraa referred to in his comments, because we all know that a very substantial number of Australians, young and old, are unable to find a job in 1983, and that will be the position in 1984. That is a matter which I think has to cause us concern on a lot of different levels. The fact is that since the war Australian society has been based on the proposition that for those who wish to seek work a job will generally be available. We now have people telling us that a quarter of our young, would-be work force are unemployed and that that figure may rise to a third. I do not think that anybody can be very relaxed about the potential social consequences of that. It is a point which was made very forcefully by some honourable senators opposite when they were in opposition and I know they will continue to be concerned about the matter now that they are in government.

I hope that within this chamber we can find some opportunities for an analysis of that problem and for some serious and not necessarily partisan debate on a problem that obviously will be with us for some time. I do not believe that we have had enough opportunity in the current session to address our minds to that very considerable issue, and I hope that this will provide an opportunity for us to do it in February.

I want to touch on one specific matter in the minute or so which remains to me. I have raised this matter before in this chamber without any response from the Government. Under the Government's Budget we will be expending something like $3 billion this year on the unemployment benefit. Honourable senators will recall that when we introduced the wage freeze in December of last year and allocated savings of some $300m to the creation of work in one form or another a couple of million dollars was set aside to experiment in the field of providing some constructive work at award rates for people who would otherwise be on unemployment benefit. There has been a great deal of interest around Australia in the proposition that some parts of the Australian economy and administration, and in particular local government, might be able to provide worthwhile work in lieu of unemployment benefit.

I believe that, with the likely continuance of high rates of unemployment, some experimentation in that area is warranted. It could be done on a voluntary basis ; it could be done with appropriate protection for those involved in that award rates could be required. We must do something to examine the possibility that we can, for the individuals involved and for the country, get better value for the $3 billion or so which will have to be expended on the unemployment benefit this year. I do not believe it is a fair start to life to spend years on unemployment benefit and I think we must try to pool our collective minds to find better solutions than we have at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks on the 1982 -83 annual report of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. In reading the report one is struck by the consultative arrangements that the Department, through the Government, has entered into with various parties in the industrial relations area. The report sets out what has been done in this field during 1982-83. Under the heading 'consultation' on page 13 the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Significant consultative machinery indirectly affecting the Employment and Industrial Relations portfolio has been developed since the April 1983 National Economic Summit Conference.

The report makes reference to the consultative arrangements. At page 86, under the heading 'Industrial Relations Calendar July 1982 to June 1983', the report tabulates our industrial relations performance over the last 12 months. It is significant to look at both the consultative changes and the industrial relations calendar for the period July 1982 to June 1983. The calendar reveals that the previous Government was concerned with some 47 major industrial disputes up until 11 March 1983. Since then there has been only one major dispute and that was inherited from the former Administration. I think that the facts tell a very important and interesting story, namely, that the style of government that we have chosen to adopt-that of consultation rather than confrontation in the industrial relations field-has in part led to a tremendous reduction in the number of disputes. The evidence in this report reveals that our style of government has led directly to far less need for government intervention or for government intervention at all in the industrial relations area. That record has improved our performance remarkably and one must sheet this home to the consultative arrangements that typify Labor's approach to this issue.

The prices and incomes accord, of course, underpins the fundamental understanding of the Government in the industrial relations area and that arrangement has been backed by the National Economic Summit Conference. It is important that the accord be supported not only by unions-and in that sense the Australian Council of Trade Unions along with other unions has a heavy responsibility to ensure that any union that wishes to maverick upon the accord is brought to book-but also implicitly by employers. There should be co- operative consultation to manage this economy out of the recession and to obtain the levels of economic and industrial growth that are necessary to put people back into full employment and to provide them with meaningful careers. I think that the role the Government has played-that is, one of not moving to accuse or trying to find someone to blame for the effects of industrial disputation but rather of finding out what the problem was that gave rise to industrial disputation and resolving that-is directly responsible, through the consultative process, for the improvement in our record. That record must stand us in good stead when it comes to getting the economic growth we need and answering the expectations, if not the anxieties, of our trading partners in terms of how they will be affected by our industrial relations position. I think that the report in that respect is a most important document. I commend it to the Senate and seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debated adjourned.
