TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The 215th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts contains the Department of Finance minute on the Committee's 190th report which reviewed the procedures used for the collection of petroleum royalties and excise. The Department of Finance minute is the formal documentation of the Government's response to the Committee's recommendations, as contained in the 190th report which was tabled on 27 October 1981. The Committee's inquiry commenced as part of its examination of the Auditor-General' s 1977-78 report. As a result of this examination, the Committee decided to examine separately matters concerning the off-shore petroleum royalties and excise, which were again referred to in reports of the Auditor-General in 1979- 80 and 1980-81.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's decision to inquire into this matter was influenced by the significance of the Commonwealth's receipts from petroleum royalties and excise. These receipts were of the order of $3,000m a year. The Committee's concern, as expressed in the 190th report, was that even a small percentage error resulting from inaccuracies in the back allocation procedures which are used to verify the amount of crude oil produced could lead to errors of plus or minus millions of dollars. The report also highlighted some of the many complex legal issues in this area involving both Federal and State governments as well as oil producers. These issues arise because of the many different Commonwealth and State Acts covering off-shore matters and the difficulties in resolving those areas and activities which should come under Commonwealth rather than State jurisdiction.

The Committee recognised that the issues identified in its 190th report were complex and involved policies and administrative procedures at both State and Federal government level. As a result, the significant delay in the finalisation of the Department of Finance minute on this report was anticipated, but the Committee has been kept informed of progress in the interim. The Public Accounts Committee is pleased to note the considerable effort which has been directed towards carrying out most of its recommendations. Overall, therefore, the Committee is satisfied with the timing and content of the response to its 190th report. Mr Deputy President, I wish to incorporate in Hansard the Committee's recommendations Nos 1 to 6 and the Department of Finance minute responses in summary form.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Recommendation 1: . . . the terms of the 1980 legislation be discussed with the States with a view to having the legislation amended prior to being proclaimed, to empower the Joint Authority established under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Act 1980 to function in relation to the territorial sea as well as the adjacent areas.

In response the Committee was advised that the Government is reviewing the operation of the Commonwealth and State legislation covering offshore petroleum and mining activities. The issue raised by the Committee will be a matter for consideration in the context of that review.

Recommendations 2 and 3: Discussions take place between the respective Commonwealth and State authorities and between Auditors-General to ensure that royalty collection procedures compatible with the requirements of both Governments are implemented under the existing legislation and under the 1980 Commonwealth legislation when proclaimed; the Department of National Development and Energy and the Auditor-General's Office should be involved, in co-operation with the Victorian Auditor-General, in ensuring the correctness of the procedures to arrive at the royalty payments.

In response an independent firm of consultants was commissioned to undertake a review of the sampling techniques employed for obtaining compositional data for the material balance program used in the calculation of royalties and excise payable to the Commonwealth and Victorian Governments. The recommendations resulting from that review have been implemented.

Also, the following four sets of detailed procedures for the collection and verification of royalties and excise for the Bass Strait producing fields either have been developed, or are being developed: Producers procedures, State procedures, Customs procedures and Department of Resources and Energy procedures .
Recommendation 4: Arrangements be made for the Commonwealth share of royalties to be paid immediately it is received by the State, with any adjustments being made in the following month's payment.
In response legislation has been amended to ensure the immediate payment to the Commonwealth, of its share of royalties.

Recommendation 5: Officers of the Department of National Development and Energy , and the Auditor-General's Office actively participate in the final verification of royalty calculations which should be completed as soon as possible.
In response audit, by the Victorian Department of Mines and Energy, of royalty payments, on the basis of wellhead values, is progressing in consultation with the Department of Resources and Energy.

Recommendation 6: The Department of National Development and Energy and Business and Consumer Affairs treat finalisation of the documentation of (excise ) procedures as a matter of urgency and the Committee will expect to see substantial progress in this area in the near future.

In response the Department of Resources and Energy advised that the procedures adopted to allocate and verify production from the various Bass Strait fields for excise purposes are the same as those used in the royalty calculation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President. The final recommendation in the 190th report concerned the need to simplify the royalty procedures and the Committee referred to the United Kingdom experience wherein procedures have been revised so that well-head value is no longer used as the basis for royalty payments. The Department of Resources and Energy responded to this by indicating the Government's intention to consider this issue in the context of its current review of taxation arrangements for resource projects. Consequently, the Committee intends to review progress in this area in approximately 12 months time. I commend this report to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch, I was pointing out to the Senate that public funding is a normal procedure throughout most of the Western democracies and that in fact Australia is one of the last democracies to install some system of public funding. I noted that former Senator Puplick, a Liberal Party senator, in his maiden speech in the Senate on 20 September 1978 said that he looked forward to the days when we would have public funding of political parties, disclosure of donations, some register of pecuniary interests, fair redistributions, one vote one value, a revised Federal Constitution and real popular participation in government. It is no wonder that he has not been re-elected to the Senate, and no wonder that Senator Sir John Carrick is staying firmly nailed to his seat, because what he said today is in complete opposition to what Senator Puplick said in his maiden speech. I suggest that if members of the Liberal Party were to read that statement, many of them would think that Senator Puplick is some dangerous radical. A contrary view of the Liberals was put by Senator Peter Baume in a speech to the Senate in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: To seek or to accept a public subsidy is a political party's admission of failure. That it should need to look to public funding is an admission that it cannot get support from those who should be attracted by the force of its ideas and its ideology. The need for public funding reflects a lack of confidence in the acceptability of the party's objectives, a lack of confidence in its policies, a lack of confidence in its performance and an unwillingness to make the necessary efforts to raise its own funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does not the Party in New South Wales accept public funding?
—I was getting to that. He continued:

SPEECH.PARA: It is an assertion by an unsuccessful and failed party . . .

I wonder whether Senator Baume thinks that his own Party in New South Wales has failed now that it accepts public funding. On the one hand we have Senator Baume , who is still in the Senate, making his statement and on the other hand we have the statement of former Senator Puplick, who is no longer in the Senate. I think therefore that we would accept that the view of the Liberal Party would be the view put forward by Senator Sir John Carrick today and by Senator Baume on a previous occasion. The reason, I believe, that this Opposition is terrified of public funding is that it will have to account for where the money comes from for its election campaigns. We know that millions of dollars-$5 or $6m in the 1980 election, and more in 1983-came to the Liberal and National parties and that money was completely unaccounted for. We do not know where one cent of these millions came from.

Public funding has already been an issue in an election in Australia. In New South Wales that issue was one of the Liberal-National Party coalition's main areas of criticism of the Labor Government leading up to the 1981 election. Full page advertisements in the Sydney Morning Herald, costing $7,000 a page, attacked the Labor Government's proposal for public funding. That proposal did not hit the deck as an issue and the Labor Government in New South Wales increased its majority. The New South Wales Opposition parties asked for a referendum on the issue and a referendum was held except that it was called a general election. In New South Wales the Liberals have gone to extraordinary lengths to conceal the identity of their corporate donors, but occasionally information gets out. I refer to an article on page 7 of the National Times of 14 to 20 October which is entitled: 'Whose money backs NSW Libs?' The article states:
The NSW branch owed $2 million in March last year--
that is 1982-

when Valder launched his fund-raising campaign. By the end of 1982 the branch was out of the red-Valder had raised $2.9 million. He set a target of a further $2.5 million in 1983 and is already comfortably close to that with around $2 million in party coffers.
I seek leave to have that article incorporated in Hansard.

In addition to the Valder Report, unveiled at the Liberal Party Conference in Sydney earlier this month, the former Sydney Stock Exchange chairman can take the credit for leading the NSW branch of the Liberal Party out of virtual bankruptcy.

The NSW branch owed $2 million in March last year when Valder launched his fund -raising campaign. By the end of 1982 the branch was out of the red-Valder had raised $2.9 million. TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President. Mr Valder in a recent article said, I believe, that since the State campaign in 1981 the New South Wales branch of the Liberal Party has raised $5m. I think we are entitled to ask who they get it from and what was the price. I make the point that trade unions have always published their donations. They have to do so under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. I know that the Opposition parties complain about undue influence on the Labor Party whenever they see the unions making a large donation. By 'a large donation' I mean about $20,000 or $30,000. Every time we have an election campaign and a photograph appears of the Amalagamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union handing over a large cheque to the Leader of the Labor Party, the Opposition parties complain bitterly about it. But we have to depend on newspaper leaks to find out that one of the traditionally poorer branches of the Liberal Party has been able to raise $5m since the last election campaign.
—That is dedication.

—I congratulate the branch, but it is a large amount of money. If individuals want to make private donations running parallel with the system of public funding established under this legislation, they can, and they should be out in the open. In 1962 President Kennedy, the then President of the United States, said that some form of public funding was inevitable because of the way that costs are rising in the United States. He proposed a commission to investigate campaign costs. The proposal was not acted upon until after Watergate, which made public funding possible in the United States. In the last United States presidential campaign, President Reagan received $21m in public funding. Does the Opposition think that President Reagan is corrupt because he accepted $21m in public funding?

SPEECH.PARA: In the 1980 Federal election, $2.76m was spent by the major political parties on electronic media advertising. In 1983, $4.3m was spent. I wonder what will be the cost of one minute on television during the next Federal election campaign. I believe that it is better that we act now and not wait for an Australian Watergate to occur. As was said earlier today, the Australian Labor Party has had the experience-

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the Iraqi breakfast, eh?

—Of the Iraqi loans affairs. As Senator Peter Baume would be aware, I am on record condemning that whole situation. The Liberal Party has not been free of trouble. Three former Ministers, Mr Garland, the then Mr Lynch and the late Mr Eric Robinson were all in trouble. Two of them were sacked over electoral matters or election funding. As I said, public funding is a reality in much of the democratic world. Australia is just bringing itself up to date.

SPEECH.PARA: I now wish to deal with some other aspects of the legislation. I am particularly pleased that the legislation provides for polling booths to close at 6 p.m. instead of 8 p.m. I have been calling for this change since my election to the Senate in 1975. Personally I have good reasons for wanting this change which relate to my experience on the last election day, 5 March 1983. I was broadcasting the election results and giving commentaries that evening for the Sydney radio station 2KY. I expected to be out of the studio at midnight, but it was not until the early hours of Sunday morning that I could conclude my broadcast, still not knowing the results from Western Australia and Queensland. Even at that late hour, I still had only the preliminary figures for a number of vital electorates around Australia, although the general pattern was reasonably clear.

The studio received many phone calls from people wanting to know what the results were before they switched off their radio for the night and went to bed. That two hours makes a lot of difference when results are coming through. The problem was magnified by the fact that daylight saving was in operation. Consequently there was a three-hour difference between Sydney and Perth. I am pleased to say that the Labor Government which was elected in Western Australia has brought in daylight saving in that State, so there will be a difference of only two hours at the next election. The consequence was that the first results from Western Australia were not received until well after 11 p.m. Even the first figures for Queensland were not available until nearly 10 p.m. Had the 6 p.m. closing requirement been in force, the vast extent of the Labor victory would have been known by 10 p.m. at the latest and the former Prime Minister would not have had to wait until 12.55 a.m. before admitting to his Government's defeat.

New South Wales brought in 6 p.m. closing and it has made for a much more efficient operation on election day. It is unreasonable to expect Australian Electoral Office staff to remain efficient and competent from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m., 11 p.m. or midnight. Furthermore, one simple mistake could have very grave consequences. I believe that my experience in the recount of the Senate vote in 1975 shows the sorts of mistakes that are made when people have been working for that length of time and are hurrying to get results through on election day. There was a complete recount of the Senate vote in New South Wales in 1975. The winning margin of the last candidate, who happened to be me, went from 854 to 2, 016, which really was not a great increase, but when we were able to go through the ballot papers with a reasonable amount of time available to us we found an additional 12,000 informal votes.

Another change which I have been advocating to the Senate for a number of years has been that the deposit should be increased for candidates standing for election to the Senate. This legislation proposes that deposits for candidates for the House of Representatives will increase from $100 to $250. In the case of an election for the Senate, the increase will be from $200 to $500. Those deposits will be forfeited if less than 4 per cent of the formal vote is obtained. I have argued time and time again that a number of people who stand for election to the Senate do so for a joke. In New South Wales, we have seen disc jockeys and rock stars--

TALK.START.PARA: —And for tax gains, too.

—As Senator Georges said, unfortunately, some people have stood so that they can claim their election expenses as a taxation deduction. Unfortunately, the results have shown that the higher the number of candidates the higher the level of informal votes. Earlier today Senator Colston said that it would be possible under the old Commonwealth Electoral Act to sabotage deliberately the Senate result. I am still not sure that in 1974, when 73 candidates stood in New South Wales, some people were not deliberately encouraged to put their name on the Senate ballot paper to bring about a high informal vote. As I said, 73 candidates stood for that election. The informality rate was 12.3 per cent. In 1975, 53 candidates stood and the informality rate was 9.7 per cent. In the 1977 and 1980 elections, the number of candidates was 35 and 33 respectively, with the informal voting component being 9.6 per cent and 9.4 per cent respectively. The 1983 election saw an informal voting level of 11.1 per cent with 62 candidates standing for election. The number of candidates who stood for the 64 senate positions throughout Australia in the 5 March election totalled 250. In New South Wales, there were 18 groups of candidates on the Senate ticket. They included the new Party, the Peace on Earth Party, the Australia First Movement and the Integrity Team. John Campbell wrote an article in the Australian on 24 February 1983 relating to these joke candidates. The article reported:

SPEECH.PARA: Excited radicals fairly leapt from their closets waving $100 deposit cheques . . . frantically arranged meetings spawned a whole new line-up of off-beat and esoteric aspirants. Some abandoned causes were quickly revived as the potential of March 5 clarified. Out sprung the DSPA-Deadly Serious Party of Australia, the EAPP-the Engineered Australia Plan Party, the IBCP-the Imperial British Conservative Party, the NAP-New Australia Party, the WAM-White Australia Movement, and the PTETPC-Party to Expose the Petrov Conspiracy, and more.

Actually, I believe that the level of the deposit should have been increased even further, but at least this goes some way to improving the situation to which I have referred. In relation to the joke candidates, one of the most important aspects of this legislation is that it will be easier to cast a formal vote in future Senate elections. Provision has been made for a voter to mark just one box on a Senate ballot paper indicating the adoption of a registered how-to-vote ticket. No longer will a person have to struggle through a long and complicated ballot paper in order to cast a formal vote with the prospects of making just one mistake very high.

I have been particularly concerned that some of the Labor Party's traditional supporters-that is, the aged, the infirm, migrants and Aborigines-have been prone to make mistakes on the ballot paper invalidating their voting intention. I believe that the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform had statistics which showed that the vast majority of informal voters at least tried to fill in their ballot paper and to cast a formal vote. Some of them did not make mistakes until they got as high as No. 28, No. 32 and so on in the ballot paper. That vote was then out of the count. As I have already mentioned, the higher the number of candidates the higher the rate of informality. One improvement that has been made is that the count of the Senate vote will be taken up to the point at which a mistake is made. This system operates in the New South Wales Legislative Council. The informal rate there is only 3 per cent to 4 per cent. It is not the 10 per cent average that we have been getting for the Senate.

Further assistance is provided for voters by the fact that help will be provided for handicapped people who vote at polling booths, including the right of the voter to request a polling official to follow a particular how-to-vote ticket. I believe that this is extremely important for migrants who are illiterate not only in English but also in their own language. Those people have been put at a severe disadvantage in the past.

Another major change will be that each polling booth will be allowed to exhibit a poster displaying registered how-to-vote tickets. This provision may go some way in allowing the parties to cut down on their enormous printing bills caused by the large amount of how-to-vote tickets which are distributed outside polling booths. I would have liked to see the party's name on the ballot paper, but that is something that the Committee--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in the legislation.

—I am pleased to see that it is in the legislation. Another improvement will be that a person will be able to vote at any polling place within his or her Federal division. We will not have the complication of people being asked to vote in their sub-division. It is a relic of the past, especially given today's transport systems.

SPEECH.PARA: I now wish to deal with some of the remarks which were made by Senator Sir John Carrick for the Opposition who put in a minority report to the Select Committee. Senator Sir John Carrick said that he supported non-compulsory voting. When his friend Sir Robert Askin was the Premier of New South Wales, I think that Senator Sir John Carrick was the General Secretary of the New South Wales Branch of the Liberal Party. I think he was, but I am not sure of that. Certainly, he would have been a close adviser to the former Premier of New South Wales, Sir Robert Askin. The Askin Liberal Government introduced non-compulsory voting for local government elections in New South Wales. What happened was that, in general elections for municipalities and shires throughout New South Wales, the vote dropped to as low as 7 per cent. In some municipalities the vote was 11 per cent . I remember a by-election in Strathfield which is a very conservative part of Sydney, where the total vote was 7 per cent. Of course, what happened was that the Labor Party organised just over 50 per cent of that vote, or just over 3.5 per cent of the total vote, and was able to win what had been a very conservative council in what was Sir William McMahon's electorate. The councils could be manipulated by very small numbers of voters. Of course, this system did not work and it was changed. I do not think there would be such a low voter turnout in State elections or Federal elections. We had that experience in New South Wales. It was not a very good experience.

Senator Sir John Carrick pointed out that the United States and Great Britain have non-compulsory voting. Frankly, I am terrified to think that a minority of voters are able to elect somebody as powerful as the President of the United States of America. Senator Sir John Carrick attempted to link a large donkey vote with compulsory voting. He pointed out that the donkey vote in the last Federal election was 2.5 per cent. I put to the Senate that that is a low figure in a democracy with compulsory voting. Of course, in the Senate it was 10 per cent. I believe that the complicated ballot paper terrified a number of elderly voters. That was one of the main reasons for that Senate informal vote of 10 per cent. Therefore, it should have been approximately 2.5 per cent, the same as that for the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was almost a quota, wasn't it?

—It was almost a quota, as Senator Georges said. Many could not complete the ballot paper even though they tried. I believe that a list system will work because the vast majority of people who will be voting for the Labor Party, for the Liberal-National parties and for the Australian Democrats will follow a how-to-vote ticket. Senator Maguire made some points about voting machines and about the computerisation of the results. I certainly support his remarks. In conclusion I wish to congratulate the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. It had a massive task. It completed that task thoroughly and efficiently. I believe this legislation brings Australian electoral laws into the twentieth century. I believe it should be passed as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much has been said in this debate on the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill. I would like to make just a short statement-it will not take too long-about some of the changes that have been incorporated in the legislation. I cannot support public funding of election campaigns and neither can the National Party of Australia, which I represent. Such a concept is an attempt to ensure bureaucratic regulation and, ultimately, nationalisation of the political party system. From a purely commonsensical approach, why should the public have to provide additional taxpayers' money to help politicians get elected? I read in the Morgan gallup poll of 19 July that 56 per cent of people in Australia opposed this concept. I believe the public funding of election campaigns would lower public regard for political parties even further.
—Keep reading.

—Thank you very much indeed, Senator. If political parties do not have sufficient public support without this form of enforced support, of course, they should not be in existence. It appears to me that the Australian Labor Party is seeking to trample on the rights of individuals and companies which wish to support an economic philosophy of the political party of their choice. It does not want to allow people to choose whom they want to support. Taxpayers will have to give money to parties which they do not support. The Labor Party obtains its hold from workers. Workers pay union fees, but lots of workers do not support the Labor Party's policies. Yet the money from the union fees goes into Labor Party Funds. I feel that union members are being conscripted financially. The Labor Party, on one hand, is paranoid about the supposedly undue influence of private or corporate donations to parties. Yet, on the other hand, it is the recipient of quite large donations from some of those companies. Furthermore, it certainly does not see its affiliation with trade unions as being in the same category. That, to me, is quite inconsistent.

SPEECH.PARA: I also place on record my opposition to the list system of voting. I feel that this will mean that we do not give too much credit to people for being able to vote the way they want. Not everybody wants to start at No. 1 on the ballot paper and do exactly what the party tells them to do. I think a list system would encourage people to go into the polling booths and make ticks. I think that, perhaps, too, bogus or dummy groups could be encouraged to contest Senate elections simply to collect preferences which they can then direct through the list system. I think this could lead, in some ways, to substantial informal voting. In my opinion this concept, as I said, questions the intelligence of the average Australian and reduces this idea to a pick a box idea, a bit like the Pick a Box that we used to see on television in the early days. I certainly believe that the Australian voter has far greater intelligence-

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you like Barry Jones in those days?
—I did like Barry Jones. I thought he was a rather clever man. I liked what he did on television, perhaps more than what he does in Parliament. That is by the way.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform made one or two recommendations which I was pleased to see. It resisted optional preferential voting. That is very important. It also resisted the move to reduce the 10 per cent tolerance to 5 per cent. I think that is something that deserves commendation. Those are only a couple of areas in this very complex legislation that is before us. Many amendments are to be introduced later. We will be interested to hear what the different speakers have to say. However, I do not agree with many clauses. I will support the amendment moved by the Opposition to the motion for the second reading. I wanted to put my thoughts on this Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill is, as other colleagues have pointed out, well and truly overdue. The last major consolidation of the Commonwealth Electoral Act was carried out in 1918. In spite of many promises over recent years we have seen no movement at all in this area. The Australian Labor Party Government of 1974 and 1975 introduced many electoral Bills that passed the House of Representatives only to meet their doom in this chamber. Once the Labor Government went out of office in 1975 there were many promises made by honourable senators opposite that they would reform the Commonwealth Electoral Act, but no Bill came forward. Labor has been in power for eight months. We have managed to hold an inquiry into the electoral process and to produce a Bill and have it in this chamber in eight months. I think that is a tribute to the Ministers concerned, both Mick Young and Kim Beazley.
—And to the Committee.
—And to the Committee, but especially to those Ministers for getting this complex legislation through the House of Representatives and into this chamber in eight months. It is a tribute to them.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing I want to comment on in this Bill is the introduction of an independent electoral commission, which I think is well overdue. The problem with electoral laws in this country is that they have been subjected to partisan interference. This Bill seeks to have the running of the electoral process put in the hands of an independent commission. We are not talking about setting up a commission and putting a few Labor stooges in charge of it. If we read the fine detail of this Bill, it becomes quite clear that what we are about is a truly independent commission. I guess the one area in which one has to be independent is in drawing up the electoral boundaries. This Bill proposes that four individuals will carry out each redistribution in a State and later another two will be added to the appeal process.

I would like to mention the appeal process because in the past what has happened if people have been dissatisfied with a redistribution is that they have been able to write to the commissioners appealing against certain provisions. No one else got to see what appeals had gone in. There was no interchange or discussion of them. Whoever appealed simply wrote to the commissioners and their appeal was either upheld or dismissed. This led to interference in the redistribution process. It was quite strange that when the commissioners brought out their proposal on one redistribution affecting the seat of Lowe the then member for Lowe, Sir William McMahon, wrote to them and for all different reasons, pointed out that the seat was wrong. Two or three very strong Labor voting subdivisions were removed and two or three very strong Liberal voting subdivisions were inserted. That was all done without anyone else knowing about it. I do not criticise the fact that it was done but everyone should have known and had the right to appear before those redistribution commissioners and to say: 'Look, the real reason for these three subdivisions coming in and the other three coming out is not the shape of the river or the community of interest; it is the survival of the member'. If the redistribution commissioners had wanted to go ahead and continue to save Sir William McMahon, that would have been fair enough. But we should have had a debate about it.

The next area-this is an area of disagreement with the Liberal Party of Australia-is that this Bill does not provide for redistributions to come back to this chamber. It provides, as does the South Australian and Victorian legislation, for the decision on the boundaries to be made independently and to be gazetted without reference to this institution. People ask why, because Sir John Carrick and others claim in this debate and elsewhere that there has never been a crook redistribution. I must say that, in the last 21 years, twice redistributions have been rejected. In 1962 all six States were distributed, and the proposals were knocked back in the other chamber by a combination of the Australian Labor Party and the National Party of Australia. The other night I had a sense of deja vu about that. Those parties knocked it back simply because they were getting a bad deal out of it. That was when the whole move to break the nexus started. It was not for any reason of principle that the National Party and the Labor Party combined to knock over the 1962 redistribution. Menzies, whose speech was a masterpiece, ended up by simply saying 'This Bill is dead' and sitting down.

In 1975 six redistributions were completed. Every one of those was knocked back in this chamber for different reasons. If they were genuine redistributions-and people say there has never been a crook one-why were there reasons for all six to be knocked back on that occasion? I interpolate here that the Victorian boundaries were knocked back and two years later the Fraser Government had them redrawn. I can tell honourable senators which set of boundaries I liked. It was the 1977 set. It was far more favourable to the Labor Party than the 1975 set. But as long as parliament is allowed to interfere with electoral boundaries there will be crook boundaries and political interference. When self-interest is involved politicians cannot resist minor tampering with the boundaries. Indeed, one of the most capable members of this chamber could not resist trying to tamper with the names of certain seats and he has been in political exile ever since. If anything, this Bill is designed to save him, our current Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley), and maybe a potential Special Minister of State, from the temptation of trying to interfere in redistributions.

Once the distribution commissioners make their decision it will be final after the appeal process. Some people may be suspicious of independent commissioners. I will relate very quickly the Victorian experience in the last few weeks. There has been a move, which was agreed to by the Labor Party and the Liberal Party, to have an independent commission in Victoria. That commission has redrawn the boundaries. All parties profess to be happy with them. Probably the result of the distribution will be that Labor gains three seats and the Liberal Party four . The Labor Party would have been much happier picking up the whole seven new seats but we went through the independent process and we have copped the results even though they are not as favourable as some people in the Labor Party would have hoped.

The next area of the Bill on which I want to touch-no one else has done so yet but I will not spend long on it-is the problem of elections at large. There is a problem in our Constitution that, if States get out of kilter in terms of their representation, we have to have elections at large. No one really went into the details of the consequences of that. There are two basic propositions if we do not legislate on it. One is that in any State affected there could be a proportional representation system one-off. I do not think the Australian Democrats, who support proportional representation, would want a one-off exercise when it does not exist in any State in Australia. Alternatively, we could have a winner take all situation. That would be like the old Senate block voting system where every candidate of a particular party would win or lose. That is a system we would favour in Victoria when the ticket is headed by Bob Hawke, but I am not so sure that we would always be in favour of that system. So to avoid a major constitutional crisis we have written into this legislation at least some temporary provisions that provide for a very temporary quick redistribution in the case where an election at large could be needed. I do not purport to say that it is a perfect solution. It is a temporary patch-up solution that will at least head off any future disaster. I am pleased to say that those measures have received bipartisan support. We are really talking about unknown waters that everyone wants to avoid.

Another aspect that has caused some controversy is our recommendation for 6 o' clock closing of the polls. I do not want to anticipate debate on an amendment later today other than to say that objections to 6 o'clock closing have always been voiced when it has been brought up. But the fears have never really come to fruition. In 1979 the Liberal Party in Victoria introduced six o'clock closing and people said: 'This could be a disaster. Hundreds of people will miss out on votes and it will discriminate against a whole range of people'. I did not receive one complaint about it. I am usually the one who is given the task of educating scrutineers across the State. At every one of the meetings I went to to educate the scrutineers I said: 'I want it reported to me if any one tries to vote after 6 o'clock'. I wanted to see whether it was a problem. I did not get one piece of feedback to suggest that any person missed out on a vote in 1979, or again in 1982, through the bringing about of 6 o'clock closing. It has been in existence in Queensland for 50 years and it has operated well in New South Wales and Victorian State elections. It is cost effective. It reduces the cost of elections and I know that those opposite are so anxious to do that. They did not want more parliamentarians or anything else. They should be very anxious to support that measure.

I move to another area which has always been almost an obsession of mine; that is, postal voting. In this Bill we make three major provisions to get around some of the problems of postal voting. In my view the major problem with postal voting has been the perverting of the electoral system by political machines that go out and garner postal votes irrespective of the wishes of the persons concerned. I pay tribute in this chamber to the Liberal Party's postal vote machine over the years. In Victoria it has taken us years to build up a comparable machine. I am pleased to say that we have finally done it. But why should we have to? Why should the old people be preyed upon for their vote with the methods that have been used in the past? I do not believe that they should be pressured into voting in a particular way, especially those in nursing homes.

The alternatives we have put up are threefold: Firstly, we provide for the automatic dispatch of application forms for postal votes to people on a register , that is, people who regularly apply for postal votes; secondly, we provide for mobile polling booths in hospitals and nursing homes; thirdly, we tighten up the restrictions about witnesses going to homes in order just to witness postal vote application forms. Of course, these will be subject to debate at the Committee stage, but we must take action to stamp out abuses of postal voting. I note that the point about witnesses not being able to attend an elector's home unless given written permission was put into the Electoral Act in Victoria by the Liberal Party. I note also with interest the division that again occurs, that what is good for the Liberal Party in Victoria does not seem to be good for the Liberal Party nationally.

I just comment on the question of party names on ballot papers, because that is a reform that we are introducing. It is not one that advantages the Labor Party, incidentally, but it helps the electors to determine which candidates they are voting for. We have a capacity basically to man every booth in Australia, barring some very small rural booths. So our how to vote cards are there and the electorate finds out who our candidates are. It does not really help the National Party, because that party mans all its booths, and the same applies to the Liberal Party; but it will help minority parties. I am not known as one to go around pressing the case for minority parties, but it is the electors' right to know who they are voting for and which party those candidates represent; so if anything, this is one of the bonuses in the legislation for the Democrats and for other minority groups. But it is really not derived out of any inherent sympathy that we have for minority groups; it is just that the electors have the right to know which party they are voting for.

While I am on the subject of candidates' names on ballot papers, I should mention that we have introduced a long overdue reform-a draw for position on the ballot paper. This is not the perfect solution to eliminating the donkey vote. Maybe the perfect solution is the rotation of names on ballot papers throughout the whole voting process. But the problem with that is that it would introduce far too many informal votes. Therefore, we go for a draw for position. All that it really does it prevent parties from cashing in on the positions, because they do not know the outcome beforehand. It would be no use running Senator Boswell in Wide Bay, for instance, because it would not be known whether he would get the donkey vote. Much analysis has been done of the House of Representatives and of legislative assemblies to prove that a disproportionate number of people whose names start with the letters A, B or C get endorsed for seats. I have used before, and I must use again, the classic example in my electorate, where I live . The sitting Liberal member between 1975 and 1980 had a name which started with A. He was chosen because the name of the incumbent candidate started with C. It took us five years to dig him out of that electorate, but lo and behold, there was a pre-selection for Bruce, a key marginal seat, and he wins again. I am sure that it is because his name starts with A. If anyone can think of any other reason for his pre-selection, would they please let me know, because I have seen no other quality and no other ability exhibited that would possibly suggest to me that he should be picked above other candidates.

I qualify that statement by saying that I am not attacking the Liberal Party for cashing in on the donkey vote. Every party does it. But if one does not know beforehand where a candidate's name will be on the ballot paper, one will tend to pick the best candidate and take one's chances.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you estimate that it means as a percentage in a doubtful electorate?

—It is very hard to estimate. It varies between about 0.5 per cent and one per cent. It is most noticeable that where an Australian Democrats candidate runs. When there are no how to vote cards in terms of absentee votes one will find that Democrats can poll up to 20 per cent of the vote, double their normal vote in the absentees. That proves that there is a donkey vote, especially in the absence of the how to vote cards.

SPEECH.PARA: I now comment on the closing of the rolls and the problems that that caused in the last election. The rolls were closed about 24 hours after the election was announced. In this legislation it is proposed that the rolls cannot close until seven days after the issue of the writs. Again, that is attracting bipartisan support. It will be there and it will not disadvantage any group in the future. For five working days people will be able to enrol at their convenience. We know that people do not think in advance. If they have moved, they think of getting on the roll only when an election is announced. We shall never have again anything up to a couple of hundred thousands people excluded from voting.

We also try to include more people on the roll than have ever been on it previously. Itinerant voters have never had a chance to be on the roll because they never have an address from which to enrol. This legislation gives them the chance to come on to the roll, either at their last place of abode or in the electorate in which they were born. As well as that, people who are overseas will have a far greater opportunity now under this legislation to stay on the roll and not be debarred from voting. Automatically they can stay on the roll for three years after they have left this country, and then, if they apply to stay on the roll after the three years, still being overseas, they are automatically granted the ability to remain on the roll. Finally, at long last we have made voting compulsory for Aboriginals. This is long overdue. It was a form of inverted racism which allowed them to have the luxury of deciding whether to be enrolled. If we are to have equality in our society, we should have equality of responsibility, and compulsory enrolment for Aboriginals is long overdue.

I come to some of the more substantive parts of the legislation which have caused some disquiet amongst the conservatives. The first one is the question of disclosure. This legislation requires that donations to political parties be disclosed if they are over $1,000 to the central party or $200 to candidates. It is interesting that this matter has aroused such opposition from the Liberal Party. The Liberals have always taken the attitude that donations are a private matter. I believe that the public has a right to know who is donating to political parties. I do not allege that there is undue influence over political parties, but as long as the prospect is there for that to occur, there should be disclosure.

Setting the figure at $1,000 was not easy. The National Party's federal submission suggested $10,000. It suggested, in writing, that it should be $10, 000 because one could not buy any influence for anything less. I do not know what the National Party judges that on, but it is there in writing; maybe it is based on experience, maybe just speculation. I must say that the various State directors of the National Party were somewhat shocked when they read that statement. We have set the figures at $1,000 and $200. In some ways it is guesswork. We shall see how it works. The Act will be amended if it does not work or if people can get around it. There is no foolproof way of ensuring that all donations are declared, but this will act as an inhibitor.

TALK.START.PARA: —You exclude all donations.
—Yes, there is no way in which all donations can be declared in our view.
—Why not?

—Because there are ways around it, by using front organisations and everything else. There will always be a way round it, but what the legislation does is to set down at least what the moral principles are in politics, and if people want to break them, they can take the consequences if they get caught. Senator Peter Baume said that one of the problems with this is that retaliatory action can be taken against the donors. It occurs to me that in a certain political party, unnamed, retaliatory action is taken if one does not donate. I am not referring to the Liberal Party and I am not referring to the National Party in any other State but Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of public funding is related to disclosure up to a point. Some honourable senators opposite have said, 'You should not dip into taxpayers' money to fund election campaigns'. What do they think they do already? What about the VIP planes? They are paid a salary throughout the election period. They use their telephones for electioneering. Let them not tell me that they do not do that. There are heaps of government resources that are marshalled behind political parties. All that this legislation is doing is making it very honest. We are saying: 'We shall allocate so much money to campaigning'. It will probably double the amount spent by government on campaigning, because already probably $8m, $9m or $10m is spent in supporting political campaigns in this country.

I believe that it is necessary to fund political parties, because that lessens the chance of corruption. It lessens the dependence of political parties on donations and on donors. It frees political parties from having to go out and sell their soul because they simply need the money to compete in the system. Secondly, it enables political parties to compete on a more equal level. There is a cut-off point above which political parties can survive out there, even if they do not have equality of funding; but if they fall below that, they have no chance. The beneficiaries in this competitive thing will clearly be the Labor Party and the Democrats, because we have not been able to compete with the amount of money spent by the conservative parties. It has not been a fair electoral process since 1972. Just occasionally the system reverses itself. In 1981 the Liberals in the State elction in New South Wales were disadvantaged in the spending, I think, and they got steamrolled in that election. The Labor Party absolutely murdered them and spent a lot more money. That was not fair, either. Elections should be made more competitive.

Also, we have this rather remarkable thing that the Liberals are opposed to public funding in principle. I must say that the National Party went one step further. It said it was opposed not only in principle but also morally. But both groups will accept the money. 'What price principle'? I ask honourable senators. What the Liberals are really saying is that for $3m they will sell out their principle. We have established what the Liberal Party is and what its price is.

I also mention a related matter which is the declaration of expenditure. The Harders Committee of Inquiry into the Disclosure of Electoral Expenses, which the Liberal Party commissioned to look into that matter, has reported and this Bill basically encompasses most of its recommendations. Nearly all expenditure should be stated by candidates and political parties, and I think that is long overdue. I have some sympathy with Senator Macklin's point that we should also be looking at limiting campaign expenditure, but in the time frame that the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform had it was a matter that we could not tackle. It is a very difficult problem to try to contain electoral expenditure via legislation, to put ceilings on it, because it is almost as easy to dodge as paying taxes in this country, or it has been up to this time. But it is a matter that we will have to look at in future. No one, no political party, wants campaign costs to spiral any higher than they are at the moment.

I move on to the question of list voting, because that has excited some comment , especially by Senator Bjelke-Petersen who preceded me. I suggest to her that out of self-interest the Opposition look at that because one of the great problems between the coalition parties in Queensland is the lack of tightness of preferences. If there was list voting all that squabbling between the Liberals and the Nationals could go on but at no cost because they could register their how to vote cards and tighten up the exchange of preferences.

TALK.START.PARA: —And belt hell out of each other.

—And belt hell out of each other. They could entertain the whole country and not at a cost to themselves. But, unfortunately, for once the Nationals are not perceptive enough to see where their own self-interest lies. I must say that it is a first for me. Why introduce list voting? I think Senator Maguire has outlined the reasons and I will therefore be brief in putting my reasons forward. It is clear to us from the 1977 study into informal voting at Senate elections that 77 per cent of those who vote informally have tried to fill out their ballot papers to some extent. They have put a '1' in a square and then the system has beaten them. That effectively means that the complexity of the system is defeating them. Senator Peter Baume comes in here and says: 'I'd like to pay tribute to the Australian people in that 90 per cent of them can get it right'. I suggest to the Senate that it is a function of his profession that a 90 per cent success rate is fair enough. But I think we should try to make the system 100 per cent successful. If we can make it 100 per cent right we must go for it. I think the list voting system will probably be 97 or 98 per cent right.

SPEECH.PARA: The other study that was interesting was the 1983 study that the Electoral Committee commissioned to show where the mistakes occurred. In many cases people were putting down two No. 44s or two No. 45s and were having their votes declared informal. Their intention was clear. Their immediate set of preferences was clear. It was only when they got right to the tail end of the vote that they were excluded. I think list voting will go a long way to fixing that up, as will the other amendments to the definition of what is a formal or informal vote. I will not go into any detail on them because a Liberal amendment and a Democrat amendment relate to when a vote becomes informal. Unfortunately, at this stage, there is no uniformity of view between the three parties here as to what constitutes a formal vote. I also add that in a spirit of consensus we allow in this legislation for a split vote to occur, for a political party to register its vote to go either way. There is some doubt constitutionally about that particular clause so we have put in another clause that says that the vote will remain valid to the point at which it becomes unconstitutional. In effect it will have the same result as splitting the vote.

I will mention three or four very minor points that are in the Bill before I finish. Firstly, we tackled the question of the death of a House of Representatives candidate. At the moment if a House of Representatives candidate drops dead five minutes before the close of nominations the election proceeds. If he drops dead five minutes after the nominations close, there is a new election. We propose that if a candidate who is actually nominated dies, the nomination period will be extended by a day. I think that solves the problem for political parties in getting a new candidate into the field. We would have liked , of course, to have tackled the problem of the death of a Senate candidate. That is a very difficult problem because the Constitution says that candidates shall be directly chosen by the people. There is no constitutional way we could come up with a solution other than merely to suggest that parties should run an extra candidate in case one of their candidates drops dead.

A second area that runs right through this legislation-it has attracted bipartisan support and we are grateful for that-is the extra aid for the handicapped, the identification of polling booths that are accessible to the handicapped and allowing quadriplegics to vote by post by just making their marks. All those sorts of reforms are in the legislation and they have attracted support from all parties. We have allowed for voting in Antarctica in a very complicated way. It takes about eight pages of this Bill, unfortunately, but at least the 100-odd people in Antarctica will be able to vote. Probably through all the effort we have made they will vote 50:50 and no one will get any benefit out of it. Nevertheless, they have felt very frustrated being stuck down in Antarctica and not being able to vote. I want to repeat a point about the Territories that I made the other day by way of interjection. No one is in favour of rorting Territory representation in this place or the other place. The Electoral Reform Committee at some stage will look at legislative measures to prevent any expanding of seats in the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory or anywhere else. That is essential because that would create a constitutional and political crisis in this country that we do not need.

Another point that I suppose has created some controversy is the ability of people to vote anywhere in their own divisions. Senator Sir John Carrick and I have had many arguments over that. I suggest that the reason we introduced it was not to rort the system-I do not think that accusation has been made-but to do away with the problem of absentee voting within a division. It creates enormous clerical problems during elections and it creates a cluttering up of the polling booths. In this day of computer technology there should be no problem at all with people voting anywhere within a division. The argument is put up that that allows multiple voting but I am afraid the opportunity is already there for that and it has not been exercised. No evidence of multiple voting in any electorates in Australia at a Federal level has come to anyone's attention. For instance, in my own subdivision where I live there are seven polling booths, so I presume someone could go around to each one of them and-

TALK.START.PARA: —Those early voters.

—Yes, they could vote early and vote often, but they get picked up in the reconciliation and there is no evidence that they do it, where there are, say, seven or eight polling booths within a subdivision. So I think the assertion that it will occur in a division is ridiculous. We have also outlawed multiple nominations. There is some disputation about this but I think people have to make up their minds which seats they want to run for. Changing their names by deed poll, like Mr Aussie-Stone did and then nominating over 13 electorates seems to me ridiculous, especially as in a spirit of consensus we have all agreed not to put up the level of deposit to a horrendous level. I say in conclusion that this legislation is the most comprehensive introduced since 1918. I think it deserves the support of every member of this chamber. Again, I compliment the Ministers responsible for this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in the debate in the second reading debate on the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill 1983. It is a pleasure to follow Senator Robert Ray. This Bill has obviously been a labour of love to him and his contribution today to the debate has been most worth while. Mr Deputy President, there can be little argument with the proposition expressed by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) at the end of his second reading speech that Australia needs an electoral system which serves the people well. For a democracy to function properly those who live in that democracy must perceive the political process as one in which their participation has some meaning and purpose. Changes to our electoral system which have as their objective the maintenance or enhancement of that confidence in the electoral process are therefore deserving of support. In this broad sense the general thrust of this Bill has my support. As the Minister has noticed, this legislation represents the first major overhaul of Australia's electoral laws in 65 years. It has given an opportunity to tidy up the Commonwealth Electoral Act through the consolidation of some disparate electoral legislation, the updating of a number of outmoded provisions and the removing of certain anomalies.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also makes changes to enrolment and voting procedures which will hopefully improve the accessibility of certain disadvantaged groups to vote and facilitate greater access to voting rights. It makes many other changes which I refer to as administrative and mechanical, most of which have been outlined by Senator Robert Ray in the preceding speech. I commend them, but will not go through them again.

In one sense this Bill is a response to the perceived need for the political process to be more responsive to the electorate. Over recent years it has become increasingly apparent that a growing section of our society has lost faith in its ability to influence the political life of this country. To the extent that this Bill meets such an important objective and to the extent that it will encourage greater confidence in our electoral system, it has my support.

However, the Bill is inherently contradictory in its approach to seeking wider public confidence in the system. There are provisions which, if implemented, will in fact discourage interest in and increase cynicism about our political system. The most notable of these and the area which I wish to concentrate upon in the short time available is the Government's intention to institute a system whereby political parties will be registered and through that registration become eligible for public financing of their election campaigns, subject to the requirement that private donations over certain amounts are disclosed. Such a system will have a dramatic and negative impact in achieving the Government's laudable objective of widening people's access to and confidence in the political process in Australia.

Debate on the issue of public funding is now no stranger to the Australian political system. Public funding has been introduced in New South Wales in the past few years and has been part of the Australian Labor Party's electoral reform subject matter for the past decade. The issue was canvassed by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. I note the view of the majority that:

The financing of political parties and elections has become a worldwide issue of major political concern in recent years. Most democracies have adopted schemes to fund publicly the political process without the dire consequences predicted by its opponents and a commission in the United Kingdom has recommended in its favour.

The argument for a system of public funding in Australia-in some ways I think it could more fairly be called an argument for additional public funding-appears to have been presented on the basis of four propositions. The first is that political parties form the focus of political life in Australia and, therefore, are deserving of public financial support. Secondly, the decline in confidence in the political system has been brought about by a perception that political parties rely too heavily for their support on too few people and organisations with the capacity to influence political decisions through financial donations. Thirdly, because some parties are able to command greater access to provide funds than others, unequal opportunities exist, it is said, for parties to present adequately their policies for public scrutiny and decision. Fourthly, systems of public funding of political parties and candidates operate in a number of democratic systems and Australia, by adopting a like system, would merely be following an established trend. I wish to answer each of these propositions in the course of my contribution.

The first point which needs to be addressed is the question of public funds flowing to political parties as they form the focus of political life in Australia. Certainly, in examining the question of political funding, the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform pointed, correctly I believe, the central role played by political parties in the democratic process. The Committee noted:

. . . that political parties play a vital role in the working of democratic governments. Indeed, one of the central characteristics of democracy is that there should be parties competing for the right to govern.

It is then asserted that, as parties are essential to democracy and as money is essential to parties and given the massive escalation in campaign costs, political parties are not receiving sufficient money to carry out their functions effectively. Such an argument was, for example, a principle line of reasoning in the report of the Houghton Committee in Britain. It is also an argument which often includes the assertion that political parties, while essential to democracy, are declining in public esteem, a trend which could be reversed only by the provision of subsidies, a position I would have thought particularly difficult to maintain.
It is true that campaigns have become expensive and that, as the Minister in his second reading speech said, public funding would help:
. . . counter the problem created by the mounting costs of political campaigning due to the increased use of television as a medium of communication.

But is that how the public purse should be spent? Assistance for political campaigns involves politicans subsidising their election expenses at the taxpayers expense. What is more, the allocation of funds requires the assigning of priorities. It is unlikely that the public respect for parties will therefore increase by a decision of politicians to assign their parties a higher priority than other obvious social needs. Respect for political parties will not be helped if other organisations with some claim to serve the public interest are denied government assistance with the parties receiving their subsidies. Furthermore, it is quite possible that the popular status of parties will be weakened by a party's greater reliance on public funds which has the potential to undermine the historical dependence of parties upon voluntary support.

One of the great strengths of the system we have, I suggest, has been that our parties are essentially voluntary organisations which have on the whole remained dependent for support provided by voluntary donations and voluntary manpower, particularly at election time. As voluntary organisations, political parties in Australia existed on their ability to attract support for the perceived merits of their respective policies. People have been accorded the same freedom to offer their personal support in the same way as they have been accorded their freedom to cast a vote. One of the great dangers inherent in the system of public funding for political parties is that such a system contains the potential to detract from the essentially voluntary nature of political activity . Furthermore, access to public funds will move political parties to a greater association with the state than with their supporters whose views the party ostensibly represents. Consequently, public funding has the potential not only to isolate the party from traditional support but also to institutionalise it within the structure of the State.

I move to the second argument put by the Minister, namely, that public funding and disclosure can be justified in that they will help to eliminate corruption by removing an election, and thus Parliament itself, from being seen as a commodity which can be purchased by the highest bidder. Such arguments were, in fact, used in setting up public funding schemes in places such as Quebec, Italy and to some extent the United States, all of which were established in the wake of scandals involving campaign activities. Those who lean heavily on this argument rely, in particular, on analogies with the Watergate scandal. Another argument connected with this put the proposition that access to public funds makes political parties or candidates less dependent on big subscribers and interest groups. Coupled with the requirement of public disclosure, political parties would therefore not have to trim their sails to the demands imposed by large contributers to party funds seeking their quid pro quo.

However, nowhere in the Minister's second reading speech or in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform is convincing evidence provided that clearly demonstrates that subsidies can eliminate or minimise corruption or that they have done so. In fact, it could be argued that subsidies and the availability of large amounts of public money may open up new means to pursue corrupt activities. Moreover, surely the Government could have looked at alternative means of weakening the influence of interest groups which could have encouraged greater individual involvement. I refer to such measures as limited forms of aid based, for example, on the United States practice of tax deductibility, or the provision of matching grants for money raised by small donations which would not only help limit the power of interest groups but also encourage parties to seek out greater numbers of individual supporters. It is a disappointment that the Government has not proceeded in that direction.

The third argument concerns the need to equalise political opportunities between those parties and candidates that are successful at generating private financial support and those that are not. Without that, it is said, there will be unequal opportunities for parties adequately to present their policies to the electorate. The Minister said in his second reading speech:
Public funding ensures that different parties offering themselves for election have an equal opportunity to present their policies to the electorate.

That is, of course, nonsense. There is no suggestion that, for example, the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats will receive the same funding out of this proposed system. The Minister continued:
Without it, worthy parties and candidates might not be able to afford the considerable sums necessary to make their policies known.

The most worthy might be an independent candidate who obviously will get very limited financial support because he is not attracting the vote that is automatically attracted to a party. So there is no link with worth as such. Contrary to the Government's assertion, it might also be said that the provision of assistance in order to equalise the opportunities of the successful and unsuccessful fund raisers discriminates against the successful and subsidises ineptitude.

In any event, where is the evidence that equal funding will give equal electoral opportunity? I believe it can be argued that incumbency of political office is just as decisive to an election campaign and result as financial resources. As has been said by others in the debate, members of Parliament enjoy significant advantages over rivals due to our entitlements of office. If the argument of political equality of opportunity is taken to its logical conclusion , advocates of public funding would first need to look at providing political rivals with equal access to such advantages. What of the role of such massive interest groups as the union movement? Media control in too few hands might also be just as decisive as any provision of funds. I have no doubt that editorials are more influential in moulding public opinion than paid advertisements.

Fourthly, it appears from both the Minister's second reading speech and the majority conclusions of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform that the operation of public funding schemes in other democratic countries provides a major reason for Australia to adopt public funding. The Minister mentioned a number of countries such as Austria, West Germany, France Israel, Japan, Canada, the United States and others, all of which operate an electoral system based on public funding and disclosure. However, the fact that similar systems may exist elsewhere does not automatically transpose any real apparent advantages of such a system to Australia. Australia, it should be remembered, has a proud tradition of progressive electoral reform. It led the world in the establishment of the secret ballot, parliamentary elections, the abolition of the property vote and the granting of female suffrage. I suggest that, given such a tradition, it appears passing strange that we are now asked to adopt a system justified in part because other countries are doing it.

What is apparently overlooked by those who argue the case for political funding based on its prevalence overseas is the major difference between the role of political parties in Australia and in other democracies. As voting is not compulsory in practically all countries now operating under a system of public funding disclosure, political parties are provided with public financial support to help get the vote out. Public funding is justified in this regard as direct assistance to the democratic process of voting. Australia, having a system of compulsory voting, remains rare among democracies. Political parties, therefore, serve no formal civic function similar to that of, say, West German political parties whose role as political educators has been recognised and paid for publicly since the 1950s. In Australia, voting at elections will result in 90 to 95 per cent of eligible voters casting votes. The vote in Australia is assured. Why should the public subsidise political parties to convince them that they should vote in a certain manner?

I must briefly make a comment about the corollary of public funding, that is, disclosure of financial donations. As has been said by others, this Bill provides that a donation of $1,000 to a party must be disclosed. The only possibly valid argument for this is that with such sums of money it may be possible to buy support. Anyone who has been around Australian politics for a while knows that is ridiculous. The minimum estimates for the last Federal election, according to the Minister's speech were $12m. If the major parties must raise $4m or $5m, it is therefore obvious that if political control or influence is to come through donations one must be talking of very big sums of money. I think there is an argument that it is in Australia's best interests to deter very large payments to political parties. I have some sympathy with the political disclosure of such sums, but for comparatively small to medium sums I find the arguments against disclosure far more persuasive. Public disclosure is a deterrent against the right to contribute financially in support of one's political beliefs. I believe it is a right to be preserved and encouraged. Those who wish so to contribute should not have to run the risk of having their names appear on what has been referred to by others as hit lists. Failure to contribute to both sides should not incur risks and, similarly, failure to contribute at all should not be made public and certainly should be no business of parliamentarians.

Whereas I believe a need exists to restore public confidence in the political process, on the major question of public funding I regret that my analysis is that it will not positively serve the objective of increasing public confidence or serve to widen public participation. Rather, I suggest the causes of the currently accepted public cynicism might better be found in such areas as broken promises by political leaders and the standard of behaviour of parliamentarians. Although they are not too bad in this chamber the personal abuse that one witnesses in the other place at Question Time and the turning of the Parliament into a circus to which the crowds gather for entertainment can lead only to this growing cynicism of the political process. Additionally, the political process appearing too distant from people is relevant and we can contribute to overcoming that with our Senate committee system. The discipline of political parties has all but destroyed the concept of representation by individual members, and there are obvious answers in that area. Another cause is Prime Ministers appearing to base decisions on purely opportunistic grounds, for example, holding double dissolutions on deadlock Bills with no intention of reintroducing those Bills, or going to the people a year before the completion of a full term for reasons purely of perceived electoral advantage. They are a part of the reason politicians and the political process are held in low esteem.

Clearly the mechanics of the electoral system are imporant, and this Bill improves such mechanics. They are matters identified, as I indicated earlier, and I commend the Joint Select Committee on its work in that area. I commend the Government for introducing remedies to these accepted mechanical matters. The Government's attempt to justify public funding as another major reform to rank with secret ballots, the abolition of the property vote and female suffrage, is to mislead the public again and will serve to build upon the disillusion already too evident in the community at large.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill 1983, which is the result of an inquiry and report by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. First, may I pay tribute to the work of that Committee and its Chairman. The Committee worked very hard during the recess and came down with a report. Although many of us may not agree with some aspect of that report, most of us agree with most aspects of it. The Chairman, Dr Klugman, quite obviously tackled his task with the view that electoral reform should, as far as is possible, reflect the various disparate views of practising politicians as well as other groups and individuals in the community who are most interested in our democratic system of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Subsequently, a great deal of work has been done by the Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley) and by his officers in preparing the Bill that we are now debating. Much of the debate, of course, has concentrated on some of the perceived defects in this legislation. Because of the time constraints that apply at this time of the year that approach has probably been necessary. One need not repeat in glowing terms the comments of those who support the legislation. Indeed, all of my remarks tonight will relate to some of the defects in the legislation. However, I do not wish that to be interpreted as meaning that I am opposed to the bulk of this legislation and to the many needed reforms that are contained in it.

I want to correct a suggestion that was made by an earlier speaker-I am not sure who it was-that the Senate had not passed motions seeking to establish a joint select committee to look at electoral matters. I can recall that in 1981 in a vote of 28 to 27 in this chamber I made up the twenty-eighth vote in support of a then Opposition motion to have an inquiry into the electoral system . I believed then that such an inquiry was necessary and I am pleased that it has been undertaken. Mind you, I supported the establishment of such a committee on the basis that its terms of reference included not only the question of funding but also the question of free time for the broadcasting of election material on the then Australian Broadcasting Commission. Unfortunately, the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform apparently did not have the time to address itself to those aspects and has sought the authority of the Parliament to consider matters such as that. I will be most interested to see its report on such matters.

My concern about this measure is that it will really entrench the party system in this Parliament, particularly in the Senate, at the expense of Independents. I suppose that in that sense I am the odd man out because I happen to be the only Independent in the Parliament. Senator Hill, who was the last speaker before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, also made that point.
