TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 33, clause 9, proposed new sub-section 25Z (1), line 38, after ''this sub-section'', insert '', sub-section 25ZBA (2)''.
(2) Page 35, Clause 9, proposed new sub-section 25ZB (2), lines 21 to 24, leave out the proposed sub-section, insert the following new sub-section:
'' '(2) The Minister shall cause copies of the suggestions, comments, proposed redistribution, reasons, objections and determinations referred to in sub- section (1)-
(a) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 5 sitting days of that House after he receives a copy of them; or

(b) if either House of the Parliament has adjourned for a period longer than 14 days when the Minister receives the copies referred to in this sub-section-to be sent to the President of the Senate or the Speaker of the House of Representatives, as the case may be, or, if the President or the Speaker is not available, to the Deputy-President or the Deputy-Speaker, who shall forthwith give directions for their immediate circulation.''.
(3) Page 35, clause 9, after section 25ZB, insert the following new section:
Consideration of views expressed by either House of the Parliament

'' '25ZBA. (1) If, within 14 days after the copies referred to in sub-section 25ZB (2) have been laid before a House of the Parliament, or have been circulated, in accordance with that sub-section, that House passes a resolution expressing any view of that House concerning any matter contained in the copies, the Minister shall forward a copy of that resolution to the Electoral Commission , which shall forthwith refer it to the relevant augmented Electoral Commission.

'(2) An augmented Electoral Commission shall forthwith proceed to consider all views contained in a copy of a resolution referred to it under sub-section (1) and shall, as soon as practicable, but in any event before the expiration of the period of six weeks after it has received the copy of the resolution-
(a) complete its consideration of those views;
(b) decide whether or not any alteration of the relevant determination should be made as a result of its consideration of those views;

(c) If it decides that any such alteration should be made, make a fresh determination giving effect to those alterations and cause a copy of the fresh determination to be published forthwith in the Gazette; and

(d) record, in writing, its reasons for the decisions referred to in the foregoing paragraphs of this sub-section and, if any member of the augmented Electoral Commission disagrees with any such decision and wishes to have his reasons for disagreeing recorded, a statement of those reasons.

'(3) The Electoral Commission shall forthwith forward to the Minister a copy of every record made by an augmented Electoral Commission in accordance with sub- section (2) and a copy of any determination made in accordance with that sub- section, and the Minister shall cause copies of those documents to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 5 sitting days of that House after receipt of those documents by the Minister.''.

By moving these amendments the Opposition is seeking to bring the involvement of the Parliament back into the process of a redistribution which may take place in a State. I accept the thrust of much of what Senator Robert Ray said during his speech when he set out the arguments for removing the power of the Parliament to overturn a redistribution and when he spoke against the power of the Parliament to demand that a redistribution be altered. That is not at issue, and we are not returning to any consideration of that proposition. A different proposal is before the Committee. It is that after the augmented Electoral Commission has made a determination on a redistribution for a State or Territory and once it has been put forward by the Commission, the Parliament should have the opportunity in a formal sense to comment upon it.

Let me say that the thinking behind the amendments is that if the Parliament wished so to do, it could make comment. But if either House of the Parliament were to do this, the Australian Electoral Office would send that amendment back to the augmented Electoral Commission, which would need to consider it, but would not be required to act upon it. I accept the argument that an independent Commission should not be subject to parliamentary direction. We have therefore, constructed amendments Nos (2) and (3) to try to establish ways in which the Parliament might be allowed, within a short time, to receive the copies of the determination of the redistribution and to have a short time to consider them, and to provide that the augmented Electoral Commission should forthwith then proceed to consider the views of either House of the Parliament if the Parliament is so disposed. What we are seeking to do is to get the determination before the Parliament if the Parliament so wishes, to have any opinion then put back before the augmented Electoral Commission and let the augmented Electoral Commission then make what determination it will. It may decide that its original determination will stand-it may reject the view of the Parliament-or it may decide to take some kind of further action. Amendment No. (3) seeks to give it a capacity, if it wanted, to take further action but it places no requirement upon it to do so.

The reason that the amendments are in fact fairly long and complicated is that the circumstance might arise where the Parliament was in recess. Because considerations of time were worrying some people we had to get a mechanism by which the Parliament would first receive the new determination quickly, and secondly, the Senate, for example, might be recalled if there were a majority of senators who wished it to be recalled to consider that determination. We have attempted in these three amendments to establish a mechanism by which those processes might be carried out. It might be necessary, since this is one of the more significant amendments we are proposing, to answer any criticisms. At this stage having opened the subject up I invite comments upon it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add, very briefly, to Senator Peter Baume's remarks. These amendments do not seek, in any way, to give the Parliament any right to amend, reject or delay a redistribution . That is fundamental to its consideration. They do give the Parliament the right to look at the redistribution in a very limited period and to make comments if it so desires. If the Parliament is not sitting and it is not convened, the time elapses and the matter automatically goes back to the augmented Electoral Commission. If the Parliament is sitting and it does not wish to debate the matter, the time still runs.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole thrust of this matter is to allow a public debate if Parliament so desires and expressions of opinion. Those opinions, in due course, will come to the attention of the augmented Commission. That Commission will objectively evaluate them not being, in any way, influenced by them except by the force of argument, to accept or to reject at will. Nothing could be more common sense. The argument in the past has been that Parliament should not intervene because Parliament has, in the past, shown an ability to reject or to delay. That now is not part of the situation at all. The fundamental situation of principle is that Parliament, having appointed its statutory bodies, ought to have a report from its statutory body and ought to be able to examine that report inside the Parliament and comment on that report.

I think it is fundamental to all the statutory bodies that we set up that we should be able to examine, and examine quickly, the work that they do. There is no question whatsoever that undue influence would be exerted. It is not good enough to suggest that the public is part of the debate and has an understanding of the debate during the time of any appeals in the journey of the examination because, as all honourable senators know, the Press does not give any wide publicity to appeals. In any case, under the legislation the appeals may not necessarily be heard in public. So the one chance that the public has to hear the arguments for and against before a decision is made would be in a debate and a discussion in the Parliament itself. I think that the argument has total reason to it and I strongly commend it to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Australian Democrats are not unsympathetic to this amendment. However, we are still wrestling with some of the problems that have arisen in discussions which have taken place over the days preceding the Committee stage of the debate. I say first of all that essentially legislation is not able to bind the Parliament in terms of its deliberations or otherwise in relation to any report of any committee, independent or otherwise, which means that this Parliament is not able to be bound by this or any other legislation if it chooses to consider the interim report of the Australian Electoral Commission. Therefore, if this chamber or the other place were sitting they could take up the interim redistribution, debate it, pass a motion and send that resolution to the commissioners as an objection provided it fell within the parameters of the Act in terms of time. I am not sure, but as I read the Opposition's amendment, its time frame is that time frame set down in the Act. I think the time might be 14 days longer or it might be the same. Perhaps Senator Baume can clarify whether that period is the same period as is available for other people in the community in which to object.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point that concerns me relates to amendment No. (3) which states:

If, within 14 days after the copies referred to in sub-section 25ZB (2) have been laid before a House of the Parliament or have been circulated, in accordance with that sub-section, that House passes the resolution expressing any view of that House concerning any matter contained in the copies, the Minister shall forward a copy-

The clause continues. I wonder whether that wording-this might be a matter for the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans)-would require the House to meet. That is my concern. The actual wording seems to suggest that. Amendment No. (2) provides that if either House is not meeting within those 14 days or has adjourned for a period longer than 14 days, the President of the Senate would circulate such material as is referred to in the amendment to honourable senators. On reading amendment No. (3), I gained the impression that it might be possible-not being a lawyer I am not able to ascertain this fact-for the House to be given an opportunity to pass such a motion. If indeed the House has an opportunity to pass a motion doubtless it could be argued that the House has to meet. If the House has not met-going the next step down the track-I wonder whether some type of legal action might be taken to prevent the redistribution continuing. That is an initial concern in relation to those items.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a number of questions may be asked I intervene now to answer those posed by Senator Macklin. First, what we are talking about is how the Parliament might comment upon a redistribution, not a provisional redistribution. I do not want in any way to mislead my colleagues. We have tried to keep the time frame as short as we can, but a redistribution will take place quite infrequently. If there were a redistribution in 1984 there would possibly not be another redistribution until 1991. The intervening period could be as long as that.

SPEECH.PARA: The numbers of days and weeks for which we have provided in this amendment are not beyond negotiation if people think the periods specified are too long. If the full time were taken it might add eight weeks to the process. It might require 14 days for the Parliament to come together and I think a further period of six weeks is allowed. It is hoped that the process would take place more quickly, but that is absolutely the longest time it could take to allow the Parliament to make its views known and for the augmented Electoral Commission to respond. I do not want to mislead honourable senators. I think eight weeks could be added, but in terms of the importance of a redistribution and the relative infrequency of redistributions I think that time would be immaterial. In the event that a government was keen to get a redistribution through I think, that time being fixed and relatively brief, it could be worked into its planning.

I think I can answer the other question asked by Senator Macklin. We have written that amendment to permit but not to require the Parliament to meet. The circulation of the documents is designed to alert senators or members of the House of Representatives to the fact that the document is available. That is why we ask that it be circulated. The mechanism for the Houses to meet when Parliament is out of session is contained in a motion which the Senate passes at the end of every session. The motion provides a mechanism by which the Senate may be called together and it requires the support of an absolute majority of senators. Of course, I wondered whether that was necessary but, upon reflection, if we cannot get a majority of senators to support a motion there is no point in bringing the Parliament together. The requirement for recalling the Parliament is that a majority of senators must inform the President, Mr Chairman or whoever is acting in place of the President at the time of their support for that action . So I do not think that the amendment as written imposes any obligation on the Parliament to reconvene and I would be very surprised if it could be construed in that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not necessarily at all concerned with the technical aspects; rather I am concerned with the main point in this matter. I make one observation: The amendment, if accepted, will add at least two weeks to the time needed for the acceptance of any redistribution. The assumption that all six redistributions will come in at the one time is wrong; they will come in like Brown's cows with, I imagine, the Territories first, then Tasmania, then South Australia and Western Australia at about the same time, then probably Queensland and Victoria with New South Wales last. In light of the conditions of the augmented Electoral Commission to hear appeals, it may well be a method that could be used-I do not say that it would be-to string out this whole process over a number of months, thereby even halting a future Federal election. It could be used to that point.
—How do you make it a number of months?

—We would be adding two weeks to each of the six processes. Let us remember the voting provisions of the augmented Electoral Commission to hear appeals. Of the three members-the judge, the Chief Electoral Officer and the third member-two have to be present to agree to any change. The second and more fundamental point that I make is as follows: What necessarily gives parliamentarians a greater right than any other individuals in relation to the objection process, the suggestions? Why should parliamentarians have a greater right to have made known to that Commission their views, with the stamp and authority of the Parliament, than the right of some resident who happens to live on one side or another of a creek? We have set up an appeals process. Why should we, as parliamentarians, have a greater right than anyone else in that process? We can each put our views to that Commission. I do not see why we should have the imprimatur of government.

SPEECH.PARA: The third and, I think, the most damaging point is that we may never come to an agreement in this chamber about motions. But honourable senators can be sure that if there is anything that is not favourable to the government of the day, the other chamber will always put in a submission on this point, trying to fix it up and trying to use the imprimatur of parliament to do so. There is always a majority for one party in that chamber across the way. The Commission may well get motions on all six States trying to maximise the position of the ruling party. It is, in my view, a step that favours government rather than the parliament and should be rejected on those grounds.

In some ways, I oppose this more than I did the honest action of a parliamentary veto. I think I would have preferred to have a parliamentary veto over redistributions because to me it is a lot cleaner and a lot more honest approach. To have not so much parliamentary interference but parliamentary influence in a redistribution seems to me to be totally unfair and totally unnecessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that the latter point raised by Senator Robert Ray shows, unfortunately, that he has had little experience in this Parliament although he has a general interest in the whole subject. We have known, in the past, what happens when there is the power of veto. It causes great delays and great interference with redistributions. To suggest that a parliamentary veto is worse than having a right to comment is, to my mind, quite extraordinary. It seems to me that the proposal in this amendment is one which gives a particular right to the Parliament. Honourable senators may ask: Why should the Parliament have any more right than any individual? Of course, the Parliament has a body of experience in the workings of the electoral system and a considerable knowledge of the areas involved in these matters. It seems to me that parliamentarians should be encouraged to comment having debated the matter, which is the method used by the Parliament. It is true that any individual parliamentarian could comment and so forth. But it is desirable that there be debate and suggestions by either House.

SPEECH.PARA: The suggestion Senator Ray also made that this would add two weeks to each of the six processes is, to my mind, quite nonsensical because it would add two weeks altogether, that is all. It does not provide, therefore, any extensive delay. I suggest that the proposal is a sensible one. I also add to what Senator Baume said about the calling together of Parliament that just as Parliament provides at the end of each session for it to be called together, one may be sure that that absolutely will be done when it is known that a redistribution is about to be completed and about to come before the Parliament. People will therefore be waiting and looking for that. I suggest therefore, that both in its drafting and in its general principles, the amendment is a good idea and Parliament should not be totally excluded from the opportunity of having a reasoned debate and commenting on proposals for redistributions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government finds this amendment quite unacceptable partly, but not solely, for the reasons articulated by Senator Robert Ray with his usual formidable weight, intellectually, brought to bear on these matters. The proposed amendment would allow a House of parliament but no other person, organisation or body to make comments on the final determination of electoral boundaries. The augmented Australian Electoral Commission would be required to consider the comments thus made and, if it thought fit, could vary the determination. That is the proposal. The amendment, in the process though, would water down the principle of the independence of the redistribution process by imposing if not political control, certainly substantial political influence and would, in the process, give politicians very much more say in the redistribution process than ordinary members of the public.

SPEECH.PARA: Moreover, as Senator Ray said, it is not just politicians as politicians, but politicians of the ruling party who will have the most clout in this respect because, in the House of Representatives, it is only with the support of the ruling party that any motion is able to be framed. In the Senate it will depend upon the party or group of parties that can construct the majority of votes. Only such a party or coalition will be able to pass a resolution. So it gives a formidable extra impetus to those arguments coming in, in a one-sided way, from the chambers in question. The result in turn is that this amendment ultimately boils down simply to something which will allow politicians who put their arguments and lost them at the comment stage of the redistribution process to attempt then to dignify those arguments by hanging on to the coat tails of the prestige of the parliamentary institution and having a second bite at the same cherry.

There are other grounds for objection to this amendment. I express them in essentially technical terms rather than in those terms of high principle enunciated by Senator Ray. I put it this way. The way in which proposed new section 25ZBA is cast really leaves quite open ended the criteria to be applied by the augmented Electoral Commission in making its determination after the second round of comment has been given in the form of this proposed parliamentary resolution. The thing is constructed in such a way that it seems to me certainly very arguable that the criteria which can be put to the Commission as appropriate and the criteria which in turn can be applied by the Commission at this stage are not limited to those which are otherwise crucial in the Commission's deliberations. It does not seem to me to follow inexorably that the basic criteria to be applied pursuant to proposed new section 25Z, with all the elaborate and careful ways in which those criteria have been formulated, will necessarily be the criteria that will be applicable in this additional stage of the process now being proposed. If that is so, the Electoral Commission could start to embark, with the assistance of this pressure from, let us assume, the governing party of the day, on a process quite beyond that which the present framework of the legislation contemplates. That could go even further to the stage of producing a result which is unconstitutional. I remind the Senate that in McKinlay's case Justice Mason observed in the following terms:

It is perhaps conceivable that variations in the numbers of electors, or people in single member electorates, could become so grossly disproportionate as to raise a question whether an election held on boundaries so drawn would produce a House of Representatives composed of members directly chosen by the people of the Commonwealth-

as is required by section 24 of the Constitution. In short, the absence of specified criteria governing this stage of the determination process could produce a situation which would throw completely at odds the basic scheme of the legislation as it now stands and, what is worse, could create a situation in which the whole legislation and the whole process could be deemed by the High Court, applying the Mason principle, to be unconstitutional. For a variety of reasons, some of them technical but the most formidable being those that have been advanced by Senator Ray, I believe and the Government believes this proposal ought to be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my remarks to the points made by Senator Ray which the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has said are the formidable ones and to his final remark, which I find astonishing. First of all, Senator Ray put forward the argument that somehow or other, because the redistributions would be done separately and in an episodic way with Tasmania perhaps finishing first and New South Wales last, there would be six extensions of the time for a redistribution. That is absolutely wrong, because quite clearly the length of the redistribution will be the length of time taken to do the redistribution for the largest State. The processes would be concurrent, so point No. 1 must fall down. The argument that both the Attorney and Senator Robert Ray put was: 'Why should the Parliament have a particlular right that others do not have?' Indeed, the Attorney talked about a second bite for Parliament. He did not tell us when the first form of mastication by the Parliament occurred. Clearly, it has not occurred. Parliament has no chance as Parliament of commenting before this amendment is envisaged-
—What is Parliament other than the sum of the majority of its members in either place?

—That interjection is almost as fatuous as the final comment of the Attorney when he suggested that this procedure might be found unconstitutional in the High Court of Australia. The fact is that Parliament has no opportunity of dealing with the proposal of the commissioners, nor indeed of any interim proposals down the way, because such proposals are done fragmentarily by individuals or organisations making submissions at the State level. The one time when anybody sees the overall plan is the time when it is suggested here that the plan should be given to parliamentarians with a time limit upon it. It is wrong to say: 'Why should Parliament be just the precious body in that regard?' The very nature of Parliament is such that if there is such a discussion there will be public discussion; there will be public contact with parliamentarians-the ordinary osmotic process which goes on with every piece of legislation, with every process in this place-and Parliament will therefore have that opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: To suggest that there is some kind of extra pressure by Parliament is of course to ridicule the whole basis on which this Bill is built. The whole basis on which the Attorney and others envisage this process of the Australian Electoral Commission, the redistribution commissioners and the augmented Commission, is that they will be totally independent, objective people who will be there because they are capable of resisting outside pressures, of assessing information, judging it and making a judgment. Now, of course, something new is that somehow or other the Parliament may be able to threaten them, may be able to dominate them. If this is so, all the dollies fall over because, of course, they are found to have clay feet; they are not objective. Why should people not be threatened along the way by the party in power? Why should they not be dominated? Quite clearly that is a nonsense. All that is being asked is that the one opportunity that the public or anybody has to make a comment on the proposal should be an opportunity for the Parliament, within a limited time, without the Parliament having the right to reject, amend or delay. Why the Attorney would say that this would be a watering down, I do not know.

I found absolutely astonishing his final remarks, which I think I understood-he can correct me if I did not-and which suggested that, after the Parliament has made some suggestions, they might be taken up. The idea that the augmented Commission would bring about a resolution that would be considered unconstitutional must be essentially nonsense. At every step the augmented Commission, as well as the Redistribution Committee, is governed by the Act. It is governed by considerations in the Act. The final result must be put together by that augmented Commission within the framework of the Act. There is no way it could be a camel. There is no way that the augmented Commission could add something because somebody in the Parliament had said something. Let us put that argument completely out of sight.

I find it abolutely astonishing that the other argument-I think the arguments are put up just for debating purposes-is that the other chamber, which has a government majority, would therefore assert a government view. That is not the purpose. The whole purpose is that it would enable debate. Various suggestions would be made. Through Hansard, the debate would be made available to the augmented Commission.

But if the Government is going to suggest that the government of the day can, by debate in that chamber, threaten, dominate or use duress or undue influence on the augmented Commission why cannot the government of the day do that all the way along the process? The Government cannot have it both ways. If the government of the day has an influence it will exert that influence. If indeed, the commissions-the Redistribution Committee or the augmented Commission-at any stage along their journey allow themselves to be dominated by government they would then be dominated. The whole basis of this argument-it is one that we either accept or reject-is that these are grown people chosen because of their objectivity, because of their ability to make honest and objective judgments and because of their ability to resist and reject undue pressure. If they cannot do that they ought not to hold these positions.

Let us put this in one piece. We are not asking something special at all in this situation. We are asking that the Parliament, which has set up this Redistribution Committee and this augmented Commission and which has given the Commission the statutory right, should do what the Parliament does with all other statutory bodies. The Parliament should have the Commission's report before it and, if it wishes, it can comment upon that report. In so doing it can do something that cannot be done anywhere else in the whole of this redistribution process-enable the public outside to hear the to and fro of the argument, to read it in the Hansards and to judge for itself. There is an absolute responsibility on the Parliament to do this.

It is the one occasion on which the whole orchestration of the redistribution is viewed by the Parliament and the public. That happens at no other stage. At all other stages only individual segments are viewed. I think this is absolutely fundamental. There would be no undue delay at all in this situation. There would be no way of amending or rejecting. Indeed, by the very nature of the Government 's legislation, there would be no possibility of duress or undue influence by the Parliament. For the one and only time in the whole redistribution there would be a capacity for a complete look and a complete debate on the overall scene. Then it would be for the augmented Commission to pick up any views it thought were wise or to reject the lot at will. It would bring in its report without any other hinderance at all. I find the proposition to have absolute logic and common sense and I commend it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I feel that there is an advantage in the proposal that has been moved by the Opposition. That is, it makes it essential for the report of the Australian Electoral Commission to be laid before each House of Parliament within five sitting days of that House after the Minister receives a copy of the suggestions, comments, proposed redistribution, reasons, objections and determination referred to in sub-clause (1). Unless I am wrong- the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) will no doubt correct me immediately if I am-I do not see anything in the legislation before us which requires the Minister to lay those documents on the table. I can see some force in the argument advanced by Senator Robert Ray in respect of the government of the day utilising this proposed amendment to put some pressure, through a vote of parliament, on the Electoral Commission. I can see that argument, although the counter-argument would be, of course, that that having been done in public debate and before the glare of public gaze, the Commission would be entitled to fall over backwards to ensure that it was objective and was not seen to kowtow to the government of the day which may use its numbers to obtain a resolution through perhaps the House of Representatives or, indeed, through this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder whether it would not be appropriate for the Opposition to consider the inclusion of words such as 'and the relevant Hansard debate' after the word ' resolution' contained in the Opposition's amendment, so that not only would the resolution be forwarded to the Electoral Commission but also the relevant Hansard debate. The Commission would take into consideration the views contained in the resolution and those contained in the relevant Hansard debate. That would be going further than what is normally utilised by commissions or courts in formulating their decisions. That is certainly extending, far more than is now the case, the extrinsic aids to those determinations. Therefore, I would not propose that that amendment be moved to the Opposition's amendment. If this amendment were to be defeated, I would be happy if the Government would, either by guarantee given in the Parliament or by an appropriate amendment, make it obligatory for the Minister to table in the Parliament the relevant decisions, et cetera, of the Electoral Commission so that note could be taken of them and if necessary a debate could take place on them. That would meet the point that I raised at the dying stage of my contribution to the second reading debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Harradine's point is met in proposed new section 25ZB (2) on page 35 of the Bill , which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister shall cause copies of the suggestions, comments, proposed redistribution, reasons, objections and determination referred to in sub-section (1) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 5 sitting days of that House after he receives a copy of them.

So there is that formal opportunity for parliamentary debate at the completion of the redistribution process. I might add, for what it is worth, that there is in fact, as I read the Bill, an opportunity for the Parliament-the Parliament as distinct from the collection of individuals who make it up-to participate at an earlier stage in the redistribution process. Proposed new section 25V on page 31 states:
A person or organisation may, within the period of 14 days after the publication in the Gazette of the notice-
referred to earlier-
lodge with the Electoral Commission a written objection against the proposed redistribution.

That follows the notice of proposed redistribution stage of the proceedings. I believe that with the way that 'organisation' is defined at the beginning in terms of bodies corporate and at large, again it is arguable that the Parliament satisfies that description as an organisation which might have a corporate view to put to the Commission. But at that stage, where views and comments are being put by other people as well, it would not be in any way different from other people in terms of the timing or the weight given to such views.

Similarly, I refer to the general preliminary suggestions and comments stage provided for in proposed new section 25Q on page 28 of the Bill, which is quite open ended in its description of the kinds of people or organisations which might supply comments in response to the initial invitation of a redistribution committee for a State. So there is that series of opportunities for parliamentary input along the way. There is the requirement for tabling at the end of the day. For all the reasons advanced earlier, I believe this is an inappropriate further extension with which Senator Baume and Senator Sir John Carrick are belabouring us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the point quite clearly that the post facto tabling of the distribution plans is not, of course, comparable in any way to what this amendment envisages. To table the plans afterwards is only to enable the Parliament to have a debate which could have no effect at all. That is, the plans would have become operative, they would have become the law of the land, and the debate would be one that may have some relevance to some seven years hence. That in itself surely does not meet the point. The question is: Should the Parliament have the opportunity to have a debate when an overview is possible? To suggest, as the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) does, and I acknowledge it, that it might be possible to have a debate at some earlier stage is to raise two matters. First of all, one would have to have the debate in all sorts of episodic ways, if Senator Ray's six different problems were to occur. Secondly, we could never have that debate in the knowledge of the various objections made by the community and in the knowledge of the overall proposed plan by the augmented Electoral Commission. It is the ability of Parliament as a whole to look at the overall plan and to comment on it that is the key to this matter. Therefore I feel that the two points made by the Attorney are not basically relevant to the purposes of this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of the amendments which the Opposition believes is important to the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill.
—Unlike the rest of them.

—That is unnecessary. I just want to indicate that when the question is put we will be pressing this amendment. We have tried to devise a time frame which is brief. We have tried to devise a mechanism which keeps all executive authority with the Electoral Commission and not with the Parliament. We have tried to confine the role of the Parliament to one of making its views known. We have not attempted to give the Parliament any executive authority at all in this area. The criteria to which the Commission would have regard are laid down in the Act. I find it difficult to envisage how the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) could raise that as an objection. In the same way, because the Parliament has no executive authority and the executive authority for the redistribution rests with the Commission, I cannot see any valid argument to support the view that the eventual redistribution might be open to challenge because the Parliament had been allowed to express an opinion. The executive authority clearly rests with the Commission which will determine the redistribution as it thinks appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate two other points. No one has contended that parliamentarians could not have had an input earlier. We understand that, but we are seeking some chance to comment on the redistribution when it is made, to comment, but not to insist upon anything, to comment, if that is thought to be appropriate. We have all said during the second reading debate that as a matter of principle the electoral process is essential for the good functioning of our democracy. To be able to comment upon a redistribution is something that we believe can be good for the process. I indicate that the Opposition will be pressing this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having followed the debate I think it would be difficult for the Australian Democrats to support this amendment, despite our initial sympathy for the proposition. In the discussions I have had with Senator Peter Baume leading up to the Committee stage Amendment Bill I made it clear that we would be willing to look at a situation which did not extend the amount of time that would be taken in relation to the redistribution.
—Did not extend it unduly.

—Yes. I think that, despite that comments of Senator Missen, Senator Ray's point is indeed correct. Because we are looking at the augmented Electoral Commission and at a situation of discrete electoral redistributions in each State, the Parliament would have two weeks to consider each discrete redistribution, which could then accelerate for each State. The Parliament could get into a debate at the stage which is suggested in the amendment only at the point at which a redistribution report became available. Therefore, it would have to comment on the Tasmanian one at the point at which the Tasmanian one became available, and it could not wait until the New South Wales one was available. It must come in at that point and cause a delay because of the fact that it must go the augmented Electoral Commission, which would have to engage in a deliberation as required in these amendments before it could proceed-
—But isn't there a separate augmented Commission for Tasmania?

—No. This follows very closely the recommendations of the Chief Australian Electoral Officer, as does the vast bulk of this Bill. There are many areas in which he is required to involve himself. Now that this Parliament has passed the Representation Bill 1983, the amount of work involved in the initial redistribution could be very large. I think in those circumstances the type of scenario mapped out by Senator Robert Ray-I do not say it always would happen- could very well occur. That is a worry to us because we are very much concerned to stay within the parameters of time as outlined in the original legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I must admit that the point Senator Ray made in relation to the Government struck me with more force than had registered on me previously. Indeed because of the Representation Bill, this chamber will scarcely have a majority in the future if the type of predictions we have made hold true, as I believe they will . The one chamber of the Parliament we know will always have a majority of one party is the House of Representatives. So undoubtedly that chamber, if the interests of its majority party are in any way affected, will engage in such an exercise whereas this chamber, which may have more sympathy at that point with the Opposition parties, may very well be deprived of a similar possibility. Not being terribly supportive of the ruling parties in terms of the Parliament, I must admit that is a worry.

But I think probably the overriding problem is the one raised by the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) in relation to the possible legal challenges involved. While these may be far-fetched I think it is very difficult for the Democrats to support the inclusion in this Bill of propositions which may bring a redistribution under question. A redistribution, quite frankly, is at the heart of the whole exercise. If somewhere down the path that in fact occurred I think it would be probably one of the most damaging moves that could occur. Whereas in the rest of this Bill a variety of amendments could be made with very little significant damage, changes at this point can have an extremely pervasive effect on the electoral process. It is very difficult for us to support the amendments.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 33, clause 9, line 38, leave out ''(4)'', insert ''(6)''.

If one looks at page 37 of the Bill it is fairly obvious that '25ZC (4)' ought to read '25ZC (6)' because that is the reference on page 37. It is only a technical matter, but I believe the reference could not possibly be to proposed new section 25ZC (4).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin is correct. We are indebted to him for his thoughtful observation on the deficiencies of the legislation and accept his amendment accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 10 to 14-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 15 (Form of rolls).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 42, clause 15, lines 11 to 19, leave out the clause, insert the following new clause:
''15. After section 31 of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:
Overseas and itinerant electors
'31A. Where an elector is an eligible overseas elector or an itinerant elector, the Roll shall not set out the place of living of the elector.'.''.

The Opposition seeks here to express a slightly different view about what is the minimum amount of information which should be on the electoral roll. That is really all there is to this issue. Accepting the Government's intention to simplify the roll and having no objection to that, the issue is whether the information available should be more than is proposed in the clause as it has been put forward by the Government. We think that problems can arise within an electorate if residents share a common name and even an address. The amendment as we have moved it would produce the result I am talking about which would require extra information to remain on the electoral roll. I refer to the gender and the occupation of the elector. The principal Act already contains what is shown here as clause 15 (2). We seek not to interfere with that which is already part of the Act. The Government proposes to introduce clause 15 (1) which we want to take out. We seek simply to add that little bit of extra information to the roll. We do not believe that to have that information on the roll is any undue intrusion upon people's privacy, but it may assist in providing identification and it may be useful. We think, in fact, that there may be benefit in having the extra information. I could expand on the reasons why that should be so, but it is a simple point and we propose the amendment accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point, for all its simplicity, does not commend itself to the Government. The Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill, in its original form, did involve an attempt to remove references to occupational category and sex from tagging electors on the rolls-sex for reasons of privacy and occupations for reasons, amongst others, of the difficulty of maintaining an up to date reference of this kind. It is not an amendment that either side is likely to want to go to the barriers over let alone a division, but it does represent closer conformity with the considered views of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform to keep the Bill as it is and to reject this amendment. I recommend to the Committee accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Australian Democrats support the view of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform which recommended the elimination of those pieces of information from the rolls.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 16 to 22-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 23 (Persons entitled to enrolment and to vote).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Page 47, Paragraph 23 (e), proposed new paragraph 39 (6) (b), line 21, leave out ''5 years'', insert ''1 year''.

The purpose of this amendment is to seek to alter the duration of sentence which will disqualify a convicted person as an elector. At the present time the Constitution provides that certain people are disqualified from becoming candidates by virtue of a conviction-

TALK.START.PARA: —Not candidates; members of parliament.

—From becoming members of parliament. I thank Senator Ray. They may become candidates but if elected they cannot take their place. But they may not become members of parliament if they are under sentence on a charge which carries a prison sentence of one year or more. We have seen occasions on which members of parliament have been charged and when people have taken some care to make sure that the matter with which they are charged carried a sentence of less than one year. However, what is proposed is that such a person would be able to vote if he were under sentence for up to five years. For the first time in Australia this would create a situation which the qualifications to be an elector and the qualifications to be a member of parliament would be separated. Of course, the qualifications to be a member of parliament are constitutional qualifications. What is being proposed in this Bill is that the qualifications to be an elector should be relaxed. The Opposition believes that there should be a commonality between the standards required of a member of parliament and those required of an elector. We believe that there is logic in the situation that has existed. We cannot see the purpose of the change which is contained in the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill. We think the severity of the penalty that prevents people from holding a seat in the Parliament should be the same as that applying to people having the right to vote.

—I would like to express first of all a purely personal view and then a view on behalf of the Australian Democrats. My view is-I have expressed it in the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform- that the criminal activities of people and sentences from which they may suffer ought not be relevant to their rights as citizens to engage in the political process. To deprive citizens of political rights because of criminal or civil activities, or crimes, is inappropriate in a democracy. I believe it smacks more of the operations that one associates with the Soviet Union. However, my Party has considered the matter and the agreement that my colleagues and I have come to is that we will support the five-year term as it is a liberalisation. It is also more in keeping with the penalties which may be imposed of a kind that may not have been envisaged, certainly not at the turn of the century. We believe, therefore, that the clause as it is contained in the Bill ought to stand, and we will vote against the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, the Government takes the trendy libertarian view that things have advanced a little since the days of Sherwood Forest and that simply because someone has been convicted of an offence punishable by a year or more in gaol, that person ought not be rendered an outlaw and denied access to other civil rights normally enjoyed by Australian citizenry. In that respect we share the sentiments of the Australian Democrats which were, in turn, the sentiments of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the point made by Senator Baume about the provisions of section 44 of the Constitution, I remind him that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, formerly chaired by Senator Missen, in fact brought down a report on the qualifications of members of parliament which made a number of recommendations including the inappropriateness of the continued application of that particular section in those terms as it affected members of parliament. So any reliance in that source of authority by way of argument from analogy or extension I think breaks down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not put it in a referendum?
—In due course, if we thought we had a chance of Senator Harradine's support, we would leap in there like a rabbit into a burrow. We suggest that for these reasons the amendment ought to be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I am reminded of the story about George Bernard Shaw who made a certain proposition to a lady and mentioned a sum of money, which was a penny, and she said 'How dare you make such a suggestion'. He made the same suggestion for a million pounds and she said she was interested. It turned out they were not haggling about the principle, but about the price. I remind those who have taken the trendy libertarian view that all we are arguing about is the extent to which they are prepared to deprive people of their rights. Let us not forget that they are quite prepared to deprive people of their rights as citizens-all we are arguing about is the price, all we are arguing about is the point at which they are willing to deprive them. Senator Macklin may say he does not believe people should be deprived; he may say it reminds him of the Soviet Union. He is still voting for a provision that will deprive people, it is just that it is slightly less onerous than the present provisions. It simply does not ring true to say that this is a trendy libertarian argument. All it is doing is shifting the pointer back slightly. Mr Chairman, I understand the way the vote will go.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise under clause 23 the fact that we still have contained within the clause the notion of unsound mind. I raised this matter with the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. It seems to me that what we have here is really an outmoded approach to mental illness, and I had hoped we might have been able to proceed beyond this. The problem, as I see it, is that we are suggesting that there is no differentiation across the board. For example, one could well be a professor of political science who may in fact suffer from a depressive disorder. That should not have any effect at all but such a person could very well be described as being of unsound mind.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that some more precise definition ought to have been attained as to what the Parliament believes we are trying to achieve with this clause. Presumably it is a person who is not able to vote or who is unaware of what he is doing about whom we ought to be concerned. That is a very difficult thing to achieve. Indeed, in this clause one set of judgments may be ascribed to people who may be, for example, in institutions and a different set of criteria to people who are not.
Consideration interrupted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 12 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Bustard Head monitoring station, which monitors the North Reef automatic navigational aid in Queensland, been inoperative for some period during this year; if so, does this mean that, apart from visual evidence, there has been no means of knowing during this period whether the North Reef light has been operating or not.
(2) For what period was the Bustard Head monitoring station inoperative.

(3) Would the failure of the Bustard Head monitoring station be included in statistical reports prepared and/or presented by the Department of Transport on the reliability of automatic lights, or would it be necessary to ask for seperate information on the operational reliability of monitoring stations as distinct from the actual lights.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The monitoring equipment at Bustard Head was installed in 1977 as part of a developmental system to monitor the performance of the light and associated power plant at North Reef. The use of the monitoring equipment was discontinued in July 1982. Malfunctions of unattended navigational aids are normally reported to the Department of Transport by ships following sightings of irregularities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 12 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why was the original information about the adulteration of Australian honey released to the Press before conclusive follow-up investigation took place if follow-up investigation into the cause of the adulteration of Australian honey indicated by analysis have generally been inconclusive. (See Hansard, 23 August 1983, page 102).
(2) Why did the Department of Primary Industry decide to release this original information to the Press before discussing it with those involved.
(3) Does the Minister for Primary Industry believe the release of this information was in the best interests of the industry; if so, why.
(4) Has the Department received conclusive evidence that glucose had been added to Australian honey: if so, what is the evidence and if not, why were the original reports issued by the Department.

(5) Is the Government investigating the possibility of replacing the export inspection system in favour of a system of limited random inspection: if so, when does the Minister believe a decision on this will be made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) My department was not involved in the release of the information in question. Following the initial media reports, my Department was however approached by sections of the media. They were informed that further work to refine the analytical technique was necessary.

(5) Yes. It is anticipated that the new export inspection system for honey incorporating random sampling based on objective, statistically based methodology, will be fully implemented from 1 October 1984.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Department of Defence, in or about the year 1981, receive a report from the Royal Australian Navy, emphasising the importance of the maintenance of manned light-stations on the New South Wales coast; if not, is the Department of Defence aware of the existence of such a report.

(2) Did the Department of Defence inform the current House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure's inquiry into lightstations, that it had no comments to make on the issue of manned lightstations; if so, why was this submission made if, in fact, the abovementioned Royal Australian Navy report was in the Department's possession.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no RAN report such as described in Senator Hamer's question. Navy Office wrote to the Department of Transport in late 1980. The letter indicated that while there is no justification for lightstations to be manned in peacetime , it was considered desirable that key lightstations be manned in times of war or tension. Earlier correspondence within Navy Office recommended that the matter of automation of lightstations should be taken up with the Department of Transport.

(2) The Department of Defence has not made, or been asked to make, a submission to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure in connection with its current inquiry into lightstations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the details of any employment or disciplinary policies of any of the defence forces which prohibit or discriminate against the employment of lesbians and/or homosexual men.
(2) Will these policies change when the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 is proclaimed, if such policies exist.
(3) Will the Minister arrange for these policies to be revoked, if there is no legal justification for such policies (and such policies do exist).
(4) Will the Minister present appropriate amendments to the relevant Act or Acts to the Parliament for consideration, if there is legal justification for such policies (and such policies do exist).
(5) Are homosexuals still being discharged 'On Request' on the basis of defence forces policies on homosexual conduct.

(6) Was the Minister and/or either of the two previous Ministers at any time under the impression that the passage of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 would mean an end to formal discrimination within the forces against consenting adult lesbians and/or homosexual men.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A common policy regarding homosexuality is applied throughout the Defence Force. This policy recognises that condonation of homosexuality can prejudice effective command relationships and the maintenance of the high levels of morale and discipline necessary for the efficient functioning of the Services. It provides that, although confirmed homosexuals are not retained in the Defence Force, their cases are treated sympathetically and with discretion. They are discharged administratively unless factors such as assault, coercion, some public display or interference with a minor are involved. When such factors are present, the provisions of Service disciplinary law can be applied and a prosecution can be initiated.

(2) No. The Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 relates to action that may be taken following the detection of offences. If it is determined that disciplinary action should be taken against a Service member, then the provisions of that Act , once proclaimed, will apply.

(3)No. The present policy of administratively discharging confirmed homosexuals is considered to be essential for the effectiveness of the Defence Force and for the maintenance of a cohesive ethos necessary for military discipline. That policy does not need to be backed up by legislation.
(5) See (1) above.
(6) No. In respect of my predecessors, I am unable to comment.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Convention on the Transfer of Sentenced Persons

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 13 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government aware of the decision of a number of European nations to launch a convention to provide for the facilitating of the exchange of their nationals held in prisons abroad, and that such a convention would be available for signature by Australia and the South-East Asia Treaty Organisation nations.
(2) Is the Convention on the Transfer of Sentenced Persons yet in force.
(3) Will Australia sign the Convention on the Transfer of Sentenced Persons.
(4) Will the Australian Government urge our SEATO allies to sign the Convention on the Transfer of Sentenced Persons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(3) Australia would be prepared to give positive consideration to the question of accession to the convention when it enters into force. However, it would first be necessary for agreement to be reached with the Australian States, because in Australia the prison system is in the hands of the States rather than the Federal Government. The absence of federal prisons in Australia means that repatriated prisoners would have to be housed in State prisons, and foreigners currently imprisoned in State prisons would become entitled to apply for transfers out of Australia under the terms of the convention. The Attorney- General in his answer to a question without notice from Senator Kilgariff on 6 October 1983 (see page 1236 of the Senate Hansard) commented on the present position as regards consultations with the States on this matter.

(4) Subject to the successful completion of consultations with the States, Australia would be prepared to consider entering into prisoner transfer agreements, either bilateral or multilateral, with countries in which Australian citizens are imprisoned. It may turn out to be true that the best way of doing this with countries which find the terms of the Council of Europe Convention acceptable would be to encourage their accession to it, when once Australia had also decided that it should accede to it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it expected that the taxing of Defence Force Reserve personnel will induce some resignations; if so, how many.
(2) How then will the Government seek to restore the present numbers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is committed to ensuring that the incidence of taxation falls fairly on all citizens and considers that the present total exemption from taxation of Reserve Forces' earnings is unfairly regressive, with the greater benefit accruing to those in the higher income bracket. Those on lower incomes, or unemployed, gain the least or even no benefit from the exemption.

There is much to be said for the principle that income from all sources should be subject to taxation. It is generally preferable that rates of remuneration be established on their own merits and that taxation apply to all earnings.

However, in view of the concerns which have been expressed in relation to the proposed phasing out of the tax exemption on Reserve Forces' earnings, and taking into account claims which have been made regarding the fairness and effects on the Reserve Forces if the earnings of its members are fully taxable, the Government has decided that one half of the pay and allowances will remain exempt from tax, with effect from 1 December 1983.

This will have the effect of restricting the rate of tax on total Reserve pay to a maximum of 30 per cent, while those in lower income brackets will have an even lower effective rate of tax. This represents a balance between the considerations of fairly imposing taxation to which I have referred and recognising the particular circumstances of part time service in the Reserve Forces.

Further, the Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay is inquiring into appropriate pay and allowances for the Reserve Forces in the light of the Government's decision to apply taxation to their earnings. The Committee has been asked to report no later than 30 June 1984.
These two decisions demonstrate the Government's support of the Reserve Forces and there is no reason why members should be contemplating resigning.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, upon notice, on 21 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: How many of the 30 women appointed to senior positions and referred to by the Minister in answer to a question without notice on 14 September 1983 (see Hansard, 14 September 1983, page 666) were at any time Australian Labor Party candidates for election to public office.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In undertaking appointments to statutory and other government bodies it is not the practice of the Government to ask candidates whether they are or have been candidates for election to public office.

There are well established procedures for selection and appointment of qualified women and men to Government bodies. Such procedures do not include an examination of a potential candidate's membership of any political party.

It would therefore be improper to waste government resources attempting to ascertain whether any of the highly competent, able and qualified women who have been appointed since this Government took office were at any time previously candidates of any party for election to public office.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 2 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Attorney-General aware that citizens in the Northern Territory, and particularly Aboriginal people, would have their legal rights curtailed by many provisions contained in the Northern Territory Criminal Code Act, such as: (a) the abolition of the unsworn statement; (b) the reversal of the onus of proof in certain cases; (c) the payment of costs and imprisonment until such costs are paid even though the accused has been acquitted; and (d) by making attempted suicide punishable by imprisonment for one year.

(2) Is the Attorney-General aware that the substantive right Aborigines have not to be sentenced to mandatory life imprisonment for murder, and to have their customary law taken into account, has been abolished and that no provision has been made to take account of Aboriginal customary law.

(3) Is the Attorney-General aware of the provisions in the proposed Act which severely limit the political rights of people under the guise of anti-terrorist measures by enabling the Executive Council to proscribe an organisation and then : (a) prohibit any meetings of that organisation including a meeting which might be called for the purpose of challenging the proscription; (b) prohibit wearing a dress or displaying a sign of the proscribed organisation; and (c) punish offenders by imprisonment.

(4) Does the Governor-General, acting on advice of the Executive Council and under the provisions of the Northern Territory Self Government Act 1976, have power to disallow this legislation, even though it has received the assent of the Northern Territory Administration.
(5) Has this legislation been considered by the Executive Council or by Cabinet ; if so, what action, if any, does the Government intend to take.
(6) Could the Attorney-General give consideration to a reply within seven days in view of the urgency of this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that the Northern Territory Criminal Code Act:
(a) abolishes the right of an accused to make an unsworn statement from the dock;
(b) reverses the onus of proof in relation to intent in cases where the accused is intoxicated at the time of the offence;
(c) permits, where an accused person is acquitted by reason of voluntary intoxication, a court to order the payment by that person of:
(i) the cost of bringing the charge including the costs of the investigations,
(ii) the cost of the committal hearing;
(iii) an amount of compensation or restitution and further permits the court to ;
(iv) order the imprisonment or release on bail of the person pending the assessment of costs or compensation; and
(v) order the imprisonment of the person for failure to comply with any order made.
(d) makes attempted suicide an offence punishable by imprisonment for one year.

(2) I am also aware that under the existing law, the Northern Territory Supreme Court has a sentencing discretion in relation to Aboriginal persons convicted of murder and that the Code abolishes this and replaces it with a mandatory life sentence upon conviction of murder, regardless of the race of the convicted person. The Code makes no express provision to take account of Aboriginal customary law in determining criminal liability, although the Northern Territory Administration claims that in murder cases the defence of coercion produces the same result. The Australian Law Reform Commission has provisionally expressed doubts about this interpretation.

(3) The Code permits the Executive Council to proscribe organisations subject to the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory approving this proscription within 14 days. It is an offence to arrange, to assist in the arrangement, to manage or to address any meeting of 3 or more persons knowing that the meeting is to support or to further the activities of a proscribed organisation. It is also an offence to be similarly involved in any such meeting which is to be addressed by any person who belongs or professes to belong to a proscribed organisation. These offences carry a maximum period of imprisonment of two years. The wearing in public of an item of dress or the wearing, carrying or displaying of any sign or article from which it can reasonably be inferred that the wearer is a member or supporter of a proscribed organisation are also made offences, carrying a maximum period of imprisonment of six months.
(4) Yes.

(5) Following considering by the Prime Minister, the Attorney-General, the Minister for Territories and Local Government and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Prime Minister wrote to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory on 17 November, 1983 requesting reconsideration and appropriate amendment of a number of provisions in the Code in respect of which widespread concern is evident.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Are animals used for experiments carried out within the Defence Department; if so, under what guidelines are these experiments conducted to ensure that undue or unnecessary cruelty to these animals is prevented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: A small number of animals is used for experiments at the Materials Research Laboratories (MRL) of the Department of Defence at Maribyrnong, Victoria.

MRL complies with the provisions of the Victorian Protection of Animals Act 1966. Information on all experiments involving animals is reported bi-annually to the office of the Chief Secretary, Government of Victoria.
Animals are anaesthetised prior to experimentation and are euthanised before recovery from the anaesthetic.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Australian of 11 September 1982 carry a report on the FFG frigate HMAS Canberra which attributed a number of comments critical of the ship to its Captain, Commander Wilson.

(2) Did the report state that Commander Wilson had said that the ship was 'a military wreck'; that it would not be ready for battle for two years because of deficiencies overlooked by the Government; that it lacks stabilisers for its helicopter pad; that it lacks a close-in weapons system; and that it lacks a means of shooting down aircraft.
(3) Did the report further state that the former Prime Minister was present when Commander Wilson made his remarks and that the Prime Minister responded to them.
(4) Did the former Minister for Defence state in the House of Representatives on 15 September 1982 that Commander Wilson claimed to have been 'totally misrepresented' by the report.
(5) With respect to each of the statements cited in parts (2) and (3), what was (a) the nature; and (b) the extent of the misrepresentation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Weekend Australian of the 11-12 September 1982 did print an article which attributed a number of critical comments to the Commanding Officer of the HMAS Canberra. The Chief of Naval Staff clarified the misrepresentations in a letter to the editor which was printed in the Weekend Australian of 25-26 September 1982. It is significant that the editor included the following note: 'The Captain of HMAS Canberra, Commander Bryan Wilson, has also written to the Australian on this topic. He categorically denies having used the words ' military wreck' and stresses that he is intensely proud of his ship and his crew despite the vessel's acknowledged deficiencies. We never doubted it. We apologise to the Commander and the Royal Australian Navy for having emphasised these-apparently temporary-deficiencies at the expense of Canberra's many virtues.'

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister for Defence provide overpressure estimates for the detonation of: (a) a 130 kilogram (b) a 200 kilogram (c) a 300 kilogram and (d) a 500 kilogram charge of: (a) conventional high explosive; and (b) fuel-air explosive at distances of: (i) zero metres (ii) 5 metres (iii) 10 metres (iv) 20 metres (v ) 40 metres (vi) 50 metres (vii) 75 metres (viii) 100 metres (ix) 150 metres and (x) 200 metres.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The following table provides overpressure estimates for bare charge high explosive (HE) and fuel-air explosive (FAE)-
PEAK OVERPRESSURE (kPa)
Mass (kg)
Radius (m)
HE FAE HE FAE HE FAE HE FAE
0 A X A X A X A X

X-Inside the fuel-air cloud at this distance peak overpressures are somewhat variable and difficult to measure, but at the centre of the cloud are of the order of 2MPa, dropping to about 800 kPa near the edge. These figures are insensitive to charge size.
