QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Did a previous Minister for Defence, Sir Allen Fairhall, say to the Press on 23 April 1969 that the station at North West Cape was a target, if so, is this view also held by the present Government; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The transcript of a Press briefing given on 23 April 1969 by the then Minister for Defence, Sir Allen Fairhall, shows that Sir Allen's remarks about the possibility that North West Cape and other installations in Australia might be targets were confined to circumstances of global nuclear war.
These remarks are not inconsistent with the present Government's view that in the unlikely event of global nuclear war, the joint defence facilities in Australia could be subject to attack.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister for Defence received reports from his Department on the present Indonesian offensive in East Timor; if not, will the Minister give an undertaking that he will ask for such a report; if so, does the Minister's information confirm the information published in the Age of 25 October 1983 which indicates that the Indonesian Air Force has dropped cluster bombs, anti- personnel bombs and incendiary bombs during its present offensive in East Timor.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I receive regular intelligence briefings from my Department on developments of interest in Australia's neighbourhood. It has been the practice of successive governments to refrain from commenting publicly on the content of such briefings .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 9 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Science and Technology given the upgrading of Landsat a low priority.
(2) Are the Department of Resources and Energy and the Department of Administrative Services both vying to take over the responsibility for Landsat.

(3) What plans does the Government have for the upgrading of Landsat and will the Department of Science and Technology be given the responsibility to ensure this is achieved; if not, which Department will have the responsibility.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The diversity of science and technology programs competing for funding in the 1983-84 Budget meant that the Minister for Science and Technology was not able to accord the upgrade of the Australian Landsat Station (ALS) the highest priority.

(2) The Minister for Science and Technology considered that, as the ALS had now progressed from a research and development phase more toward an operational function, it would be better placed in another portfolio. Both the Department of Administrative Services and the Department of Resources and Energy expressed interest in assuming responsibility for the ALS. The Government has now decided to transfer responsibility for the ALS to the portfolio of Resources and Energy.
(3) The Department of Resources and Energy will be responsible for planning the future operation, including any upgrade, of the ALS once the transfer has been effected.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are there any rules or regulations which enable the Department of Defence to discriminate for employment purposes against civilian gay employees of the Department.

(2) Is discrimination against gay civilian employees of the Department practised either overtly or covertly irrespective of the existence or non- existence of such rules and regulations; if so, what is the reason for these practices.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) I am not aware of any instances of such discrimination.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 16 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that there is no Federal works program in the electoral division of Bass for 1983-84.
(2) When was the last works program in Bass.
(3) When was this program and what was it worth.
(4) What works programs are in prospect for the Bass electorate in the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are no federal works under the control of the Department of Housing and Construction in the electoral division of Bass. However there is work being undertaken by the Department of Housing and Construction for the Australian Telecommunications Commission Launceston-Mechanical Aids Workshop-new floor and floor heating $85,000.

(2) and (3) The last work under the Department of Housing and Construction's control was undertaken in the mid 1970s, within the 1975-76 program. A small project of $53,000 was carried out at Eddystone Point for the Department of Transport. The Department of Housing and Construction also undertook work for the Australian Telecommunications Commission in 1981-82 and the Australian Postal Commission in 1980-81.

(4) Subject to budgetary considerations the Department of Housing and Construction may carry out work during 1984-85 for the Department of Transport on Swan Island. Further work for the area may also arise out of the Government forward Estimates exercise later this year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 October 1983 (Hansard, page 1036) Senator Kilgariff asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, the following question without notice:

QUESTION.PARA: With respect to the Government's new First Home Owners Bill, does the Minister realise the disadvantages that the scheme's $27,900 annual taxable income limit- that, of course, includes the individual incomes of a married couple being taken together as one income-will place on people living in remote areas of Australia where the cost of living is much higher than it is in the cities and metropolitan areas? Will the Government review the scheme and, in particular, the means test so that people of the outback who are currently earning more than the income limit will be eligible to receive financial assistance for their first home through the First Home Owners Scheme?
The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In fact, the income test provisions of our First Home Owners Scheme, including the maximum qualifying levels, are similar to those set by the previous Government for its Home Deposit Assistance Scheme. The upper income limit above which no benefit is payable is set at 155 per cent of average weekly earnings.

During the preparation of the new scheme, consideration was given to regional variations in income limits just as it was given to regional variations in property prices. The levels of the income test and of benefits was determined accordingly. It was noted that it was impractical to administer in a satisfactory way a scheme which had different income limits and benefits for different regions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 October 1983 (Hansard, page 1032) Senator Townley asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

QUESTION.PARA: I refer to an advertisement for Telecom Australia mobile phones which says, in part:
'Of course, you'll be saving time not having to hunt for Public Phones . . .'

I ask: Is this advertisement an admission by Telecom that the number of public phones throughout this country is much too low, so much so that one has actually to hunt to find one? Will the Minister ask Telecom Australia to examine the possibility of installing more public phones, particularly in remote areas, now that it has had time to analyse the increased income from such phones due to the present 20c fee?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

No. Telecom Australia provides a network of some 30,000 prominently located, modern public coin telephones which meet the needs of the vast majority of public telephone users. In addition, there are 40,000 red phone coin telephones rented from Telecom.

The costs involved in providing and maintaining the public telephone service are considerable and although the fee for local calls from public telephones was increased to 20c last year, it is expected that losses will continue to be incurred. It is therefore not practicable for Telecom to install public coin telephones in all remote area locations where the amount of usage will not offset, to a reasonable degree, the high costs associated with providing the public telephone service.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 October 1983 (Hansard, page 1323) Senator Reynolds asked me , as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the National Diseases Control Program.

QUESTION.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

On 15 September 1983 the office of the Queensland Minister for Health was invited to issue a press statement, on 20 September 1983, by the Hon. A.P.D. Bertoni and myself jointly. Whilst the statement concerned the Commonwealth's offer of funding for the Queensland component of the National Diseases Control Program, it was similar to those proposed for joint release on 20 September 1983 by the States mentioned by the honourable senator and by the Northern Territory.

Subsequently, on 26 September 1983 advice was received from the Queensland Minister's office that the statement had been released that day advising of the Commonwealth's offer of $164,000 on a dollar for dollar basis for control of mosquito borne diseases in Queensland.
The intention is that Commonwealth and State funds will be utilised in Queensland to establish a vector control unit to co-ordinate the State's mosquito control program.

The Commonwealth Government has significantly boosted its funding for mosquito control program and research from $193,000 in 1982-83 to $489,000 in 1983-84. This reflects its concern at the increased incidence of mosquito borne diseases in northern Australia, particularly dengue fever.

Of all the States participating in the program, Queensland gained the most of this increased effort. It received a boost in funds from $18,000 under the previous Government to $164,000 this year. Queensland's proportion of total funds available under the program rose from 14 per cent to 39 per cent over the same period, and now receives by far the largest proportion of available funding of all States.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Appointment to the Australian Diplomatic Service

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October 1983 (Hansard, page 1842) Senator Primmer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs assure the Senate that a full and proper investigation will be made into allegations that the son of Sir Robert Sparkes, President of the Queensland National Party, was recruited into the Australian diplomatic service earlier this year as a result of Sir Robert's influence with Mr Peter Henderson, Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs? Does the Minister agree that this example of coalition harmony in Canberra contrasts sharply with the current conflict on show in the Queensland election campaign?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
I refer the honourable senator to my answer to his Question No. 201, of 25 May 1983.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 October 1983 (Hansard, page 1938) Senator Robert Ray asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, on 21 October 1983, a question without notice relating to the use of telephones by illegal bookmakers, including the following question:

QUESTION.PARA: '. . . Finally, is it practical as suggested by Special Prosecutor Redlich, that Telecom should question the purpose for which a telephone service will be used?'
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The matters raised by Mr Redlich in his report concerning Telecom policy towards use of the network for illegal purposes are under active consideration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 October 1983, Senator Archer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, a question without notice which included whether the Minister would review the proposed withdrawal of fire fighting services from Wynyard Airport.

QUESTION.PARA: The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In an effort to reduce the costs of rescue and fire fighting services borne by the aviation industry the Department of Aviation has been reviewing the need to retain those units that no longer meet the criteria for their establishment.

By way of explanation, for domestic airports the Department uses a benchmark of an annual figure of 150,000 persons on board scheduled aircraft services as the criterion for the establishment of a rescue and fire fighting service at an airport. In this context Wynyard is marginally above the benchmark but is considered likely to drop after jet services are established into Devonport, ie it is expected that passenger rates will increase at Devonport and reduce at Wynyard due to rationalisation of traffic patterns. The situation at Devonport will of course be kept under review.

The final decision to withdraw the fire service will not be made until consultations with the staff and with the local community are completed. It should be made quite clear that all staff affected by the proposed closure will be offered positions at other locations.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Prime Minister: Payments for Speaking Engagements and Advertisements

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 November 1983 (Hansard, page 1922) Senator Walters asked me , as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question without notice concerning payments received by the Prime Minister for speaking engagements and advertisements. I undertook to provide her with answers to the following specific questions:

QUESTION.PARA: (a) Whether the parliamentary salary paid to the Prime Minister at the time when he was receiving payments for political speaking engagements was double dipping at taxpayers' expense?
(b) Is the Prime Minister remaining consistent with his previous policy by accepting payment as a bit part actor in the Medicare advertisements?
The Prime Minister has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's questions:
(a) I refer the honourable senator to my answer on 13 September 1983 (House of Representatives Hansard, page 649) to a question from Mr Spender.

(b) I am not receiving any remuneration for appearing on behalf of the Government in the Medicare advertisement. This is consistent with the longstanding policy recognised by successive governments that Ministers, because of their executive responsibilities, may derive no income from personal exertion other than that arising from their duties as a Minister and member of Parliament .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 November 1983 (Hansard, page 2255) Senator Coleman asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

QUESTION.PARA: I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It follows a question asked by Senator Richardson on 22 September relating to increased Indonesian activity in East Timor. Given that figures reporting on the situation put the number of Fretilin members at about 100, will the Minister advise on what direct action has been or will be taken by Australia to do more than express concern at the most recent reports that 10,000 armed Indonesians have been used to repress the activities of the East Timorese people in their own country?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Australian Government has been following events in East Timor closely. The honourable senator will, however appreciate that the ability of the Australian Government to influence events in East Timor is limited.

The Government welcomed the reports of peaceful contacts between the Indonesian authorities and Fretilin which from March this year resulted in a virtual ceasefire throughout East Timor. Similarly, it was with regret that the Government learnt of a reported major incident on 8 August in which ex-Fretilin villagers were said to have attacked and killed 15 Indonesian soldiers and which subsequently led to a build-up of Indonesian military forces.

The Government has already made it clear that it believes the resumption of hostilities will delay any chance of reconciliation in East Timor. It has accordingly, conveyed its concern to the Indonesian Government and will continue to urge restraint on all sides.
The Government's primary concern is to do what it reasonably can to help the East Timorese.
In this respect, Australia has contributed $6.2m to the joint Indonesian Red Cross/International Committee of the Red Cross relief program for East Timor.
Also, departures for Australia under the family reunion program have been continuing. The most recent departures were on 6 November and only three agreed 'List' cases still remain to travel.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 November 1983 (Hansard, page 2367) Senator Primmer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

QUESTION.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Minister seen the report in last week's National Times to the effect that my speech on 13 October on corruption in the Department of Foreign Affairs and my question relative to the irregular appointment by Mr Henderson to the Department of the son of Sir Robert Sparkes were cut out of the Department's magazine Backgrounder? Does this act indicate censorship by some person or persons within that Department? What was the cost, via wastage, of the exercise?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The publication Backgrounder is as is set out on the cover sheet of each issue, 'part of the Foreign Affairs Department's program for disseminating information about foreign affairs and Australia's role and interests therein.' Decisions must be taken as to whether material is relevant or appropriate for inclusion on this basis. It is not a question of censorship. The allegations made by Senator Primmer, as I have made clear, are without foundation. It was therefore decided that they should not be circulated yet again. Any waste of paper which may have occurred was caused by the failure of the officer responsible to consult with his supervisor. This failure has been taken up by the supervisor with the officer concerned.
